Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute inaccurate late payment entries on my credit report regarding my account with XXXX XXXX  ( Account # XXXX ). These late payments appear to be reported in error, as the account is marked as Current across all bureaus and there is no valid evidence to support these entries. This is a violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and my rights as a consumer. 
Details : 1. Account Information : o Account Type : Revolving ( Flexible Spending Credit Card ).

o High Credit : TransUnion and XXXX : {$13000.00}. 
XXXX : {$0.00} ( inaccurate or incomplete ). 
o Credit Limit : {$12000.00} across all bureaus. 
o Balance : {$0.00} across all bureaus. 
2. Payment Status : o Listed as Current across all three credit bureaus. 
3. Late Payments Reported : o TransUnion : Reports " 60 days late '' ( XX/XX/XXXX ) and " 30 days late '' ( XX/XX/XXXX ). 
o XXXX : Reports " 60 days late '' ( XX/XX/XXXX ) and " 30 days late '' ( XX/XX/XXXX ). 
o XXXX : Reports " 60 days late '' ( XX/XX/XXXX ) and " 30 days late '' ( XX/XX/XXXX ). 
4. Comments and Anomalies : o TransUnion and XXXX comments are missing critical context. 
o XXXX mentions, " Amount in XXXX column is credit limit, '' which doesn't clarify the reason for the reported late payments. 
5. Activity Dates : o Date Last Active : TransUnion : XX/XX/XXXX. XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Date of Last Payment : TransUnion and XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX Discrepancies and Issues : 1. Late Payment Reporting Conflict : o The account is marked as Current across all bureaus, yet late payments for XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX are reported. 
o If the account was " Current, '' these late payments are invalid and must be removed. 
2. Inconsistent High Credit : o XXXX reports a High Credit of {$0.00}, which contradicts the reported high credit of {$13000.00} on TransUnion and XXXX. 
3. Future Reporting Dates : o TransUnion and XXXX report " Last Reported '' as XX/XX/XXXX, while XXXX lists XX/XX/XXXX. Reporting dates in the future violate the FCRA 's accuracy requirements. 
4. Date Discrepancies : o Date Last Active and Date of Last Payment vary across bureaus, suggesting potential inaccuracies in reporting. 
5. Payment Status Mismatch : o The account status being " Current '' conflicts with the late payments reported for XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX. 
Violation of Consumer Protection Laws : Violations of 15 U.S.C. 1681 ( FCRA ) : 1. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies are required to ensure maximum possible accuracy of consumer information. Reporting late payments on a current account violates this standard. 
2. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : I have the right to dispute any inaccurate information on my credit report. The bureau must conduct a reasonable reinvestigation to verify its accuracy. 
3. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) : If the disputed information can not be verified as accurate, it must be promptly deleted or corrected. 
4. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : Information furnishers, such as creditors, are prohibited from knowingly reporting inaccurate information. 
5. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( b ) : Upon receiving notice of a dispute, the furnisher must investigate, review relevant information, and report its findings to the credit bureaus. 
FCRA Section 607 ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies are required to ensure maximum possible accuracy when reporting consumer information. The reporting of late payments on a current account fails to meet this standard. 
FCRA Section 611 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : I have the right to dispute any inaccurate information on my credit report and demand a thorough reinvestigation. 
FCRA Section 611 ( a ) ( 5 ) : If the information can not be verified as accurate, it must be deleted promptly. 
CFPB Standards : The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau mandates that credit bureaus and furnishers maintain fair and accurate reporting practices.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally file a complaint regarding inaccurate and adverse information that has been reported on my credit report. Despite my efforts to resolve this matter with the consumer reporting agencies, XXXX, Experian, and XXXX. My private information continues to appear on my credit file in violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). I am seeking your assistance in rectifying this issue.

1. Violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) Under 15 U.S.C. 1681b and 15 U.S.C. 1681a, consumer reporting agencies are prohibited from furnishing information without the express consent of the consumer. I have not given written consent for the reporting of the account in question, nor have I authorized the financial institution that furnished this information to report it to the credit bureaus. In fact, I have revoked any such consent, as outlined below.

2. Revocation of Consent As of the date of this letter, I am formally revoking any and all consent, whether implied or explicit, to the furnishing of this information to the credit reporting agencies. I have not provided any written consent for this account to be reported. This revocation is in full accordance with 15 U.S.C. 1681b ( a ) ( 2 ), which requires written consent from the consumer for information to be furnished to a consumer reporting agency. As such, I request that this information be immediately removed from my credit report.

3. Failure to Inform Me of My Rights Furthermore, the furnisher of the information,, has never informed me of my right to exercise my non-disclosure option as required under 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ). This failure to inform me of my rights violates the obligations placed upon them by the Fair Credit Reporting Act. I was not notified that I could object to or limit the disclosure of this account to consumer reporting agencies, as mandated under 12 CFR 1016.7.

4. Adverse Information Continues to Be Reported Without Consent Despite my objections and revocation of consent, the adverse account information has continued to be reported by the credit bureaus, which constitutes a further violation of the FCRA. As stated in 15 U.S.C. 1681 Section 602, " There is a need to ensure that consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and a respect for the consumers right to privacy. '' The continued reporting of this account, despite the lack of my consent, represents a failure to uphold these responsibilities.

5. Request for Immediate Action I made an attempt to resolve this issue directly by sending written notice of these issues to XXXX, Experian, and XXXX on XX/XX/scrub>XXXX However, the information has not been removed. As such, I am now seeking the assistance of the CFPB to rectify this matter.In 15 USC 1681C ( a ) ( 5 ) states '' Except as authorized under subsection ( b ), no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years. '' This account is an adverse item they are reporting without my permission.

I have attached copies of all relevant documentation, including some of my correspondence with the credit reporting agencies, as well as any relevant account details. I look forward to your investigation and resolution of this matter.

Thank you for your time and attention to this important issue. 

Best wishes, Without Prejudice XXXX XXXX XXXX, Authorized Rep All Rights Reserved

Product: Mortgage
Issue: Applying for a mortgage or refinancing an existing mortgage
Consumer complaint narrative:
navy federal credit union has included false information to my mortgage application and repeatedly checked my credit which has greatly lowered my credit score making me ineligible to obtain a mortgage through them. 

At least one credit reporting agency has refused to follow policy in requesting a reply from companies that report I owe them. 

I am XXXX and these false accusations are limiting my options for obtaining a mortgage at a rate commensurate to what my credit score should actually be. 

When you apply for a mortgage through navy federal credit union you pay them to run your credit. They ask for the address of the property you want to buy. When you don't buy that property nfcu requires that you start over again paying for another credit check and starting a whole new mortgage application. These additional credit check fees can put a lot of money into nfcu at the expense of the applicant. This repeated requirement to pay for credit checks greatly reduces the credit score of the XXXX applicant. I do not know if Americans that apply for a mortgage through nfcu are required to repeatedly pay for credit checks, are required to do multiple mortgage applications or if their credit scores are intentionally reduced by nfcu policy of repeated credit checks and new mortgage applications.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Product: Credit card
Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Complaint Regarding Unfair Account Closure and Charges To Whom It May Concern, I am writing to file a complaint against Capital One for unfairly charging me fees and closing my account after I made efforts to pay off my balance. My account was in good standing with a consistent history of on time payments. The situation has caused financial and emotional distress, and I believe their actions were unjustified.

Details of the Issue 1. Account Closure : Capital One closed my account after claiming a returned payment violated their terms. However, the returned payment occurred due to processing delays beyond my control.

2. Payment Made : Prior to the account closure, I paid {$800.00} toward my balance. {$500.00} one card and {$300.00} on the other card. Despite this payment, Capital One charged me for an overdraft and additional fees after the account was closed.

3. Lack of Transparency : When I contacted Capital One for clarification, they refused to acknowledge how their processing times contributed to the returned payment. When I viewed mu account in the app, I noticed my accounts were restricted. I called the company on December 19th and was told it was closed due to fraud that someone reported. As the only authorized user on the account, and having not reported of credit card being lost or stolen, I was taken aback. They have closed my account without an investigation and giving proper notice.

Why I Believe This Is Unfair The returned payment resulted from a delay in processing, not from insufficient funds or any deliberate fault on my part. The payments cleared with my bank account.

I made a good-faith effort to pay my balance, and the account closure and subsequent fees penalized me unfairly.

Capital One has not provided adequate justification or documentation to support these charges or their decision to close my account. 


Resolution Requested A refund of the overdraft and any additional fees charged after the account closure. 

An acknowledgment of how processing times contributed to the issue. 

A review of Capital Ones policies regarding returned payments and account closures to ensure fairness for other customers. 


I hope the CFPB will investigate this matter to prevent similar issues for other consumers. Please let me know if you need further details or documentation to proceed with this complaint. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

Product: Credit card
Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Sub-issue: Can't use card to make purchases
Consumer complaint narrative:
On Tuesday, XX/XX/XXXX, I made a {$1500.00} payment to my Chase Freedom credit card from my XXXX checking account using my Chase mobile app. The payment was posted to my account the same day ( XX/XX/XXXX ), but my available credit did not increase. I waited until the next day ( XX/XX/XXXX ), at which point the {$1500.00} debit from my XXXX checking had hard posted. It had now been a full business day since I'd initiated the payment, and both the credit ( Chase ) and the debit ( XXXX  ) were hard posted as final transactions on both accounts, with matching transaction Ids/reference numbers. Still, my available credit remained the same. 

I attempted to use my Chase Freedom card to pay for something yesterday ( XX/XX/XXXX ) and it was declined ; upon checking my account, my available credit had still not been updated. I thought this must be an error, as I hadn't received any emails, calls, texts, or other communications from Chase alerting me to any issues with my account. 
With my available credit still unchanged by the time I found a break in my workday this evening ( Friday, XX/XX/XXXX ), I called to find out what was going on. The first representative I spoke to acted rather strange during the call. He stammered for a few minutes about needing to check my account, and kept saying he 'needed to make sure this is really what's happening ' before he could tell me what was happening ... as if he was unfamiliar and/or surprised with what he was seeing. When he finally decided to tell me what the problem was, he stated that my payment 'has been placed on hold for review and would not be released until XX/XX/XXXX. I expressed my confusion ( and displeasure ) at hearing this and asked why it was being held, even though it had cleared the funding account and hard posted to the credit account. He mumbled something about it being Chase policy to sometimes review large payments, and I again asked why it needed to continue to be reviewed for a full week, even after clearing both accounts. He then answered with a slightly different response, stating that it was because mine was a newer account and ACH payments take several days to clear. 

After arguing about how awful and incredibly inconvenient it is for them to be doing this the weekend before XXXX, I asked to speak with a supervisor, who just repeated the same non-answers as the previous representative. ( This time, however, I was told that my payment would be held for review until XX/XX/XXXX as opposed to XX/XX/XXXX. ) I pointed out that my Chase checking account had a regular balance of $ XXXX, which is more than enough to cover my payment ( 3 times over! ). He asked if I had made this payment from my Chase checking account, to which I said no, because thats not the account I pay bills from. His response was that the accounts were not connected, so my Chase checking balance had no bearing on my Chase credit card status. ( This doesn't add up, for two reasons : 1. He asked if Id made the payment from a Chase account, implying that it DOES have some bearing on payment posting, and 2. I had asked him at one point why my first card payment had cleared immediately, as opposed to being held, and he said that it was because I HAD paid with my Chase checking account. ) At this point I said that they needed to either release my funds back to my XXXX account, or update my available credit. His response was that Chase was not in receipt of the funds, and he claimed he did not have the ability or power to override the hold, nor did he have access to anyone who did. Again, I do not believe this to be true, being that there are matching transaction IDs on both the Chase credit and the XXXX debit, since Wednesday XX/XX/XXXX. I also asked why I had not received any communication from Chase about the fact that my {$1500.00} was being held in limbo for an entire week, and he replied, 'yes you did, it's in your cardmember agreement '. 

The cardmember agreement states : As long as you make your payment in accordance with the instructions on your billing statement by the date and time payments are due, we will credit your payment as of the same day it is received. 

The Chase mobile app, on the final screen when making a payment, states : If youre paying between XXXX XXXX  and XXXX XXXX  ET, well credit your account for the date you choose, but you might not see it for 1 to 2 days. 

My due date is not until XX/XX/XXXX and my minimum payment due for this month was only {$40.00}. I already made a payment of {$250.00} on XX/XX/XXXX which was posted immediately, and I've had an automatic monthly payment of {$200.00} set to pay on the due date since I opened the account, which is to be paid on top of any pre-arranged 'Pay Over Time ' payment amounts. I also have two Chase checking accounts which have held a combined balance of $ XXXX for the past month. I have never had any derogatory items or actions on any of my Chase accounts, nor have myself or my account been flagged for fraud at any time. I have also not had a single delinquent payment or derogatory item on any of my credit cards in over 4 years.

Equifax : XX/XX/XXXX Discrepancies and Issues : XXXX. Late Payment Reporting Conflict : o The account is marked as Current across all bureaus, yet late payments for XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX are reported. 
o If the account was " Current, '' these late payments are invalid and must be removed. 
XXXX. Inconsistent High Credit : o Equifax reports a High Credit of {$0.00}, which contradicts the reported high credit of {$13000.00} on XXXX and XXXX. 
XXXX. Future Reporting Dates : o XXXX and XXXX report " Last Reported '' as XX/XX/XXXX, while Equifax lists XX/XX/XXXX. Reporting dates in the future violate the FCRA 's accuracy requirements. 
XXXX. Date Discrepancies : o Date Last Active and Date of Last Payment vary across bureaus, suggesting potential inaccuracies in reporting. 
XXXX. Payment Status Mismatch : o The account status being " Current '' conflicts with the late payments reported for XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX. 
Violation of Consumer Protection Laws : Violations of 15 U.S.C. 1681 ( FCRA ) : 1. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies are required to ensure maximum possible accuracy of consumer information. Reporting late payments on a current account violates this standard.

2. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : I have the right to dispute any inaccurate information on my credit report. The bureau must conduct a reasonable reinvestigation to verify its accuracy.

3. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) : If the disputed information can not be verified as accurate, it must be promptly deleted or corrected.

4. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : Information furnishers, such as creditors, are prohibited from knowingly reporting inaccurate information.

5. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( b ) : Upon receiving notice of a dispute, the furnisher must investigate, review relevant information, and report its findings to the credit bureaus.

FCRA Section 607 ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies are required to ensure maximum possible accuracy when reporting consumer information. The reporting of late payments on a current account fails to meet this standard.

FCRA Section 611 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : I have the right to dispute any inaccurate information on my credit report and demand a thorough reinvestigation.

FCRA Section 611 ( a ) ( 5 ) : If the information can not be verified as accurate, it must be deleted promptly. 
CFPB Standards : The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau mandates that credit bureaus and furnishers maintain fair and accurate reporting practices.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Navy Federal Credit has illegally, unlawfully reported information on my credit files, without adequate authorization. The information is a result of identity theft and is fraudulent. I have never authorized, or opened the accounts listed. This information is frivolous. I request an investigation into fraudulent activities related with my SSN and personal information. There is no legally admissible evidence to verify the accuracy of what Navy Federal Credit is reporting Account # XXXX Balance : {$2000.00} on my credit files, and this agency have not validated pursuant to the requirements of the FCRA XXXX I have never signed a wet signature of an application with Navy Federal Credit, nor have I provided any valid identification that would allow them to legally report.

Navy Federal Credit has failed to provide a copy of any wet-signed application, valid ID, or proof of authorization to support the legitimacy of their actions. In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I have not given them the authority to access or report any information related to me. This failure to provide adequate proof of the alleged debt is a violation of my rights under federal law. I requested for Navy Federal Credit to provide verifiable proof of this debt and a clear clarification of how this debt was verified. I have not received anything. This raise concerns about their compliance with legal requirements. In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I have not given them the authority to access or report any information related to me. Their actions are in violation of the FCRAs requirement for a permissible purpose in reporting credit information. This unauthorized reporting has negatively impacted my credit standing. I request that FDIC investigate this matter and take appropriate action to ensure that the erroneous and derogatory information is removed from my credit report. I am also pursuing complaints at federal levels to address these violations. I have given Navy Federal Credit a fair opportunity to clear this matter up and I am still being harassed.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative: To whom it may concern : According to FCRA Section 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681 ( l ) ), I have the right to dispute any information on my credit report that I believe is not correct. I reserve the right to dispute any information that I deem to be inaccurate. If there's something on my credit report that doesn't seem right, you can bet that I'll be taking action to get it removed.I can not recognize or accept the allegation of delinquency without factual proof. There must be some sort of evidence to back up the claim. Otherwise, I can not and will not recognize or accept the allegation. According to federal and state law, you must report any allegations with the greatest compliance and accuracy possible.You should not report any claims that you know or should know are not in compliance with regulations and the law. If you do report such claims, you could be subject to fines or other penalties. Furthermore, reporting claims that you know are not in compliance could damage the reputation of your company.I am writing to inform you that you need to make sure all your claims are factual and certified before reporting them. This is required by the XXXX XXXX reporting standard. I request that you provide evidence to support the existence of the account and evidence that the account was used for a permissible purpose. Please provide any documents or records you may have that can help corroborate the account and it's permissible purpose.I am giving you 30 days to investigate the matter and determine whether it is still being reported accurately and in compliance with regulations. If it is not, I want it removed from the report.I hereby authorize you to take whatever steps are necessary to correct my credit. Please send me physical proof of any actions taken on my behalf. I appreciate your help in making sure my credit is in good standing.

Future Reporting Dates : o XXXX and Experian : Last Reported is XX/XX/XXXX. 
o XXXX : Last Reported is XX/XX/XXXX.

2. Payment History Discrepancies : o XXXX and XXXX : Show several months with " 30/60/90-day late payments ''. 
o Experian : Shows no similar late payment entries. 
o If the account is listed as " Current, '' there should be no late payments reported. 

3. Comments Conflicts : o XXXX and Experian : State " Consumer Statement Item in Dispute by Consumer. '' o XXXX : States " Consumer disputes - reinvestigation in progress. '' o These conflicting comments indicate unresolved or inconsistent handling of disputes. 
4. Number of Months ( Terms ) Inconsistency : o XXXX and Experian : Show 564 months. 
o XXXX : Shows 0 months, which is inaccurate or incomplete. 
5. High Credit vs. Balance : o Balance : {$480000.00}. 
o High Credit : {$500000.00}.

o The balance does not exceed the high credit, but it requires proper documentation to ensure accuracy. 
6. Date Discrepancies : o Date Last Active : XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
Experian : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : Missing. 
o Date of Last Payment : XXXX and XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
Experian : Missing. 



Violation of Consumer Protection Laws : Violations of 15 U.S.C. 1681 ( FCRA ) : 1. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies are required to ensure maximum possible accuracy of consumer information. Reporting late payments on a current account violates this standard.

2. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : I have the right to dispute any inaccurate information on my credit report. The bureau must conduct a reasonable reinvestigation to verify its accuracy.

3. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) : If the disputed information can not be verified as accurate, it must be promptly deleted or corrected.

4. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : Information furnishers, such as creditors, are prohibited from knowingly reporting inaccurate information.

5. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( b ) : Upon receiving notice of a dispute, the furnisher must investigate, review relevant information, and report its findings to the credit bureaus.

FCRA Section 607 ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies are required to ensure maximum possible accuracy when reporting consumer information. The reporting of late payments on a current account fails to meet this standard.

FCRA Section 611 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : I have the right to dispute any inaccurate information on my credit report and demand a thorough reinvestigation.

Alleged Name and Address of Creditor : ii. Name on File of alleged debtor : iii. Alleged Account Number : iv. Amount of alleged debt : v. Date that this alleged debt became payable : vi. Date of original charge off or delinquency : vii. Amount paid if debt was purchased : viii. Please attach a copy of any signed agreement debtor has made with debt collector, or other verifiable proof that debtor has a contractual obligation to pay debt collector ; ix. Furnish a copy of the original promissory note/agreement redacting My social security number to prevent identity theft and state that your client named above is the holder in due course of the note agreement and will produce the original for My own and a judges inspection should there be a trial to contest these matters ; x. Verify as a third party debt collector, you have not purchased evidence of the alleged debt and are proceeding with collection activity in the name of the original maker of the note ; xiii. Verify you know and understand that certain clauses in a contract of adhesion, such as a so-called forum selection clause, are unenforceable unless the party to whom the contract is extended could have rejected the clause without impunity ; xiv. Verify that you know and understand that contacting Me again after receipt of this notice without providing procedurally proper validation of the debt constitutes the use of interstate communications in a scheme of fraud by advancing a writing, which you know is false with the intention that others rely on the written communication to their detriment a violation of 18 United States Code Section 1341. Unauthorized Inquiries : XXXX XXXX XXXX : XXXX XXXX XXXX  : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX : XXXX These inaccuracies not only compromise the integrity of my credit report but also raise serious concerns about compliance with FCRA standards, particularly 605 and 611, which require credit reporting agencies to ensure accurate and verifiable information. 

I demand a verified, comprehensive, and truthful explanation for each item on my report. If these entries can not be substantiated with proper documentation, including my signature or electronic authorization, I expect them to be removed immediately. 

This situation has jeopardized the accuracy of my credit profile and could lead to potential financial repercussions. I insist on prompt action to rectify these errors, as accuracy and compliance are essential to safeguarding my creditworthiness and financial security.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute inaccurate late payment entries on my credit report regarding my account with XXXX XXXX ( Account # XXXX ). These late payments appear to be reported in error, as the account is marked as Current across all bureaus and there is no valid evidence to support these entries. This is a violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and my rights as a consumer. 
Details of Dispute : Account Name : XXXX XXXX  Account Number : XXXX Disputed Late Payment Entries : o XXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX With discrepancies o XXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX With discrepancies o Experian : XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX With Discrepancies Additional Inaccuracies and Issues 1. Future Reporting Dates : o XXXX and Experian : Last Reported is XX/XX/XXXX. 
o XXXX : Last Reported is XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Reporting dates in the future violates the FCRA 's accuracy and timeliness requirements. 
2. Payment History Discrepancies : o XXXX and XXXX : Show several months with " XXXX late payments ''. 
o Experian : Shows no similar late payment entries. 
o If the account is listed as " Current, '' there should be no late payments reported. 

XXXX. Comments Conflicts : o XXXX and Experian : State " Consumer Statement Item in Dispute by Consumer. '' o XXXX : States " Consumer disputes - reinvestigation in progress. '' o These conflicting comments indicate unresolved or inconsistent handling of disputes. 
4. Number of Months ( Terms ) Inconsistency : o XXXX and Experian : Show 564 months. 
o XXXX : Shows 0 months, which is inaccurate or incomplete. 
5. High Credit vs. Balance : o Balance : {$480000.00}.

o High Credit : {$500000.00}.

o The balance does not exceed the high credit, but it requires proper documentation to ensure accuracy. 
XXXX. Date Discrepancies : o Date Last Active : XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
Experian : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : Missing. 
o Date of Last Payment : XXXX and XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
Experian : Missing. 



Violation of Consumer Protection Laws : Violations of 15 U.S.C. 1681 ( FCRA ) : 1. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies are required to ensure maximum possible accuracy of consumer information. Reporting late payments on a current account violates this standard.

2. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : I have the right to dispute any inaccurate information on my credit report. The bureau must conduct a reasonable reinvestigation to verify its accuracy.

3. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) : If the disputed information can not be verified as accurate, it must be promptly deleted or corrected.

4. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : Information furnishers, such as creditors, are prohibited from knowingly reporting inaccurate information.

5. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( b ) : Upon receiving notice of a dispute, the furnisher must investigate, review relevant information, and report its findings to the credit bureaus.

FCRA Section 607 ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies are required to ensure maximum possible accuracy when reporting consumer information. The reporting of late payments on a current account fails to meet this standard.

FCRA Section 611 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : I have the right to dispute any inaccurate information on my credit report and demand a thorough reinvestigation.

FCRA Section 611 ( a ) ( 5 ) : If the information can not be verified as accurate, it must be deleted promptly.

CFPB Standards : The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau mandates that credit bureaus and furnishers maintain fair and accurate reporting practices.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XX/XX/2024 Subject : Formal Complaint Regarding Inaccurate Late Payment Reporting Dear CFPB, I am filing a formal complaint against Experian for failing to correct inaccurate information regarding late payments reported on my credit report. Despite multiple requests for correction ( letters dated XX/XX/2024 and XX/XX/2024 ), no changes have been made to resolve this issue, in violation of both the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ). Since my last dispute, nothing has changed, and the errors remain on my credit report. 
FCRA Violations : Under 15 U.S. Code 1666b, creditors must send periodic statements at least 21 days before the payment due date. The inaccurate late payment reporting suggests a failure to comply with this requirement.

15 U.S. Code 1681i mandates that credit reporting agencies ensure the accuracy of information in consumer files. This obligation has not been upheld in my case. 
TILA Violations : The Truth in Lending Act requires creditors to provide accurate and timely disclosures to consumers. The incorrect reporting of late payments has caused significant harm to my creditworthiness and financial well-being. 
Summary of Errors and Discrepancies : The reported late payments for this account are inconsistent and inaccurate across different months and reporting periods. Specific discrepancies include : Late payments reported for months where no late payments occurred. 
Different late payment statuses reported across credit bureaus. 
Dates of delinquency that do not align with the accounts actual payment history. 
These errors significantly misrepresent my credit history and have negatively impacted my creditworthiness.

Desired Resolution : Immediate removal of the inaccurate late payment notations from my credit report.

Written confirmation of the correction.

If this issue is not resolved promptly, I will escalate my complaint further, including potential legal action and filing additional complaints with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and other relevant agencies. 
I look forward to your prompt response to this matter. Please send confirmation of the corrections to the address provided above. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I recently conducted a review of my credit report and found several items that have caused me significant distress. These items appear to be unverifiable, inaccurate, and questionable. Your agency has failed to ensure the accuracy of the information as required under 15 U.S. Code 1681e ( b ) Accuracy of Reports. This statute mandates that consumer reporting agencies must follow reasonable procedures to ensure the maximum possible accuracy of the information they report.

Furthermore, under 15 U.S. Code 1681i ( 5 ) Treatment of Inaccurate or Unverifiable Information, you are required to promptly delete or modify any information found to be inaccurate, incomplete, or unverifiable during a reinvestigation. If you are unable to provide me with verifiable proof of the accuracy of the disputed items within 15 days of your investigation, these accounts and the related information must be removed from my credit report. 

Additionally, under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), I do not recognize any of the alleged creditors or debt collectors. I have never entered into a valid contract with any of these entities, nor have I engaged in any transactions with them. As such, these accounts are fraudulent and and inaccurate information.

Moreover, under the Fair Credit Billing Act, my right to privacy has been violated, and this breach infringes upon my rights as outlined in The Privacy Act of 1974. Removing the inaccurate and fraudulent information from my credit report will help restore my privacy and prevent further violations.

I am uploading a copy of my XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX credit report for your review. I kindly request that you investigate this matter and facilitate the re-instatement of my account on my credit report. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I look forward to your response. 

Sincerely,

Consumer complaint narrative:
Recently, I did an investigation on my credit report and found several items on there to be inaccurate. 

Under 15 U.S Code 1681e ( b ) Accuracy of report Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report. It shall follow reasonable procedures to assure the maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates.

15 U.S. Code 1691i ( 5 ) Treatment of inaccurate or unverifiable information ( A ) In general if, after any reinvestigation under paragraph ( 1 ) of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency shall ( i ) promptly delete that item of information from the file of the consumer, or modify that item of information as appropriate, based on the results of the investigation; and ( ii ) promptly notify the furnisher of that information that the information has been modified or deleted from the file of the consumer.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
XX/XX/XXXX Subject : Formal Complaint Regarding Inaccurate Late Payments on XXXX  XXXX Account Dear CFPB, I am writing to dispute inaccurate late payments reported on my XXXX XXXX account ( Account Number : XXXX ). Specifically, the account reflects a 30-day late payment for XX/XX/XXXX and a XXXX late payment for XX/XX/XXXX, which are erroneous and negatively impact my creditworthiness. 
Nature of the Complaint : Inaccurate Reporting : These late payments are false, as I have maintained a consistent on-time payment history through autopay.

Violation of FCRA ( 15 USC 1681i and 1681s-2 ) : The failure to correct these inaccuracies breaches the Fair Credit Reporting Act, which mandates accuracy in consumer credit reports.

Violation of FDCPA ( 15 USC 1692e ) : Reporting incorrect payment information could qualify as a misleading or deceptive act.

Violation of TILA ( 15 USC 1601 ) : The Truth in Lending Act requires that all payment and account information be accurate.

Civil Liability Under FCRA ( 15 USC 1681n and 1681o ) : Noncompliance with these requirements exposes the responsible parties to legal penalties.

Summary of Discrepancies Experian : Reported 30-day late payment for XX/XX/XXXX and XXXX late payment for XX/XX/XXXX. 
These late payments are inaccurate, as payments were made on time. 
Requested Resolution : I request the following actions : Investigate the inaccuracies and remove the erroneous late payment entries. 
Update my credit file to accurately reflect my history of on-time payments. 
Provide written confirmation of the corrections within 30 days, as mandated by the FCRA. 
Enclosed, you will find copies of supporting documentation to substantiate my claims. Please address this issue promptly to prevent further actions. 
Thank you for your attention to this matter. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
I have over 15 years of credit history both good and bad. I've filed bankruptcy more than once and I've had tons of accounts in collections over the years. I also have a very common name that often gets mixed up with other people with the same name. 
There are more than a dozen inaccurate addresses on my Experian credit profile. I've tried deleting them through online disputes only to be met with an error message to call XXXX. I've written a request to delete these addresses that I've never been associated with & didn't get a response and nothing happened. I called Wednesday XX/XX/XXXX as requested. The frontline representative told me they can't delete or dispute the erroneous addresses and that I should contact whichever bank/company reported it. I told them I believe some of these addresses are fraud as I've never lived there. They transferred me to the fraud department at Experian who told me the same thing. 
I believe banks/collection agencies use tools to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX / find other possible addresses to send collection notices. When they did this, they also reported these addresses that aren't mine. Regardless of however they came up with these addresses- they aren't mine. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX removed addresses that aren't mine in one simple request. Why does Experian have to be so difficult? 
I haven't been declined credit as a result of my Experian report having 19 addresses that need to be removed, nor has this impacted my credit score... it is simply inaccurate information and it needs to be removed. 
Objectively I know where I have lived and what my address is.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I sent a second request to have unauthorized inquiries removed from my credit report. The inquiries are from " XXXX XXXXXXXX '' on XXXX and XXXX, as well as " XXXX XXXX '' on XXXX. These inquiries were not authorized by me, and the company has not provided proof of authorization as required under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). According to 15 U.S. Code 1681b ( c ), credit reporting agencies must have my consent before allowing an inquiry.

Ive given them 20 days to resolve the issue, as required by the FCRAs timelines for disputing inaccuracies. If they dont remove these unauthorized inquiries or provide proof of authorization, I may take further legal action under 15 U.S. Code 1681n, which allows me to seek damages for their noncompliance.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally lodge a complaint regarding several unfamiliar accounts that have appeared on my credit report following my exposure in a national data breach. Despite my proactive efforts to address this matter, I have not received satisfactory assistance, and I am seeking your intervention to resolve the issue. 

Following the data breach, I reviewed my credit report and identified accounts that I did not open or authorize. In response, I submitted a written request to the credit bureaus, pursuant to the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), to validate the debts associated with these accounts. However, I have not received adequate documentation or validation confirming the legitimacy of these accounts.

Consumer complaint narrative:
SECTION 16.Rights of accused and of victims.

( a ) In all criminal prosecutions the accused shall, upon demand, be informed of the nature and cause of the accusation, and shall be furnished a copy of the charges, and shall have the right to have compulsory process for witnesses, to confront at trial adverse witnesses, to be heard in person, by counsel or both, and to have a speedy and public trial by impartial jury in the county where the crime was committed. If the county is not known, the indictment or information may charge venue in two or more counties conjunctively and proof that the crime was committed in that area shall be sufficient ; but before pleading the accused may elect in which of those counties the trial will take place. Venue for prosecution of crimes committed beyond the boundaries of the state shall be fixed by law. 
( b ) To preserve and protect the right of crime victims to achieve justice, ensure a meaningful role throughout the criminal and juvenile justice systems for crime victims, and ensure that crime victims rights and interests are respected and protected by law in a manner no less vigorous than protections afforded to criminal defendants and juvenile delinquents, every victim is entitled to the following rights, beginning at the time of his or her victimization : ( XXXX ) The right to due process and to be treated with fairness and respect for the victims dignity. 
( XXXX ) The right to be free from intimidation, harassment, and abuse. 
( XXXX ) The right, within the judicial process, to be reasonably protected from the accused and any person acting on behalf of the accused. However, nothing contained herein is intended to create a special relationship between the crime victim and any law enforcement agency or office absent a special relationship or duty as defined by Florida law. 
( XXXX ) The right to have the safety and welfare of the victim and the victims family considered when setting bail, including setting pretrial release conditions that protect the safety and welfare of the victim and the victims family. 
( XXXX ) The right to prevent the disclosure of information or records that could be used to locate or harass the victim or the victims family, or which could disclose confidential or privileged information of the victim. 
( XXXX ) A victim shall have the following specific rights upon request : a.The right to reasonable, accurate, and timely notice of, and to be present at, all public proceedings involving the criminal conduct, including, but not limited to, trial, plea, sentencing, or adjudication, even if the victim will be a witness at the proceeding, notwithstanding any rule to the contrary. A victim shall also be provided reasonable, accurate, and timely notice of any release or escape of the defendant or delinquent, and any proceeding during which a right of the victim is implicated. 
b.The right to be heard in any public proceeding involving pretrial or other release from any form of legal constraint, plea, sentencing, adjudication, or parole, and any proceeding during which a right of the victim is implicated. 
c.The right to confer with the prosecuting attorney concerning any plea agreements, participation in pretrial diversion programs, release, restitution, sentencing, or any other disposition of the case. 
d.The right to provide information regarding the impact of the offenders conduct on the victim and the victims family to the individual responsible for conducting any presentence investigation or compiling any presentence investigation report, and to have any such information considered in any sentencing recommendations submitted to the court. 
e.The right to receive a copy of any presentence report, and any other report or record relevant to the exercise of a victims right, except for such portions made confidential or exempt by law. 
f.The right to be informed of the conviction, sentence, adjudication, place and time of incarceration, or other disposition of the convicted offender, any scheduled release date of the offender, and the release of or the escape of the offender from custody. 
g.The right to be informed of all postconviction processes and procedures, to participate in such processes and procedures, to provide information to the release authority to be considered before any release decision is made, and to be notified of any release decision regarding the offender. The parole or early release authority shall extend the right to be heard to any person harmed by the offender. 
h.The right to be informed of clemency and expungement procedures, to provide information to the governor, the court, any clemency board, and other authority in these procedures, and to have that information considered before a clemency or expungement decision is made ; and to be notified of such decision in advance of any release of the offender. 
( XXXX ) The rights of the victim, as provided in subparagraph ( XXXX ) a., subparagraph ( XXXX ) b., or subparagraph ( XXXX ) c., that apply to any first appearance proceeding are satisfied by a reasonable attempt by the appropriate agency to notify the victim and convey the victims views to the court. 
( XXXX ) The right to the prompt return of the victims property when no longer needed as evidence in the case. 
( XXXX ) The right to full and timely restitution in every case and from each convicted offender for all losses suffered, both directly and indirectly, by the victim as a result of the criminal conduct. 
( XXXX ) The right to proceedings free from unreasonable delay, and to a prompt and final conclusion of the case and any related postjudgment proceedings.

a.The state attorney may file a good faith demand for a speedy trial and the trial court shall hold a calendar call, with notice, within fifteen days of the filing demand, to schedule a trial to commence on a date at least five days but no more than sixty days after the date of the calendar call unless the trial judge enters an order with specific findings of fact justifying a trial date more than sixty days after the calendar call.

b.All state-level appeals and collateral attacks on any judgment must be complete within two years from the date of appeal in non-capital cases and within five years from the date of appeal in capital cases, unless a court enters an order with specific findings as to why the court was unable to comply with this subparagraph and the circumstances causing the delay. Each year, the chief judge of any district court of appeal or the chief justice of the supreme court shall report on a case-by-case basis to the speaker of the house of representatives and the president of the senate all cases where the court entered an order regarding inability to comply with this subparagraph. The legislature may enact legislation to implement this subparagraph.

( 11 ) The right to be informed of these rights, and to be informed that victims can seek the advice of an attorney with respect to their rights. This information shall be made available to the general public and provided to all crime victims in the form of a card or by other means intended to effectively advise the victim of their rights under this section.

( c ) The victim, the retained attorney of the victim, a lawful representative of the victim, or the office of the state attorney upon request of the victim, may assert and seek enforcement of the rights enumerated in this section and any other right afforded to a victim by law in any trial or appellate court, or before any other authority with jurisdiction over the case, as a matter of right. The court or other authority with jurisdiction shall act promptly on such a request, affording a remedy by due course of law for the violation of any right. The reasons for any decision regarding the disposition of a victims right shall be clearly stated on the record.

( d ) The granting of the rights enumerated in this section to victims may not be construed to deny or impair any other rights possessed by victims. The provisions of this section apply throughout criminal and juvenile justice processes, are self-executing, and do not require implementing legislation. This section may not be construed to create any cause of action for damages against the state or a political subdivision of the state, or any officer, employee, or agent of the state or its political subdivisions.

( e ) As used in this section, a victim is a person who suffers direct or threatened physical, psychological, or financial harm as a result of the commission or attempted commission of a crime or delinquent act or against whom the crime or delinquent act is committed. The term victim includes the victims lawful representative, the parent or guardian of a minor, or the next of kin of a homicide victim, except upon a showing that the interest of such individual would be in actual or potential conflict with the interests of the victim. The term victim does not include the accused. The terms crime and criminal include delinquent acts and conduct.

Please note : That I wish to deal with this matter in writing and I do not give your organization permission to contact me by telephone. Should you do so, I must warn you that the calls could constitute " harassment '' and I may take action under Section 1 of the Protection from Harassment Act of XXXX and the Administration of XXXX XXXX of 1970 UCC 40 which makes it a criminal offence for a creditor or a creditors agent to make demands ( for money ) which are aimed at causing alarm, distress or humiliation, because of their frequency or manner.

I am writing to formally lodge a complaint regarding several unfamiliar accounts that have appeared on my credit report following my exposure in a national data breach. Despite my proactive efforts to address this matter, I have not received satisfactory assistance, and I am seeking your intervention to resolve the issue. 

Following the data breach, I reviewed my credit report and identified accounts that I did not open or authorize. In response, I submitted a written request to the credit bureaus, pursuant to the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), to validate the debts associated with these accounts. However, I have not received adequate documentation or validation confirming the legitimacy of these accounts.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to dispute the inaccurate reporting of a XXXX  item ( # XXXX ) on my credit report. This item was disputed and correctly deleted and removed from the systems of the original data furnisher, XXXX on XX/XX/year> as confirmed by correspondence in my possession ( See Attachment ). Despite this, your agency has claimed the item as verified upon re-investigation, thereby validating inaccurate and misleading information. 



In addition to this violation, I have not provided permissible purpose as required under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1681b ) for this item to be reported on my consumer report. This is a clear breach of my consumer rights, and the continued reporting of this item constitutes unauthorized and unlawful activity.

Under the FCRA, you are obligated to : 1. Ensure the maximum possible accuracy of the information you report ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ).

2. Conduct a reasonable investigation into disputes ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ).

3. Only report information for which a permissible purpose exists ( 15 U.S.C. 1681b ). 



Your failure to comply with these legal requirements has caused significant harm to my creditworthiness, impacting me and my family financially. 
I demand the following actions : 1. Immediate deletion of the inaccurate XXXX  item ( # XXXX ) from my credit report.

2. Written confirmation of the deletion within 30 days.

3. A written explanation of the permissible purpose, if any, under which this item was reported.

Failure to comply with this request may result in formal complaints to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and other regulatory authorities. Furthermore, I reserve the right to pursue civil remedies for willful non-compliance and violations of the FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681n ). 



To support my dispute, I have enclosed the following documentation : Correspondence from XXXX confirming the removal of the item. 

A copy of my Drivers License including a copy my utility bill. 



I expect this matter to be resolved promptly by this agency and await your confirmation of the deletion as XXXX has since complied. Thank you for your immediate attention to this critical issue.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute inaccurate late payment entries on my credit report regarding my account with XXXXXXXX XXXX  ( Account # XXXX ). These late payments appear to be reported in error, as the account is marked as Current across all bureaus and there is no valid evidence to support these entries. This is a violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and my rights as a consumer.

Details : 1. Account Information : o Account Type : Revolving ( Flexible Spending Credit Card ). 
o High Credit : XXXX and XXXX : {$13000.00}. 
Equifax : {$0.00} ( inaccurate or incomplete ). 
o Credit Limit : {$12000.00} across all bureaus.

o Balance : {$0.00} across all bureaus.

2. Payment Status : o Listed as Current across all three credit bureaus.

3. Late Payments Reported : o XXXX : Reports " 60 days late '' ( XX/XX/XXXX ) and " 30 days late '' ( XX/XX/XXXX ). 
o XXXX : Reports " 60 days late '' ( XX/XX/XXXX ) and " 30 days late '' ( XX/XX/XXXX ). 
o Equifax : Reports " 60 days late '' ( XX/XX/XXXX ) and " 30 days late '' ( XX/XX/XXXX ). 
XXXX. Comments and Anomalies : o XXXX and XXXX comments are missing critical context. 
o Equifax mentions, " Amount in H/C column is credit limit, '' which doesn't clarify the reason for the reported late payments. 
XXXX. Activity Dates : o Date Last Active : XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. Equifax : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Date of Last Payment : XXXX and XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
Equifax : XX/XX/XXXX Discrepancies and Issues : XXXX. Late Payment Reporting Conflict : o The account is marked as Current across all bureaus, yet late payments for XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX are reported. 
o If the account was " Current, '' these late payments are invalid and must be removed. 
XXXX. Inconsistent High Credit : o Equifax reports a High Credit of {$0.00}, which contradicts the reported high credit of {$13000.00} on XXXX and XXXX. 
XXXX. Future Reporting Dates : o XXXX and XXXX report " Last Reported '' as XX/XX/XXXX, while Equifax lists XX/XX/XXXX. Reporting dates in the future violate the FCRA 's accuracy requirements. 
XXXX. Date Discrepancies : o Date Last Active and Date of Last Payment vary across bureaus, suggesting potential inaccuracies in reporting. 
XXXX. Payment Status Mismatch : o The account status being " Current '' conflicts with the late payments reported for XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX. 
Violation of Consumer Protection Laws : Violations of 15 U.S.C. 1681 ( FCRA ) : 1. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies are required to ensure maximum possible accuracy of consumer information. Reporting late payments on a current account violates this standard.

2. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : I have the right to dispute any inaccurate information on my credit report. The bureau must conduct a reasonable reinvestigation to verify its accuracy.

3. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) : If the disputed information can not be verified as accurate, it must be promptly deleted or corrected.

4. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : Information furnishers, such as creditors, are prohibited from knowingly reporting inaccurate information.

5. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( b ) : Upon receiving notice of a dispute, the furnisher must investigate, review relevant information, and report its findings to the credit bureaus.

FCRA Section 607 ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies are required to ensure maximum possible accuracy when reporting consumer information. The reporting of late payments on a current account fails to meet this standard.

FCRA Section 611 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : I have the right to dispute any inaccurate information on my credit report and demand a thorough reinvestigation.

FCRA Section 611 ( a ) ( 5 ) : If the information can not be verified as accurate, it must be deleted promptly.

CFPB Standards : The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau mandates that credit bureaus and furnishers maintain fair and accurate reporting practices.

I am writing to formally dispute inaccurate late payment entries on my credit report regarding my account with XXXX XXXX XXXX Account # XXXX ). These late payments appear to be reported in error, as the account is marked as XXXX across all bureaus and there is no valid evidence to support these entries. Details of Dispute : Account Name : XXXX XXXX Account Number : XXXX Disputed Late Payment Entries : o XXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX With discrepancies o XXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX With discrepancies o Experian : XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX With Discrepancies Additional Inaccuracies and Issues XXXX. XXXX XXXX Dates : o XXXX and Experian : Last Reported is XX/XX/XXXX. 
o XXXX : Last Reported is XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Reporting dates in the future violates the FCRA 's accuracy and timeliness requirements. 
XXXX. Payment History Discrepancies : o XXXX and XXXX : Show several months with " 30/60/90-day late payments ''. 
o Experian : Shows no similar late payment entries. 
o If the account is listed as " Current, '' there should be no late payments reported. 

XXXX. Comments Conflicts : o XXXX and Experian : State " Consumer Statement Item in Dispute by Consumer. '' o XXXX : States " Consumer disputes - reinvestigation in progress. '' o These conflicting comments indicate unresolved or inconsistent handling of disputes. 
XXXX. Number of Months ( Terms ) Inconsistency : o XXXX and Experian : Show 564 months. 
o XXXX : Shows 0 months, which is inaccurate or incomplete. 
5. High Credit vs. Balance : o Balance : {$480000.00}.

o High Credit : {$500000.00}.

o The balance does not exceed the high credit, but it requires proper documentation to ensure accuracy. 
XXXX. Date Discrepancies : o Date Last Active : XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
Experian : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : Missing. 
o Date of Last Payment : XXXX and XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
Experian : Missing.

Violation of Consumer Protection Laws : Violations of 15 U.S.C. 1681 ( FCRA ) : 1. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies are required to ensure maximum possible accuracy of consumer information. Reporting late payments on a current account violates this standard.

2. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : I have the right to dispute any inaccurate information on my credit report. The bureau must conduct a reasonable reinvestigation to verify its accuracy.

3. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) : If the disputed information can not be verified as accurate, it must be promptly deleted or corrected.

4. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : Information furnishers, such as creditors, are prohibited from knowingly reporting inaccurate information.

5. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( b ) : Upon receiving notice of a dispute, the furnisher must investigate, review relevant information, and report its findings to the credit bureaus.

FCRA Section 607 ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies are required to ensure maximum possible accuracy when reporting consumer information. The reporting of late payments on a current account fails to meet this standard.

FCRA Section 611 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : I have the right to dispute any inaccurate information on my credit report and demand a thorough reinvestigation.

FCRA Section 611 ( a ) ( 5 ) : If the information can not be verified as accurate, it must be deleted promptly.

CFPB Standards : The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau mandates that credit bureaus and furnishers maintain fair and accurate reporting practices.

I have the right to make sure my private information isn't shared which is backed by 15 USC 6801 which states '' It is the policy of the Congress that each financial institution has an affirmative and continuing obligation to respect the privacy of its customers and to protect the security and confidentiality of those customers nonpublic personal information. '' ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) is a financial institution by definition under that title. 15 USC 1681 section 604 a section 2 states that " In general Subject to subsection ( c ), any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report under the following circumstances and no other : in accordance with the written instructions of the consumer to whom it relates. '' ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) the financial institution and the Consumer reporting agencies XXXX and Experian do not have my consent to furnish this information and they surely do not have my written consent. Any and all consent to XXXX, Experian, ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) whether it be verbal, non-verbal, written, implied or otherwise is revoked. 15 USC 6802 ( b ) ( c ) states that " A financial institution may not disclose nonpublic personal information to a nonaffiliated third party unless the consumer is given an explanation of how the consumer can exercise that nondisclosure option. '' ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) Never informed me of my right to exercise my nondisclosure option. Not only that 15 USC 1681C ( a ) ( 5 ) states '' Except as authorized under subsection ( b ), no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years. '' This account is an adverse item they are reporting again without my permission which is against the law. 15 U.S. Code 1681s2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A states " A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. 15 U.S. Code 1681e states '' Every consumer reporting agency shall maintain reasonable procedures designed to avoid violations of section 1681c of this title and to limit the furnishing of consumer reports to the purposes listed under section 1681b of this title. XXXX and Experian are not maintaining reasonable procedures. Also 12 CFR 1016.7 states that " A consumer may exercise the right to opt out at any time. '' I am opting out of your reporting services.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Formal Dispute for Aggravated Identity Theft - Request for Immediate Account Removal I am writing to dispute an account on my file that is the result of aggravated identity theft. The name and address associated with this account do not match the information on file with the credit bureaus or my personal records. I believe this account was fraudulently opened in my name by an unauthorized individual.

I have taken immediate steps to address this matter, including : Applicable Laws Supporting My Request for Account Removal Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), Section 605B ( 15 U.S.C. 1681c-2 ) : Under the FCRA, you are required to block fraudulent information resulting from identity theft from appearing on my credit file within four business days of receiving the following documentation : A copy of my identity theft report.

Proof of my identity. 
A written statement regarding the fraudulent account. 
Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act ( 18 U.S.C. 1028A ) : Aggravated identity theft is a federal crime, and the law requires that businesses take action to assist victims in clearing fraudulent accounts.

Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), Section 805 ( b ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1692c ( b ) ) : Debt collectors are prohibited from pursuing debts resulting from identity theft.

FACTA Identity Theft Red Flags Rule ( Fair and Accurate Credit Transactions Act ) : Financial institutions and creditors are required to take proactive measures when identity theft indicators, such as mismatched name and address information, are present. 

Requested Actions Immediately investigate and remove the fraudulent account from my records. 
Provide written confirmation of the removal and resolution within 30 days. 
Notify any third parties who were provided the fraudulent information to correct their records. 

Enclosures : Copy of my FTC Identity Theft Report.

Copy of the police report. 
Proof of my identity ( e.g., drivers license, utility bill, or Social Security card ). 
Additional supporting documents as required. 
This incident has caused undue stress and inconvenience. 

I have filed file a complaint with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and consider further legal action. 

Please contact me at if you require any further information.

My identity has been stolen you are hereby put on notice.

Aggravated Identity Theft pursuant to 18 U.S.C. 1028A.

( 1 ) In general.

Whoever, during and in relation to any felony violation enumerated in subsection ( c ), knowingly transfers, possesses, or uses, without lawful authority, a means of identification of another person shall, in addition to the punishment provided for such felony, be sentenced to a term of imprisonment of 2 years.

An identification of me has been used without my permission to open several accounts that have damaged my reputation and damaged my mode of living because you furnished a consumer report without my written permission as stated by Federal Law 15 USC 1681b Permissible purpose of consumer reports IN GENERAL Subject to subsection ( c ) any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report under the following circumstances and no other : ( 2 ) In accordance with the written instructions of the consumer to whom it relates. 


YOU XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX have aided this Fraud by reporting these accounts and are ACTIVELY PARTICIPATING IN AGGRAVATED IDENTITY THEFT. 


Congress states 15 USC 1681 Fair Credit Reporting Act ( a ) Accuracy and fairness of credit reports ( 4 ) There is a need to insure that consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and a respect for the consumers right to privacy. 


List of Accounts : Charge -Off : NAVY FEDERAL CR UNION {$21000.00} Date opened XX/XX/year> Charge Off - By Definition The IRS Clearly says a Cancelled debt or Charge off is Income. The reporting of this account as a debt is inaccurate. 
15 USC 1681 s-2 Says ( XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX ) is a furnisher of information to / and/ or a consumer reporting agency. 
You ARE PROHIBITED BY LAW to furnish and/or report inaccurate information. I demand you to Cease and Desist the reporting of incorrect/ inaccurate information immediately. 
15 USC 1681 s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate You are hereby put on NOTICE that you are furnishing incorrect inaccurate information and further/knowingly participating in Aggravated Identity Theft Pursuant 15 U.S. Code 1681c2 - Block of information resulting from identity theft. 
Except as otherwise provided in this section, a consumer reporting agency shall block the reporting of any information in the file of a consumer that the consumer identifies as information that resulted from an alleged identity theft, not later than 4 business days after the date of receipt by such agency of ( 1 ) appropriate proof of the identity of the consumer ; ( 2 ) a copy of an identity theft report ; ( 3 ) the identification of such information by the consumer; and ( 4 ) a statement by the consumer that the information is not information relating to any transaction by the consumer. 



I have attached all the relevant documents pursuant the above Section of the law.

I demand all the above Fraudulent accounts DELETED immediately.

I Demand an updated copy of my Consumer file reflecting these changes ( 15 USC 1681 c-1 2 Access to free reports ) ( 2 ) Access to free reports In any case in which a consumer reporting agency includes a fraud alert in the file of a consumer pursuant to this subsection, the consumer reporting agency shall ( A ) disclose to the consumer that the consumer may request a free copy of the file of the consumer pursuant to section 1681j ( d ) of this title ;

Consumer complaint narrative:
Three accounts were charged off but they still appear on my credit report in a negative status. The companies did not issue a 1099C although they have already charged off the amounts an of course take a loss on their financial statements for these items. I have requested removal of these negative information from my credit reports and/or the issuance of 1099C without success.

I have also refuted some of these balances as most times the original lender sold the account to a collection agency for pennies on the dollars. This then result in a collection agency hounding us like a bulldog to collect moneys that have already been written off. 

All these issues paint a negative picture on the credit reporting agencies which effectively effect creditability and affect my ability to get credit at a lower interest rate or no credit at all

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing in response to your request regarding my complaint against XXXX XXXX XXXX. Below is a summary of the actions I have taken and the ongoing issues with XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX handling of my personal information and credit reporting. 

Timeline of Events and Actions Taken : Debt Validation Letter ( XX/XX/XXXX ) : On XX/XX/XXXX, I sent XXXX XXXX XXXX a Debt Validation letter requesting validation of the alleged debt they are attempting to collect. This is my right under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ). The letter explicitly requested that XXXX XXXX XXXX provide verification of the debt, including the original creditor, the amount, and other relevant details. 
No response was received from XXXX XXXX XXXX within the required XXXX period. This lack of response is a violation of my rights under the FDCPA, which mandates that they must provide this validation before continuing any collection activities. 
Cease and Desist Letter ( XX/XX/XXXX ) : On XX/XX/XXXX, I sent a Cease and Desist letter to XXXX XXXX XXXX, demanding that they immediately stop accessing or reporting my personal information to credit bureaus without my consent. 
This letter also reiterated my rights under 15 U.S.C. 1681b ( Fair Credit Reporting Act ), which requires consumer consent before any third party can access or report my credit information. I have not given XXXX XXXX XXXX permission to obtain or report my personal or credit information. 
Despite this request, no response has been received from XXXX XXXX XXXX, and they continue to report inaccurate and unauthorized information on my credit report. 

Key Issues : Unauthorized Access and Reporting : XXXX XXXX XXXX has been reporting on my credit report without my consent. Under 15 U.S.C. 1681b, they are not permitted to obtain my personal information or report it to credit bureaus without my explicit permission. Their actions are not only a violation of my privacy rights but may also constitute identity theft. 
Failure to Respond : Both my Debt Validation letter and my Cease and Desist letter were sent in good faith, requesting that XXXX XXXX XXXX provide the necessary documentation and cease their unauthorized actions. However, as of today, they have failed to respond to either request, which further compounds the violation of my rights. 
Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your prompt resolution of this complaint and confirmation that XXXX XXXX XXXX is taking the appropriate corrective actions. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to address the ongoing inaccuracies on my credit report. Despite previous attempts to dispute the following items, they remain unresolved, significantly impacting my ability to obtain credit. I am entitled to monetary compensation under 15 U.S. Code 1681i ( 6 ), which requires consumer reporting agencies to notify consumers of the results of reinvestigations within five business days after completion. You failed to correct these errors indicates noncompliance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ).

Under the FCRA, if disputed items can not be verified, they must be removed from my report. As per 15 U.S. Code 1681n ( Civil Liability for Willful Noncompliance ) and 15 U.S. Code 1681o ( Civil Liability for Negligent Noncompliance ), your agency may be held liable for failing to comply with federal law. Additionally, 15 U.S. Code 1692k holds entities accountable for violations related to debt collection. Any continued failure to address these inaccuracies in a timely manner will result in further legal action.

Charge-Off Accounts listed below must be DELETED IMMEDIATELY! due to violations of FDCPA Section 807 ( False and Misleading Representations ) and These accounts are falsely reported as charge-offs.

Collection Accounts Collection accounts listed below is in violation of 15 U.S. Code 1681b ( Permissible Purposes of Consumer Reports ). These must be DELETED in my report immediately.

Unauthorized Inquiries listed below were made without my authorization, violating 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( 1 ) ( A ) ( B ) ( i ) ( 3 ). They must be deleted from my report.

DELETE THIS ACCOUNTS IN MY CREDIT REPORT IMMEDIATELY!

Consumer complaint narrative:
XX/XX/year> Subject : Formal Complaint Regarding Missing and Inaccurate Account Information Dear CFPB, I am filing a formal complaint against Experian for failing to provide complete and accurate information regarding my credit report for account XXXX. Despite multiple requests for correction ( letters dated XX/XX/year> and XX/XX/year> ), my requests have been ignored, violating both the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ). Since my last dispute, nothing has changed, and the inaccuracies persist.

FCRA Violations : According to 15 U.S. Code 1666b, creditors are required to send periodic statements at least 21 days before the payment due date. The absence of detailed reporting suggests a failure to comply with this requirement.

Additionally, 15 U.S. Code 1681i mandates that credit reporting agencies ensure the accuracy of information in consumer files, which has not been upheld in my case.

Reporting incomplete information violates 15 U.S. Code 1681s-2, which prohibits the omission of essential data regarding accounts.

Summary of Errors and Discrepancies : Missing account details such as balances, high credit limit, and payment history.

No reported late payments ; however, the omission of critical account information creates inconsistencies in my credit profile.

Impact on Creditworthiness : The lack of comprehensive and accurate information in my XXXX report has created discrepancies across credit bureaus, undermining my creditworthiness and leading to financial harm. 
Desired Resolution : Immediate inclusion of all relevant account details in my credit report.

Written confirmation of the updates.

Assurance that the reporting will be accurate and consistent moving forward.

If this issue is not resolved promptly, I will escalate my complaint further, including potential legal action and filing additional complaints with relevant agencies such as the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ). 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX
