Product: Student loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
I have been in school less than full time and was paying out of pocket for classes. At that time in my life, I could not enroll in full time due to life circumstances. Every time Sallie Mae offered me the lowest payment possible, I could not afford it so I did not agree to any payment plans. I was not able to make payments due to severe life changing events. I was told if I enrolled in school full time the loan would go into forbearance. I had my school send Sallie Mae my registration information. At that time, my school hours were less than full time. My plan was to take full time hours the next term which started in XXXX. I ended up agreeing to The Step Up Plan of {$140.00} in XX/XX/XXXX. A payment was made on XX/XX/XXXX for {$140.00} XX/XX/XXXX for {$140.00} A partial payment for XXXX was made on XX/XX/XXXX for {$10.00}. 
I called and canceled the payment for the month of XXXX due to having a major XXXX. Unfortunately I was unable to work for XXXX weeks. My plan was to resume payments if I did not enroll in classes full time. 
I received a call from Sallie Mae stating to call them by the end of that business day or my account would go into collections. That was very unprofessional and did not allow me time to respond. 
I enrolled in classes in XXXX full time. My account was sent to a collections agency in XXXX. Sallie Mae did not check Clearinghouse to see my enrollment status. I was sent into collections while enrolled fulltime. How could this happen? Sallie Mae would not speak to me once the account was charged off. This experience with Sallie Mae has been frustrating and I would not recommend them if this is their routine practice.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to dispute the presence of certain charge offs on my credit report. I believe that these closed account/charge offs have been reported in violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and the XXXX XXXX XXXX requirements. 

Specifically, I believe that the information reported by your agency regarding the closed account/charge off is inaccurate, incomplete, and misleading. As a result, my XXXX XXXX has been unfair impacted and I have suffered damages as a result. 

Under the FCRA, it is your responsibility to ensure that all information is reported to credit bureaus is accurate and up to date. Additionally, the XXXX XXXX compliance guidelines outline specific reporting requirements for charged off accounts, including the requirement to report the date of first delinquency and the date of charge off. 

Based on my own records, I believe that the information reported by your agency is incorrect and in violation of these guidelines. I have attached copies of my records to this letter for your review. I am requesting that you investigate this matter and correct any inaccurate or incomplete information in my credit report. 

Additionally, I am requesting that you provide me with a copy of the investigation results and any updates made to my credit report as a result of your investigation. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative: Reference Accounts : XXXX I am writing to formally dispute inaccurate information on my credit report, pursuant to Section 605B of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681c-2, and request the immediate removal of any fraudulent accounts associated with my name and personal information. In accordance with this law, I have provided the necessary FTC Identity Theft Report to support my claim of fraudulent activity and data breach. I recently discovered that my personal information was compromised as part of a data breach involving XXXX. As a direct result of this breach, I am now facing fraudulent collections accounts on my credit report. The unauthorized use of my personal information has led to these collections being wrongly attributed to me. Under the FCRA, specifically Section 605B, I am entitled to request the removal of these fraudulent accounts from my credit file, as they do not reflect any legitimate debt I owe. 2. Request for Immediate Removal of Fraudulent Information : Under Section 605B of the FCRA, I request that you immediately remove all accounts that were opened fraudulently or are associated with identity theft from my credit report. These accounts were not authorized by me and have been opened as a result of the data breach involving XXXX. I have included a copy of my FTC Identity Theft Report, which details the fraudulent activity and confirms the theft of my personal information. 3. Legal Timeframe for Removal : Under Section 605B of the FCRA, when a consumer submits a valid FTC Identity Theft Report, credit reporting agencies must take action to investigate and remove fraudulent accounts within 4 business days. Therefore, I request that you immediately remove these fraudulent accounts from my credit report and correct the inaccuracies. Failure to comply with this requirement will leave me no choice but to pursue further legal actions, including filing complaints with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ). 4. Failure to Verify Fraudulent Accounts : As per 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ), when a consumer disputes information on their credit report, the credit bureaus must conduct a reasonable investigation into the disputed items. However, I have reason to believe that the fraudulent accounts, stemming from the data breach, have not been properly investigated or removed. Despite my prior dispute, these accounts remain on my credit report, which is causing severe damage to my credit score. 5. Request for Removal Due to Inaccuracy or Fraud : As these accounts are the result of identity theft and a data breach, I am requesting that you immediately remove them from my credit file in accordance with the FCRA. Under 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ), if information can not be verified or is found to be inaccurate or incomplete, it must be deleted. This includes accounts opened fraudulently due to a data breach. 6. FTC Report Submission : Enclosed with this letter is a copy of my FTC Identity Theft Report, which I filed to support my claim. According to the FCRA and guidelines of the Federal Trade Commission, this report serves as evidence that I have been a victim of identity theft and data breach, and it should be sufficient for the removal of fraudulent accounts from my credit report. I kindly ask that you complete your investigation and remove the fraudulent accounts from my credit report within 4 business days, as required by law. If you do not comply with the FCRA, I will escalate the matter by filing a formal complaint with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and may consider pursuing further legal action. Please provide written confirmation that these fraudulent accounts have been removed and that my credit report has been updated to reflect the accurate information. Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I look forward to your timely response.

Please use this letter as an explanation of what Bank of America is reporting as a late payment flag on my Cash Rewards Visa Credit Card. 
On XX/XX/2024, I transferred my {$130.00} cash back rewards to my credit card to apply toward my XXXX bill. This transfer was categorized as Payments and Other Credits,. On XX/XX/2024, I made a payment of {$210.00}, which was a few days late ; my due date was XX/XX/XXXX. Bank of America has confirmed they do not impose penalties until a payment is 30 days late, a threshold I did not reach. 
After multiple conversations with Bank of America representatives via phone, it was confirmed that the late payment in XXXX should not have triggered a flag. However, I was informed that cash back rewards do not count as an official payment, despite the system allowing the transfer. I was advised that I could have moved the funds from my cash back rewards to my checking account and then made a payment to avoid the flag, which seems unnecessary given that I used the rewards directly. 
On XX/XX/2024 I visited the Bank of America branch on XXXX XXXX in XXXX XXXX XXXX and spoke with XXXX XXXX and her manager, who confirmed that cash back rewards can indeed be applied to credit card balances. They assured me that this is a common practice. We filed another complaint to resolve the issue, and a representative promised to fax a statement confirming the resolution. However, after two days and multiple calls, I have yet to receive that fax. 
On a subsequent visit to the XXXX XXXX branch on XX/XX/2024, I spoke with XXXX XXXX from the XXXX XXXX, who acknowledged the unfairness of the situation but indicated that they would not change their stance, even though they had received the full payment from me and I owe nothing to bank of America. 
I am happy to seek legal action and have already started the process. Looking forward to more conversations and this being resolved timely.

Product: Credit card
Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Issue: Problem with a purchase shown on your statement
Sub-issue: Card was charged for something you did not purchase with the card
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX I was a victim of fraud on my Bank of America credit card for four ( 4 ) purchase transactions made without my consent and neither was made by any of my authorized users at XXXX XXXX # XXXX for {$140.00}, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX for {$1.00}, XXXX XXXX XXXX for {$100.00} and XXXX # XXXX for {$150.00} for a total of {$410.00}. 

The first claim was automatically initiated by the bank after issuing a fraud alert. After several weeks, I received an alert in my online account that they had not approved the claim and since they did not give an explanation, I decided to call and they told me the reason why it was Denied is because the physical card with the chip was used and the receipt was signed. I requested that they send me that proof because neither I nor any of my authorized users made these purchases, but they denied my request. 

I decided to go to a physical office of the Bank of America and talk to a banker about the case, she told me that I had to send a form, and I explained that I never received anything, so she called, and the case was reopened. But I never received the form that was mentioned to me and again the case was not approved. So, I had to pay for those purchases although neither I nor my authorized users did, in order not to damage my credit history. 

After a few months trying to investigate what other options I had, since the bank never informed me what other steps I should or could take. I saw that I could file a police report, so I went and filed the report on XX/XX/XXXX and the case number is # XXXX. Reiterating that I did not make those purchases and none of my authorized users made those purchases. I also mentioned to the police that these unauthorized purchases happened after I used my physical card at the XXXX XXXX XXXX ( # XXXX ) on XX/XX/XXXX.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Consumer Financial Protection Bureau XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, DC XXXX Subject : Request for Review of Case Involving Capital One Quick Silver Credit Card Dear CFPB Team, I am writing to request that you review the case I previously filed regarding my Capital One Quick Silver Credit Card account. I recently spoke with a representative at the CFPB to clarify several issues with this account. These issues remain unresolved and have caused significant harm to my credit and financial stability. 

In XXXX, I paid {$320.00} on a {$300.00} balance for my credit card. Despite this payment, Capital One initially claimed there were returned transactions. However, after insisting they look deeper into the account, the company confirmed that the balance had been paid in full. 

After paying off the balance, I contacted Capital One to remind them that I am an XXXX XXXX XXXX. The company stated they would review my account to determine if I was entitled to any reimbursement for interest or late payment fees under the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ). Instead of resolving the matter fairly, I was charged {$7.00} in interest fees beginning in XXXX. These fees have since compounded, resulting in a current balance of {$68.00}. 

As of XX/XX/XXXX, Capital One is charging off the account. This situation reflects unfair credit reporting practices, especially toward an XXXX XXXX servicemember striving to maintain financial stability and build credit responsibly. 

I respectfully request the CFPB to intervene and thoroughly review this case to ensure Capital Ones practices are in compliance with applicable laws, including the XXXX. Additionally, I would appreciate guidance on resolving this matter fairly and preventing further harm to my credit report. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. Please feel free to contact me at [ your phone number ] or [ your email address ] if additional information or documentation is required. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

Dear CFPB, I am writing to formally file a complaint against XXXX XXXX regarding their continued inaccurate reporting of a debt on my Experian credit report. This reporting violates the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and has caused significant harm to my XXXX XXXX and financial reputation. 

Key Issues : Incorrect Reporting of Sold Debt : Capital XXXX is reporting a balance of {$470.00} on my Experian credit report, even though this debt was sold to XXXX XXXX XXXX. 
Under the FCRA, once an account is sold, the original creditor is required to update the balance to {$0.00} and note that the debt was transferred or sold. XXXX XXXX has failed to update this information properly. 
Impact on My Credit Report and Score : The continued reporting of this balance by Capital XXXX creates confusion and misrepresents my financial obligations, resulting in a negative impact on my XXXX XXXX. 
This inaccurate reporting has adversely affected my ability to secure financial opportunities. 
Failure to Address the Issue : Despite previous disputes and attempts to resolve this matter directly with XXXX XXXX, they have not corrected their reporting. 
XXXX Requested : I request the following actions : Immediate Update of the Account : XXXX XXXX must update the account on my Experian credit report to reflect a {$0.00} balance and clearly indicate that the debt was sold to XXXX XXXX XXXX. 
Removal of Inaccurate Reporting : If XXXX XXXX can not validate the current reporting, I request that the account be removed entirely from my Experian credit report. 
Compliance with the FCRA : XXXX XXXX must ensure their reporting practices comply with the FCRA to avoid future inaccuracies. 
Supporting Documents Enclosed : A copy of my Experian credit report showing the incorrect reporting by XXXX XXXX. 
Correspondence with XXXX XXXX regarding this dispute. 
Impact and Final Request : The continued inaccurate reporting by XXXX XXXX on my Experian credit report has caused significant financial harm and undue stress. I kindly request the CFPBs assistance in ensuring XXXX XXXX updates this account appropriately and in compliance with federal regulations. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

I made the payment of {$220.00} and the extension documents were completed showing I was now current and would not be reported 30 days delinquent on my credit report. XXXX sent me a copy of the extension documents signed on by both parties for approval. Document number XXXX. Days later I go back in to look at my account and no evidence of the Deferment and now Ive been reported 30 days late. I called XXXX today, XX/XX/XXXX and spoke with XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, a Customer relations associate. She tells me their department is the highest in the company and that my extension was reviewed again and denied due to my cars upcoming maturity date. I told her nothing was sent to me in writing stating this. She told me that they do not send the denial out in writing. I requested the denial in writing. She told me she was not going to send it to me. I told her then I can not believe it was actually denied. I have a signed document of approval and without a denial in writing, they could be telling me anything. I want my credit reporting corrected for this month as its unfair I was approved and under the impression I would not be reported as delinquent. I want my deferment shown as up to date and my credit reporting corrected and fixed. Also spoke to XXXX, ID number XXXX, XXXX XXXX  XXXX, also denied me the right to have the denial in writing. She stated thats not the companys practice. It sounds to me that they are refusing to honor the approval and back peddling because of their oversight.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute inaccurate late payment entries on my credit report regarding my account with XXXX XXXX ( Account # XXXX ). These late payments appear to be reported in error, as the account is marked as Current across all bureaus and there is no valid evidence to support these entries. This is a violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and my rights as a consumer. 
Details of Dispute : Account Name : XXXX XXXX Account Number : XXXX Disputed Late Payment Entries : XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX With discrepancies XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX With discrepancies XXXX  Experian : XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX With Discrepancies Additional Inaccuracies and Issues XXXX. Future Reporting Dates : XXXX XXXXXXXX and Experian : Last Reported is XXXX 
XXXX XXXXXXXX : Last Reported is XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX Reporting dates in the future violates the FCRA 's accuracy and timeliness requirements. 
XXXX. Payment History Discrepancies : XXXX XXXXXXXX and XXXX : Show several months with " 30/60/90-day late payments ''.

XXXX Experian : Shows no similar late payment entries. 
o If the account is listed as " Current, '' there should be no late payments reported. 

XXXX. Comments Conflicts : XXXX XXXXXXXX and Experian : State " Consumer Statement Item in Dispute by Consumer. '' XXXX XXXX : States " Consumer disputes - reinvestigation in progress. '' o These conflicting comments indicate unresolved or inconsistent handling of disputes. 
XXXX. Number of Months ( Terms ) Inconsistency : XXXX XXXXXXXX and Experian : Show 564 months. 
XXXX XXXXXXXX : Shows 0 months, which is inaccurate or incomplete. 
XXXX. High Credit vs. Balance : XXXX  Balance : {$480000.00}. 
XXXX  High Credit : {$500000.00}. 
XXXX  The balance does not exceed the high credit, but it requires proper documentation to ensure accuracy. 
XXXX. Date Discrepancies : o Date Last Active : XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
Experian : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : Missing. 
o Date of Last Payment : XXXX and XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
Experian : Missing.

Violation of Consumer Protection Laws : Violations of 15 U.S.C. 1681 ( FCRA ) : 1. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies are required to ensure maximum possible accuracy of consumer information. Reporting late payments on a current account violates this standard.

2. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : I have the right to dispute any inaccurate information on my credit report. The bureau must conduct a reasonable reinvestigation to verify its accuracy.

3. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) : If the disputed information can not be verified as accurate, it must be promptly deleted or corrected.

4. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : Information furnishers, such as creditors, are prohibited from knowingly reporting inaccurate information.

5. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( b ) : Upon receiving notice of a dispute, the furnisher must investigate, review relevant information, and report its findings to the credit bureaus.

FCRA Section 607 ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies are required to ensure maximum possible accuracy when reporting consumer information. The reporting of late payments on a current account fails to meet this standard.

FCRA Section 611 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : I have the right to dispute any inaccurate information on my credit report and demand a thorough reinvestigation.

FCRA Section 611 ( a ) ( 5 ) : If the information can not be verified as accurate, it must be deleted promptly.

CFPB Standards : The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau mandates that credit bureaus and furnishers maintain fair and accurate reporting practices.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX This letter is in response to all letters, emails, phone calls, or any other mediums of communication where I've received notices from your organization. By the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act, specifically 15 U.S. Code 1692c, this is my formal declaration to terminate and cease all communication from your organization regarding the debt you are attempting to collect. In response to this " Cease Communication '' letter, and by the Federal Fair Debt Collections Act, you may only contact me to inform me that there will be no further collection efforts or to notify me that a specific action will take place. If this alleged debt belongs to me, then please provide the Validation of Debt agreement that speaks on my behalf. By 15 U.S. Code 1692g, please send me a detailed list of the history of payments I've made on this account. I also want to witness the signature that I've signed on official contract documents guaranteeing that I would pay this creditor or your agency. I am also requesting proof that there have been any insurance claims found on this debt. And lastly, I will request proof that you have the chain of title to collect on this debt. 
Please be advised that I am well aware of my rights and know that any further contact by you or your company, except a communication confirming your acknowledgment of this letter, violates the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act. In addition, any third ( 3rd ) party that you use to coerce the collection of this debt shall also violate federal law.

If you do not cease communication, a lawsuit will be filed against you. 
This letter has been sent by certified mail with a return receipt and shall be presented to any court of proper jurisdiction if communication continues. 
Sincere, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am compelled to highlight the violation of my consumer rights caused by the dissemination of inaccurate information. Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to dispute the accuracy and validity of a charge-off account that has been reported on my consumer report. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681 et seq., I have the right to accurate and complete information in my credit reports. I believe the information regarding this charge-off account is inaccurate and/or incomplete, and I request an immediate investigation into this matter. 

XXXX  XXXX XXXX Inaccuracies and Issues 1. Account Type and Description Discrepancy : o XXXX : " Business Credit Card. '' o Experian : " Charge Account. '' o This inconsistency in account type descriptions raises concerns about data accuracy. 
2. High Credit and Credit Limit Discrepancies : o High Credit : {$3200.00} ( consistent across reports ). 
o Credit Limit : {$3000.00} ( XXXX and XXXX ). 
o Past Due Balance : {$3600.00}. 
o The past due balance exceeds the high credit and credit limit, which is an anomaly requiring verification. 
3. Comments Conflict : o XXXX : " Charged off as bad debt. Dispute resolved ; reported by grantor. '' o Experian : " Unpaid balance reported as a loss by the credit grantor. '' o XXXX : " CONSUMER STATEMENT ITEM IN DISPUTE BY CONSUMER. '' o These comments reflect inconsistent handling of disputes and charge-offs. 

4. Date Discrepancies : o Date Last Active : XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
Experian : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Date of Last Payment : XXXX and XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o These inconsistencies should be clarified and corrected. 
5. Payment History Errors : o The Two-Year Payment History shows " CO '' ( Charge Off ) consistently across all bureaus. If this account was disputed or resolved, these entries should reflect the resolution accurately. 


XXXX  XXXX XXXX Inaccuracies and Issues 1. Balance vs. Credit Limit Conflict : o Balance : {$4100.00} ( XXXX and XXXX ). 
o Credit Limit : {$3700.00} ( all bureaus ). 
o The balance exceeds the credit limit, which is an anomaly that needs verification. 
2. Comments Discrepancies : o XXXX : " Charged off as bad debt. Dispute resolved : reported by grantor. '' o Experian : " Account was in dispute, now resolved - reported by subscriber. '' o XXXX : " CONSUMER STATEMENT ITEM IN DISPUTE BY CONSUMER. '' o Comments lack consistency regarding the resolution status and how the dispute was handled. 
3. Date Discrepancies : o Date Last Active : XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
Experian : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Date of Last Payment : XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
Experian : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o There is a slight discrepancy in the " Date Last Active '' between XXXX and Experian. 
4. Future Reporting Dates : o Last Reported : XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
Experian : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Reporting future dates violates the FCRA 's accuracy and timeliness requirements.

5. Payment History Inconsistencies : o The Two-Year Payment History shows continuous " CO '' ( Charge Off ) statuses. If the account dispute was resolved, these entries should reflect the resolution XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Key Inaccuracies and Issues : 1. Balance Exceeding Credit Limit : o Balance : {$7800.00}. 
o Credit Limit : {$7100.00}. 
o The balance exceeds the credit limit, which is inconsistent with standard account reporting practices and needs verification. 
2. Comments Discrepancies : o XXXX : " Charged off as bad debt. Account information disputed by consumer, meets FCRA requirements. '' o Experian : " Customer disputed account - reported by subscriber. Unpaid balance reported as a loss by the credit grantor. '' o XXXX : " CONSUMER STATEMENT ITEM IN DISPUTE BY CONSUMER. '' o These comments vary significantly and do not provide a clear resolution status. 
3. Future Reporting Dates : o Last Reported : XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
Experian : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Reporting future dates violates the FCRA 's accuracy requirements.

4. Date Discrepancies : o Date Last Active : XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
Experian : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Date of Last Payment : All bureaus : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Discrepancies in the " Date Last Active '' should be clarified. 
5. Payment History Errors : o The Two-Year Payment History shows " CO '' ( Charge Off ) consistently for all months. If the account was disputed or resolved, the history should reflect this. 


1. Verification Requirement ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ) : - The FCRA mandates that all disputed information be verified within 30 days of a consumers dispute. If the information can not be verified, it must be corrected or deleted.

2. Obligation of Accuracy ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ) : - Consumer reporting agencies must ensure maximum possible accuracy of the information in consumer reports. The inaccurate or unverifiable information regarding the charge-off account violates this requirement.

3. Re-Aging of Debt ( 15 U.S.C. 1681c ) : - The FCRA prohibits re-aging of old debt. If the date of first delinquency is inaccurately reported, the charge-off may appear on my credit report longer than the allowed 7 years.

4. Validation of Debt ( Fair Debt Collection Practices Act, 15 U.S.C. 1692g ) : - Under the FDCPA, if the debt is being collected by a third party, I have the right to request validation of the debt, including proof of ownership and the amount owed. If the creditor or collection agency can not validate the debt, it must be removed.

XX/XX/XXXX Subject : Formal Complaint Regarding Inaccurate Late Payments on XXXX XXXXXXXX Account Dear CFPB, I am writing to dispute inaccurate late payments reported on my XXXX XXXX account ( Account Number : XXXX ). Specifically, the account reflects a 30-day late payment for XX/XX/XXXX and a 60-day late payment for XX/XX/XXXX, which are erroneous and negatively impact my creditworthiness. 
Nature of the Complaint : Inaccurate Reporting : These late payments are false, as I have maintained a consistent on-time payment history through autopay. 
Violation of FCRA ( 15 USC 1681i and 1681s-2 ) : The failure to correct these inaccuracies breaches the Fair Credit Reporting Act, which mandates accuracy in consumer credit reports.

Violation of FDCPA ( 15 USC 1692e ) : Reporting incorrect payment information could qualify as a misleading or deceptive act.

Violation of TILA ( 15 USC 1601 ) : The Truth in Lending Act requires that all payment and account information be accurate.

Civil Liability Under FCRA ( 15 USC 1681n and 1681o ) : Noncompliance with these requirements exposes the responsible parties to legal penalties. 
Summary of Discrepancies Experian : Reported 30-day late payment for XX/XX/XXXX and 60-day late payment for XX/XX/XXXX. 
These late payments are inaccurate, as payments were made on time. 
Requested Resolution : I request the following actions : Investigate the inaccuracies and remove the erroneous late payment entries. 
Update my credit file to accurately reflect my history of on-time payments. 
Provide written confirmation of the corrections within 30 days, as mandated by the FCRA. 
Enclosed, you will find copies of supporting documentation to substantiate my claims. Please address this issue promptly to prevent further actions. 
Thank you for your attention to this matter. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute inaccurate late payment entries on my credit report regarding my account with XXXX XXXX  ( Account # XXXX ). These late payments appear to be reported in error, as the account is marked as Current across all bureaus and there is no valid evidence to support these entries. This is a violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and my rights as a consumer. 
Details : 1. Account Information : o Account Type : Revolving ( XXXX XXXX Credit Card ). 
o High Credit : XXXX and Experian : {$13000.00}. 
XXXX : {$0.00} ( inaccurate or incomplete ). 
o Credit Limit : {$12000.00} across all bureaus. 
o Balance : {$0.00} across all bureaus. 
XXXX. Payment Status : o Listed as Current across all three credit bureaus. 
XXXX. Late Payments Reported : o XXXX : Reports " 60 days late '' ( XX/XX/XXXX ) and " 30 days late '' ( XX/XX/XXXX ). 
o Experian : Reports " 60 days late '' ( XX/XX/XXXX ) and " 30 days late '' ( XX/XX/XXXX ). 
o XXXX : Reports " 60 days late '' ( XX/XX/XXXX ) and " 30 days late '' ( XX/XX/XXXX ). 
XXXX. Comments and Anomalies : o XXXX and Experian comments are missing critical context. 
o XXXX mentions, " Amount in H/C column is credit limit, '' which doesn't clarify the reason for the reported late payments. 
XXXX. Activity Dates : o Date Last Active : XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. Experian : XX/XX/XXXX. XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Date of Last Payment : XXXX and Experian : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX Discrepancies and Issues : XXXX. Late Payment Reporting Conflict : o The account is marked as Current across all bureaus, yet late payments for XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX are reported. 
o If the account was " Current, '' these late payments are invalid and must be removed. 
XXXX. Inconsistent High Credit : o XXXX reports a High Credit of {$0.00}, which contradicts the reported high credit of {$13000.00} on XXXX and Experian. 
XXXX. Future Reporting Dates : o XXXX and Experian report " Last Reported '' as XX/XX/XXXX, while XXXX lists XX/XX/XXXX. Reporting dates in the future violate the FCRA 's accuracy requirements. 
XXXX. Date Discrepancies : o Date Last Active and Date of Last Payment vary across bureaus, suggesting potential inaccuracies in reporting. 
XXXX. Payment Status Mismatch : o The account status being " Current '' conflicts with the late payments reported for XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX. 
Violation of Consumer Protection Laws : Violations of 15 U.S.C. 1681 ( FCRA ) : 1. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies are required to ensure maximum possible accuracy of consumer information. Reporting late payments on a current account violates this standard. 
2. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : I have the right to dispute any inaccurate information on my credit report. The bureau must conduct a reasonable reinvestigation to verify its accuracy.

3. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) : If the disputed information can not be verified as accurate, it must be promptly deleted or corrected.

4. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : Information furnishers, such as creditors, are prohibited from knowingly reporting inaccurate information.

5. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( b ) : Upon receiving notice of a dispute, the furnisher must investigate, review relevant information, and report its findings to the credit bureaus.

FCRA Section 607 ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies are required to ensure maximum possible accuracy when reporting consumer information. The reporting of late payments on a current account fails to meet this standard.

FCRA Section 611 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : I have the right to dispute any inaccurate information on my credit report and demand a thorough reinvestigation.

FCRA Section 611 ( a ) ( 5 ) : If the information can not be verified as accurate, it must be deleted promptly.

CFPB Standards : The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau mandates that credit bureaus and furnishers maintain fair and accurate reporting practices.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute certain items on my credit report that I believe are inaccurate and should be removed. Specifically, I have identified several collection accounts listed that fail to provide adequate information regarding the original creditor, which I believe constitutes erroneous reporting. 

Upon reviewing my credit report, I found that these collection accounts lack sufficient details regarding the original creditor, including the name and contact information of the creditor, the date the debt was incurred, and other necessary data that would support the validity of these collections. Without this critical information, I am unable to verify the legitimacy of the debts, and they should not remain on my credit report. 

As required by the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I am requesting that these collection accounts be removed from my credit file. I ask that you conduct a thorough investigation into these items, and if the information can not be substantiated by the original creditor, that these entries be promptly deleted from my report.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute unauthorized inquiries that have been reported on my credit file by your company, 700 CreditXXXX XXXX XXXX The inquiries in question were made on XX/XX/scrub>XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXX/XX/year>. These inquiries were conducted without my consent and therefore violate the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically regarding permissible purpose. 
Under the FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681b ), a company must have a permissible purpose to access a consumers credit report. Since I did not authorize or initiate any business dealings that would grant your company such access, these inquiries are unauthorized.

I request that you immediately : 1.Remove the unauthorized inquiries from all of my credit reports ( XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 
2.Provide compensation of {$1000.00} as stipulated under the FCRA for each violation.

If you are willing to resolve this matter amicably, I am prepared to sign an agreement that includes the removal of these inquiries and the payment of the compensation without requiring your client to admit any wrongdoing. This would be a mutually beneficial resolution and would save both parties the time and expense of further action. 

Please be advised that if I am forced to litigate, I will seek actual damages as allowed under the FCRA, including but not limited to costs incurred as a result of these unauthorized inquiries. Product: Debt collection
Consumer complaint narrative:
To Whom It May Concern, I am writing regarding a debt you claim I owe, which you referenced in your recent communication dated [ XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ]. I am formally requesting validation of this debt under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), 15 U.S.C. 1692g. I also request a copy of the original assignment contract to verify your legal right to collect this debt. 

Please provide the following information : Validation of the Debt : The amount of the debt, including a breakdown of principal, interest, fees, and other charges. 
The original creditor 's name, address, and account number associated with this debt. 
A copy of the original contract or agreement that establishes my obligation to pay. 

Proof of Assignment : A copy of the contract of assignment or other legal documentation proving that you have the authority to collect this debt on behalf of the original creditor or any subsequent assignees. 

Account History : An itemized statement of all charges and payments related to this debt from its inception. 

Confirmation of Your Authority : Your debt collector license number and the state ( s ) where you are licensed to operate. 

Please consider this letter a formal dispute of the alleged debt until you provide sufficient evidence that validates your claim. I also request that you cease all collection efforts, including phone calls and written communications, until the requested documentation has been provided. 

If you can not validate this debt, I request that you notify me in writing and remove any negative information related to this account from my credit reports, as required by law. 

Under the FDCPA, you are required to provide this information within 30 days. If you fail to comply, I reserve the right to pursue all legal remedies available to me under federal and state law. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. Please direct all future correspondence regarding this debt to me in writing at the address provided above. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, TN XXXX XXXX Republic Finance Dispute of Inaccurate Credit Reporting Dockett Number : XXXX Attention Republic Finance, I am writing to formally dispute the inaccurate information you are reporting on my credit file concerning an account. This account was sold and subsequently dropped in court, yet Republic Finance continues to report this information, for months I have been told that you verified this erroneous information. Your actions are causing harm to my life, especially as the company to which you sold this account pursued legal action against me continually missing work to go to court for months, in which you did not report being in disputed status nor did you report that this has been sold to another company. XXXX and XXXX stated that you verified the information you are reporting to them. Enclosed as XXXX XXXX  and XXXX XXXX 
By continuing to report false and misleading information, you are in violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). Additionally the actions of Republic Finance violate the Tennessee Consumer Protection Act ( TCPA ), Tenn. Code Ann . 47-18-104, which prohibits unfair and deceptive practices, including but not limited to : Misrepresentation of the information reported to credit bureaus. 
Failure to provide accurate information on my credit file. 
15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Your obligation to ensure maximum accuracy of the information reported. 
I'm sending this demand letter so that you immediately delete this inaccurate and harmful information from my credit file. Under the FCRA, I may have the right to pursue statutory damages ( up to {$1000.00} per violation ), as well as actual damages and punitive damages if it is determined that there was willful and negligent noncompliance. 
I will take appropriate action under both the FCRA and TCPA, including filing complaints with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), the Tennessee Attorney General 's Office, and pursuing legal action if necessary. 
Investigate this matter and provide me with written confirmation once the inaccurate information has been removed.

Product: Money transfer, virtual currency, or money service
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX, I discovered XXXX cash transfers from my CapitalOne checking account. Each transaction was {$250.00} and were wired to a person named XXXX XXXX. I contacted CapitalOne immediately and reported the fraudulent transactions. They responded by closing my account, offering to open a new account and open an investigation on the fraud. 

CapitalOne responded by advising me they were not at fault and that the funds transfer was done through XXXX and would not replace the funds as they were initiated by a " trusted computer. '' They further advised that the transfer was initiated in XXXX, XXXX XXXX  from a trusted computer. I had spent 2 months working in XXXX, XXXX  during the summer of XXXX and had left in XXXX of the year. They advised me to contact the local police in my community which at the time was XXXX XXXX, XXXX A report was begun but a day later I was contacted by XXXX XXXX Police telling me I had to file a complaint in XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 

I contacted the Police in XXXX, XXXX  and was told there was not too much they could do but would investigate even though they were dramatically short staffed and it was the start of XXXX. The XXXX police did nothing and refused to return my calls. I could not travel to XXXX as XXXX restrictions had begun and I could not leave Connecticut. 

I made XXXX additional attempts through CapitalOne to reverse the transactions and they kept stating that since the transfers were done from a trusted computer there was nothing they would do. I asked for the location of the computer and it turned out to be located at the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX at XXXX XXXX  XXXX, XXXX from the General Managers Computer in the back office. CapitalOne stated that I had accessed my accounts from that computer in XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX and they were correct. They further told me I had to notify them that the particular computer should be listed as no longer a trusted computer and that I needed to enter that in their website. I told them there was no such place to do that on their site. Additionally, in the Terms of Service with CapitalOne, there was nothing mentioned that I had to call or contact the bank to untrust the computer. 

I was unsure who it was that initiated the transfers so I contacted the CEO of the Management Company, Prestige Hospitality. It turned out to be the Night Auditor of the hotel. They pleaded with me not to have the man arrested at work, but again, the XXXX Police refused to do anything and my local police could not do anything claiming it was out of their jurisdiction. 

The battle went on for months with CapitalOne and they refused to reverse the transactions XXXX separate times. I immediately withdrew all but {$1.00} from the account to keep it open for my records. 

CapitalOne played loose and easy with the rules and now I understand why, they are XXXX of the owners of XXXX XXXX. I do not use XXXX XXXX, I do not have an account with them and to my knowledge have never received any transfers from anyone that uses XXXX. The funds were never returned and to my knowledge the employee is no longer employed by that company. 

I have a copy of the bank statement that shows the unauthorized transactions and I still would like these funds returned. Due to CapitalOne not advising anyone that a computer must be declared untrusted, and there being no way to do so at that time, CapitalOne was complicit in the fraud that took place and understood there was nothing someone like me could do to rectify the matter.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing a complaint against Experian for failing to correct inaccurate information regarding late payment reported on my credit report for account XXXX. 
Despite several requests for correction ( letters dated XX/XX/year>, XX/XX/year> ) and ( XX/XX/year> ), my requests have been ignored, violating both the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ). 
1. FCRA Violations : According to 15 U.S. Code 1666b, creditors are required to send periodic statements at least 21 days before the payment due date. The inaccurate late payment reporting on my account suggests a failure to comply with this requirement. Additionally, 15 U.S. Code 1681i mandates that credit reporting agencies ensure the accuracy of information in consumer files, which has not been upheld in my case. 

2. TILA Violations : The Truth in Lending Act emphasizes the necessity for accurate and timely disclosures to consumers. The inaccurate reporting of late payments has caused undue harm to my creditworthiness. 

3. Protection Against Non-Payment of Obligations Act ( PAANL ) : This act reinforces the responsibility of creditors to provide timely statements, preventing unfair penalties to consumers. 
I am formally requesting that the inaccurate late payment notation be removed from my credit report immediately. 
If this issue is not resolved promptly, I will escalate my complaint further, including potential legal action and filing additional complaints with relevant agencies.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Details : XXXX. Account Information : o Account Type : Revolving ( Flexible Spending Credit Card ). 
o XXXX XXXX : TransUnion and XXXX : {$13000.00}. 
XXXX : {$0.00} ( inaccurate or incomplete ). 
o XXXX XXXX : {$12000.00} across all bureaus. 
o XXXX : {$0.00} across all bureaus. 
XXXX. Payment Status : o Listed as XXXX across all three credit bureaus. 
XXXX. Late Payments Reported : o TransUnion : Reports " 60 days late '' ( XX/XX/XXXX ) and " 30 days late '' ( XX/XX/XXXX ). 
o XXXX : Reports " 60 days late '' ( XX/XX/XXXX ) and " 30 days late '' ( XX/XX/XXXX ). 
o XXXX : Reports " 60 days late '' ( XX/XX/XXXX ) and " 30 days late '' ( XX/XX/XXXX ). 
XXXX. Comments and Anomalies : o TransUnion and XXXX comments are missing critical context. 
o XXXX mentions, " Amount in H/C column is credit limit, '' which doesn't clarify the reason for the reported late payments. 
XXXX. Activity Dates : o Date Last Active : TransUnion : XX/XX/XXXX. XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Date of Last Payment : TransUnion and XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX Discrepancies and Issues : XXXX. Late Payment Reporting Conflict : o The account is marked as Current across all bureaus, yet late payments for XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX are reported. 
o If the account was " Current, '' these late payments are invalid and must be removed. 
XXXX. Inconsistent High Credit : o XXXX reports a High Credit of {$0.00}, which contradicts the reported high credit of {$13000.00} on TransUnion and XXXX. 
XXXX. Future Reporting Dates : o TransUnion and XXXX report " Last Reported '' as XX/XX/XXXX, while XXXX lists XX/XX/XXXX. Reporting dates in the future violate the FCRA 's accuracy requirements. 
XXXX. Date Discrepancies : o Date Last Active and Date of Last Payment vary across bureaus, suggesting potential inaccuracies in reporting. 
XXXX. Payment Status Mismatch : o The account status being " Current '' conflicts with the late payments reported for XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX. 
Violation of Consumer Protection Laws : Violations of 15 U.S.C. 1681 ( FCRA ) : 1. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies are required to ensure maximum possible accuracy of consumer information. Reporting late payments on a current account violates this standard.

2. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : I have the right to dispute any inaccurate information on my credit report. The bureau must conduct a reasonable reinvestigation to verify its accuracy.

3. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) : If the disputed information can not be verified as accurate, it must be promptly deleted or corrected.

4. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : Information furnishers, such as creditors, are prohibited from knowingly reporting inaccurate information.

5. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( b ) : Upon receiving notice of a dispute, the furnisher must investigate, review relevant information, and report its findings to the credit bureaus.

FCRA Section 607 ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies are required to ensure maximum possible accuracy when reporting consumer information. The reporting of late payments on a current account fails to meet this standard.

FCRA Section 611 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : I have the right to dispute any inaccurate information on my credit report and demand a thorough reinvestigation.

FCRA Section 611 ( a ) ( 5 ) : If the information can not be verified as accurate, it must be deleted promptly. 
CFPB Standards : The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau mandates that credit bureaus and furnishers maintain fair and accurate reporting practices.

Product: Student loan
Sub-issue: Can't get other flexible options for repaying your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
I was under the impression that I had set up a repayment plan with Sallie Mae, since I had last spoke with them in XX/XX/XXXX. On XX/XX/XXXX, I received a letter referring to Notice of Right to Cure Loan Delinquency. On XX/XX/XXXX, I called them on my lunch break ( around XXXX XXXX ), which is within their open hours, and it stated to call back during the hours they are available. I called them again that evening ( XX/XX/XXXX ), and when I was able to speak with someone, the resolution team was unavailable. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, I called back and spoke with them. They asked for my information like income and expenses and was told I had to get in touch with my cosigner for them to ask the same questions. When we tried calling him, he did not answer. During that time, I requested an income based repayment plan. They told me that they don't have income based payment plans. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, I attempted to call my cosigner to go through the same process. He did not answer ; I tried calling several times. I then reached out to Sallie Mae to request a repayment plan without speaking with the cosigner. The representative asked me the same questions as before. He asked how I was paying my bills with the income that I have, and I stated that I wasn't able to keep up with everything. He even stated that he saw 2 payments of the amount that is due on a monthly basis, and implied that I was lying to him about my expenses. I asked about options like an income based repayment plan, and he then again repeated that they would have to consider the information from my cosigner before making any decisions. 

It took about a year of searching to get the job I am in after graduating from college. I have a family, and I have been attempting to right-size payments in order to stay on top of my debt without having to put the entire financial burden of the family on my partner. When I try to resolve this with them, they defer and make broad statements about repayment calculations, but do not explain what they are looking for or offer any assistance on how we can resolve this.

Despite my best efforts to obtain a refund from XXXX XXXX, my numerous inquiries have gone unanswered. I submitted all relevant communications and evidence to Bank of America ; however, my dispute was closed in favor of XXXX XXXX  without any thorough investigation or consideration of the materials I provided. 

I am deeply troubled by Bank of Americas handling of my claim, which seems both unprofessional and negligent. The closure of my dispute without a comprehensive review of the evidence is concerning and has left me without the funds that are rightfully owed to me. 

I am now seeking legal advice and assistance from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau in addressing this situation. I believe it is imperative for financial institutions to uphold their obligations to their customers and ensure fair dispute resolution processes.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear CFPB, I am writing to formally file a complaint against Capital One regarding their continued inaccurate reporting of a debt on my XXXX credit report. This reporting violates the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and has caused significant harm to my credit score and financial reputation.

Key Issues : Incorrect Reporting of Sold Debt : Capital One is reporting a balance of {$470.00} on my XXXX credit report, even though this debt was sold to XXXX XXXX XXXX. 
Under the FCRA, once an account is sold, the original creditor is required to update the balance to {$0.00} and note that the debt was transferred or sold. Capital One has failed to update this information properly. 
Impact on My Credit Report and Score : The continued reporting of this balance by Capital One creates confusion and misrepresents my financial obligations, resulting in a negative impact on my credit score.

This inaccurate reporting has adversely affected my ability to secure financial opportunities.

Failure to Address the Issue : Despite previous disputes and attempts to resolve this matter directly with Capital One, they have not corrected their reporting.

Resolution Requested : I request the following actions : Immediate Update of the Account : Capital One must update the account on my XXXX credit report to reflect a {$0.00} balance and clearly indicate that the debt was sold to XXXX XXXX XXXX. 
Removal of Inaccurate Reporting : If Capital One can not validate the current reporting, I request that the account be removed entirely from my XXXX credit report. 
Compliance with the FCRA : Capital One must ensure their reporting practices comply with the FCRA to avoid future inaccuracies. 
Supporting Documents Enclosed : A copy of my XXXX credit report showing the incorrect reporting by Capital One. 
Correspondence with Capital One regarding this dispute. 
Impact and Final Request : The continued inaccurate reporting by Capital One on my XXXX credit report has caused significant financial harm and undue stress. I kindly request the CFPBs assistance in ensuring Capital One updates this account appropriately and in compliance with federal regulations. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, FL XXXX Phone : ( XXXX ) XXXX Email : XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX TransUnion XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Subject : Arbitration Notice and Formal Dispute of Inaccurate Charge-Off Accounts on My Credit Report** Dear TransUnion, This letter serves as a formal dispute and notice of intent to arbitrate regarding the inaccurate reporting of charge-off accounts on my credit file, which is severely damaging my credit reputation, emotional well-being, and ability to secure housing, transportation, and other essentials. Pursuant to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I demand a thorough investigation and resolution of the inaccuracies detailed below. 

Accounts in Question Creditor Name XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Discrepancies and Grounds for Dispute Charge-Off Reporting : IRS Publication 525 stipulates that canceled or charged-off debts are taxable income only if the creditor issues a 1099-C form. Please verify whether the creditor filed this form and whether the debt is legally collectible.

Account Accuracy : Confirm with the creditor the payment history, account balances, and charge-off validity for all listed accounts.

Verification Documentation : Under 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ), I have the right to request documentation verifying the legitimacy of these accounts. Without proper evidence, these entries must be removed from my credit file.

Tax Implications : If a 1099-C was issued, the debt is considered forgiven and may not remain valid for collection or reporting as a charge-off.

Legal Violations Under the FCRA, the following violations are applicable : 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Failure to maintain reasonable procedures to assure maximum accuracy.

15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) : Failure to investigate and correct disputed information.

15 U.S.C. 1681n and 1681o : Willful and negligent noncompliance with the FCRA.

Additionally, CFR Title 16 660.4 requires furnishers to promptly investigate disputes and update inaccurate information. Your failure to comply with these requirements constitutes actionable harm.

Harms Experienced Reputational Damage : Tarnished creditworthiness due to inaccurate reporting. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  and undue hardship caused by your reporting negligence. 
Financial Harm : Inability to secure credit cards, finance vehicles, or obtain loans at reasonable terms. 
Resolution Sought Immediately remove all inaccurate and unverifiable information regarding the accounts listed above.

Provide written verification and supporting documentation from creditors confirming the accuracy of each disputed entry within 15 days.

Issue compensation for damages caused by inaccurate reporting, including but not limited to statutory damages of {$1000.00} per violation per month as allowed under 15 U.S.C. 1681n and 1681o, backdated to the first instance of incorrect reporting.

Intent to Arbitrate and Legal Action If the inaccuracies and damages outlined are not resolved within 30 days, I will initiate arbitration or legal proceedings for violations of the FCRA and other applicable laws. This includes seeking punitive damages for emotional distress, financial losses, and statutory penalties for each unresolved month the errors remained uncorrected. 

Supporting Documentation I have enclosed copies of my credit report highlighting the inaccuracies in the accounts listed. 

Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter. I expect a written response and resolution within 30 days, as required by law. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX This letter is in response to all letters, emails, phone calls, or any other mediums of communication where I've received notices from your organization. By the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act, specifically 15 U.S. Code 1692c, this is my formal declaration to terminate and cease all communication from your organization regarding the debt you are attempting to collect. In response to this " Cease Communication '' letter, and by the Federal Fair Debt Collections Act, you may only contact me to inform me that there will be no further collection efforts or to notify me that a specific action will take place. If this alleged debt belongs to me, then please provide the Validation of Debt agreement that speaks on my behalf. By 15 U.S. Code 1692g, please send me a detailed list of the history of payments I've made on this account. I also want to witness the signature that I've signed on official contract documents guaranteeing that I would pay this creditor or your agency. I am also requesting proof that there have been any insurance claims found on this debt. And lastly, I will request proof that you have the chain of title to collect on this debt.

Please be advised that I am well aware of my rights and know that any further contact by you or your company, except a communication confirming your acknowledgment of this letter, violates the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act. In addition, any third ( 3rd ) party that you use to coerce the collection of this debt shall also violate federal law.

If you do not cease communication, a lawsuit will be filed against you. 
This letter has been sent by certified mail with a return receipt and shall be presented to any court of proper jurisdiction if communication continues. 
XXXX, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
Please be advised that this is my XXXX XXXX WRITTEN REQUEST AND FINAL WARNING that I fully intend to pursue litigation in accordance with the FCRA to enforce my right and seek relief and recover all monetary damages that I may be entitled to under Section 616 and Section 617 regarding your continued willful and negligent noncompliance.

Despite my previous 2 written requests, the unverified items listed below still remain on my credit report in violation of XXXX XXXX. You stated in your responses to my 2 dispute letters that you have verified that the items listed below are accurate, but you failed to send me copies of the documents that you used to verify these accounts as per my request. The fact that you have ignored my request to send me copies of that of the documents that you used to verify the disputed accounts like you said you did. Your failure to delete the disputed accounts that you can not verify after XXXX written requests is also evidence of your Willful disregard of XXXX XXXX. 
When we go through the discovery process you will be required to produce these documents along with an affidavit swearing under oath that these are the true and correct documents that you used to verify the disputed accounts. The fact that you do not have any of the said documents in your files is proof that you did not properly verify the accounts within 30 days as required by law and Court will order you to delete them.

You say that you have reinvestigated these accounts but you have admitted that all you have done is parroted information given to you by other sources and shifted the burden back to me to contact the original creditor to verify these accounts which is clearly in violation in violation of 1681 { a } { 4 }.

I also asked you to give me the name of the person in your company who verified the accuracy of these accounts but you ignored this request as well which is another violation of XXXX XXXX and evidence of your willful disregard of the law. 
Please be advised that under Section 611 { 5 } { A } of the FCRA-you are required to .PROMPTLY DELETE ALL INFORMATION WHICH CAN NOT BE VERIFIED. I request that you do this immediately. 
The law is very clear as to the Civil liability and remedy available to me { Section 616 & amp ; 617 } if you fail to comply with XXXX XXXX. I am a litigious consumer and fully intend on fully intend on pursuing litigation in this matter to enforce my rights under the FCRA. 
I DEMAND THAT YOU DELETE ALL OF THE ACCOUNTS LISTED BELOW IMMEDIATELY. PLEASE PROVIDE ME WITH A COPY OF AN UPDATED AND CORRECTED CREDIT REPORT SHOWING THAT THESE HAVE BEEN DELETED.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Formal Dispute Regarding Reporting of Late Payments and Permissible Purpose Dear [ XXXX XXXX XXXX ], I am writing to formally dispute certain entries on my credit report that indicate late payments. Specifically, I question whether the entity reporting these late payments had a permissible purpose under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), as codified in 15 U.S.C. 1681 ( b ), to access and report this information.

Under FCRA 15 U.S.C. 1681 ( b ), a consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report only under specific circumstances that constitute a permissible purpose. These purposes include, but are not limited to, transactions initiated by the consumer, employment considerations, or other legitimate needs as defined by law. If the entity reporting these late payments accessed or shared my information outside these parameters, they may have violated federal law.

The late payments in question are associated with the following account ( s ) : Creditor Name : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Date ( s ) of Late Payment ( s ) : XX/XX/XXXX - XXXX XXXX I request that you investigate this matter promptly. Please verify whether the reporting entity had a permissible purpose to access and furnish this information and provide me with documentation supporting their compliance with the FCRA. If the reporting can not be verified or is found to lack a permissible purpose, I demand that these entries be deleted from my credit report immediately.

Furthermore, I request that you notify me of the results of your investigation, as well as any changes made to my credit report, within the time frame prescribed by law.

For your reference, I have attached a copy of my credit report highlighting the disputed entries, along with copies of relevant supporting documentation, including proof of identity.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Credit inquiries on your report that you don't recognize
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute unauthorized inquiries that have been reported on my credit file by your company, AMERICAN CREDIT ACCEPT. The inquiry in question was made on XX/XX/year>. This inquiry was conducted without my consent and therefore violated the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically regarding permissible purpose. 

Under the FCRA ( 15 U.S.C. 1681b ), a company must have a permissible purpose to access a consumers credit report. Since I did not authorize or initiate any business dealings that would grant your company such access, these inquiries are unauthorized.

I request that you immediately : 1.Remove the unauthorized inquiries from all of my credit reports ( XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 
2.Provide compensation of {$1000.00} as stipulated under the FCRA for each violation. 

If you are willing to resolve this matter amicably, I am prepared to sign an agreement that includes the removal of these inquiries and the payment of the compensation without requiring your client to admit any wrongdoing. This would be a mutually beneficial resolution and would save both parties the time and expense of further action.Failure to do so mat also lead meto file complaints with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and other regulatory agencies. 

Please be advised that if I am forced to litigate, I will seek actual damages as allowed under the FCRA, including but not limited to costs incurred as a result of these unauthorized inquiries. Additionally, I will pursue compensation for attorneys fees, court costs, and other expenses related to litigation. Below is an itemized estimate of potential litigation costs : Attorney Fees : {$5000.00} - {$10000.00} Court Filing Fees : {$500.00} Discovery Costs : {$1000.00} Expert Witness Fees ( if necessary ) : {$3000.00} Additional Miscellaneous Costs : {$1000.00} Total Estimated Litigation Costs : {$10000.00} - {$15000.00} I urge you to consider the significant expense litigation would entail for your company in comparison to resolving this matter promptly and amicably. 

Please provide a written response to this letter within 15 days of receipt, confirming the steps you will take to address this matter. If I do not receive a satisfactory resolution, I will be compelled to explore additional remedies available to me under the law. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I look forward to your response.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative: To whom it may concern : According to the FCRA, I have the right to dispute any information on my credit report that I believe is not correct. I reserve the right to dispute any information that I deem to be inaccurate. I won't stand for any misinformation being associated with my name and financial history. If there's something on my credit report that doesn't seem right, you can bet that I'll be taking action to get it removed.I can not recognize or accept the allegation of delinquency without factual proof. There must be some sort of evidence to back up the claim. Otherwise, I can not and will not recognize or accept the allegation. According to federal and state law, you must report any allegations with the greatest compliance and accuracy possible.You should not report any claims that you know or should know are not in compliance with regulations and the law. If you do report such claims, you could be subject to fines or other penalties. Furthermore, reporting claims that you know are not in compliance could damage the reputation of your company.I am writing to inform you that you need to make sure all your claims are factual and certified before reporting them. This is required by the Metro 2 reporting standard. I request that you provide evidence to support the existence of the account and evidence that the account was used for a permissible purpose. Please provide any documents or records you may have that can help corroborate the account and it's permissible purpose.I am giving you 30 days to investigate the matter and determine whether it is still being reported accurately and in compliance with regulations. If it is not, I want it removed from the report.I hereby authorize you to take whatever steps are necessary to correct my credit. Please send me physical proof of any actions taken on my behalf. I appreciate your help in making sure my credit is in good standing.

XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XX/XX/year> Consumer Financial Protection Bureau XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Subject : Request for Investigation into Transunion Reporting Practices Dear CFPB, I am writing to formally request your assistance regarding a violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act by TransUnion. TransUnion has not adhered to the obligations set forth in 15 U.S. Code 1681, particularly concerning the accuracy and fairness of credit reporting. 

I have noticed that my account ( XXXX XXXXXXXX ) related to my XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, which was reported in XX/XX/year>. But was deleted by TransUnion Between XX/XX/XXXX, XX/XX/year> from my credit report. This action has adversely affected my credit history and overall credit score, undermining my financial standing.

The Congressional findings highlight the importance of accurate and fair credit reporting, emphasizing how inaccuracies can impair the efficiency of the banking system and erode public confidence. As a consumer, I rely on accurate credit reporting for fair access to credit, and the deletion of my account has hindered that access. 

I am uploading a copy of my XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX credit report for your review. I kindly request that you investigate this matter and facilitate the reinstatement of my account on my credit report. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I look forward to your response. 

Sincerely,

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to dispute the accuracy and validity of a charge-off account that has been reported on my consumer report. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681 et seq., I have the right to accurate and complete information in my credit reports. I believe the information regarding this charge-off account is inaccurate and/or incomplete, and I request an immediate investigation into this matter. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX Inaccuracies and Issues 1. Account Type and Description Discrepancy : o TransUnion : " Business Credit Card. '' o XXXX : " Charge Account. '' o This inconsistency in account type descriptions raises concerns about data accuracy. 
2. High Credit and Credit Limit Discrepancies : o High Credit : {$3200.00} ( consistent across reports ). 
o Credit Limit : {$3000.00} ( TransUnion and XXXX ). 
o Past Due Balance : {$3600.00}. 
o The past due balance exceeds the high credit and credit limit, which is an anomaly requiring verification. 
3. Comments Conflict : o TransUnion : " Charged off as bad debt. Dispute resolved ; reported by grantor. '' o XXXX : " Unpaid balance reported as a loss by the credit grantor. '' o XXXX : " CONSUMER STATEMENT ITEM IN DISPUTE BY CONSUMER. '' o These comments reflect inconsistent handling of disputes and charge-offs. 

4. Date Discrepancies : o Date Last Active : TransUnion : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Date of Last Payment : TransUnion and XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o These inconsistencies should be clarified and corrected. 
5. Payment History Errors : o The Two-Year Payment History shows " CO '' ( Charge Off ) consistently across all bureaus. If this account was disputed or resolved, these entries should reflect the resolution accurately. 


XXXX  XXXX XXXX Inaccuracies and Issues XXXX. XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX : o Balance : {$4100.00} ( TransUnion and XXXX ). 
o Credit Limit : {$3700.00} ( all bureaus ). 
o The balance exceeds the credit limit, which is an anomaly that needs verification. 
2. Comments Discrepancies : o TransUnion : " Charged off as bad debt. Dispute resolved : reported by grantor. '' o XXXX : " Account was in dispute, now resolved - reported by subscriber. '' o XXXX : " CONSUMER STATEMENT ITEM IN DISPUTE BY CONSUMER. '' o Comments lack consistency regarding the resolution status and how the dispute was handled. 
3. Date Discrepancies : o Date Last Active : TransUnion : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Date of Last Payment : TransUnion : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o There is a slight discrepancy in the " Date Last Active '' between TransUnion and XXXX. 
4. Future Reporting Dates : o Last Reported : TransUnion : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Reporting future dates violates the FCRA 's accuracy and timeliness requirements.

5. Payment History Inconsistencies : o The Two-Year Payment History shows continuous " CO '' ( Charge Off ) statuses. If the account dispute was resolved, these entries should reflect the resolution XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Key Inaccuracies and Issues : 1. Balance Exceeding Credit Limit : o Balance : {$7800.00}.

o Credit Limit : {$7100.00}.

o The balance exceeds the credit limit, which is inconsistent with standard account reporting practices and needs verification. 
2. Comments Discrepancies : o TransUnion : " Charged off as bad debt. Account information disputed by consumer, meets FCRA requirements. '' o XXXX : " Customer disputed account - reported by subscriber. Unpaid balance reported as a loss by the credit grantor. '' o XXXX : " CONSUMER STATEMENT ITEM IN DISPUTE BY CONSUMER. '' o These comments vary significantly and do not provide a clear resolution status. 
3. Future Reporting Dates : o Last Reported : TransUnion : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Reporting future dates violates the FCRA 's accuracy requirements. 
4. Date Discrepancies : o Date Last Active : TransUnion : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Date of Last Payment : All bureaus : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Discrepancies in the " Date Last Active '' should be clarified. 
5. Payment History Errors : o The Two-Year Payment History shows " CO '' ( Charge Off ) consistently for all months. If the account was disputed or resolved, the history should reflect this. 


1. Verification Requirement ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ) : - The FCRA mandates that all disputed information be verified within 30 days of a consumers dispute. If the information can not be verified, it must be corrected or deleted. 
2. Obligation of Accuracy ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ) : - Consumer reporting agencies must ensure maximum possible accuracy of the information in consumer reports. The inaccurate or unverifiable information regarding the charge-off account violates this requirement. 
3. Re-Aging of Debt ( 15 U.S.C. 1681c ) : - The FCRA prohibits re-aging of old debt. If the date of first delinquency is inaccurately reported, the charge-off may appear on my credit report longer than the allowed 7 years. 
4. Validation of Debt ( Fair Debt Collection Practices Act, 15 U.S.C. 1692g ) : - Under the FDCPA, if the debt is being collected by a third party, I have the right to request validation of the debt, including proof of ownership and the amount owed. If the creditor or collection agency can not validate the debt, it must be removed.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
XX/XX/XXXX Subject : Dispute of Inaccurate Late Payments on Credit Report Dear CFPB, I am submitting this complaint regarding inaccurate late payments that are reported on my credit file maintained by TransUnion. I believe these late payments are erroneous and do not accurately reflect my payment history. 
Nature of the Complaint : Inaccurate Reporting : The late payments listed on my credit report for XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX are inaccurate. My payment history reflects consistent on-time payments, and I have been enrolled in autopay for this account. 
Violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : The inaccurate reporting of these late payments violates my rights under the FCRA ( 15 USC 1666 ( b ) ), as they misrepresent my creditworthiness.

Potential Violation of Fair Debt Collections Practices Act ( FDCPA ) : The reporting of false late payments may also constitute a violation of the FDCPA, which protects consumers from misrepresentation regarding their accounts. 
Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) : I assert that the reporting practices violate the TILA, which mandates accurate reporting of credit information. 
Additionally, the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically sections 15 U.S. Code 1681i and 15 U.S. Code 1681s-2, mandates that credit reporting agencies and information furnishers correct any inaccurate or incomplete information in credit reports and ensure the maximum accuracy of information contained in consumer files. 
Summary of Errors and Discrepancies : The account reflects late payments in XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX, which are inaccurate. 
Payment history should reflect 100 % on-time payments. 
The discrepancies misrepresent my creditworthiness and violate consumer protection laws. 
Requested Resolution : I request that TransUnion conduct a thorough investigation into this matter and remove the inaccurate late payments from my credit report. I ask that all such entries be updated to reflect my true payment history of 100 % on-time payments. 
I expect to receive written documentation confirming the removal of these entries within 30 days of this complaint submission. Failure to resolve this issue may lead to further action to protect my rights as a consumer. 
Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX
