Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Formal Dispute Regarding Reporting of Late Payments and Permissible Purpose Dear [ XXXX XXXX XXXX ], I am writing to formally dispute certain entries on my credit report that indicate late payments. Specifically, I question whether the entity reporting these late payments had a permissible purpose under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), as codified in 15 U.S.C. 1681 ( b ), to access and report this information.

Under FCRA 15 U.S.C. 1681 ( b ), a consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report only under specific circumstances that constitute a permissible purpose. These purposes include, but are not limited to, transactions initiated by the consumer, employment considerations, or other legitimate needs as defined by law. If the entity reporting these late payments accessed or shared my information outside these parameters, they may have violated federal law.

The late payments in question are associated with the following account ( s ) : Creditor Name : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Date ( s ) of Late Payment ( s ) : XX/XX/XXXX - XXXX XXXX I request that you investigate this matter promptly. Please verify whether the reporting entity had a permissible purpose to access and furnish this information and provide me with documentation supporting their compliance with the FCRA. If the reporting can not be verified or is found to lack a permissible purpose, I demand that these entries be deleted from my credit report immediately.

Furthermore, I request that you notify me of the results of your investigation, as well as any changes made to my credit report, within the time frame prescribed by law.

For your reference, I have attached a copy of my credit report highlighting the disputed entries, along with copies of relevant supporting documentation, including proof of identity.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
SECTION 16.Rights of accused and of victims.

( a ) In all criminal prosecutions the accused shall, upon demand, be informed of the nature and cause of the accusation, and shall be furnished a copy of the charges, and shall have the right to have compulsory process for witnesses, to confront at trial adverse witnesses, to be heard in person, by counsel or both, and to have a speedy and public trial by impartial jury in the county where the crime was committed. If the county is not known, the indictment or information may charge venue in two or more counties conjunctively and proof that the crime was committed in that area shall be sufficient ; but before pleading the accused may elect in which of those counties the trial will take place. Venue for prosecution of crimes committed beyond the boundaries of the state shall be fixed by law.

( b ) To preserve and protect the right of crime victims to achieve justice, ensure a meaningful role throughout the criminal and juvenile justice systems for crime victims, and ensure that crime victims rights and interests are respected and protected by law in a manner no less vigorous than protections afforded to criminal defendants and juvenile delinquents, every victim is entitled to the following rights, beginning at the time of his or her victimization : ( 1 ) The right to due process and to be treated with fairness and respect for the victims dignity.

( 2 ) The right to be free from intimidation, harassment, and abuse.

( 3 ) The right, within the judicial process, to be reasonably protected from the accused and any person acting on behalf of the accused. However, nothing contained herein is intended to create a special relationship between the crime victim and any law enforcement agency or office absent a special relationship or duty as defined by Florida law.

( 4 ) The right to have the safety and welfare of the victim and the victims family considered when setting bail, including setting pretrial release conditions that protect the safety and welfare of the victim and the victims family.

( 5 ) The right to prevent the disclosure of information or records that could be used to locate or harass the victim or the victims family, or which could disclose confidential or privileged information of the victim.

( 6 ) A victim shall have the following specific rights upon request : a.The right to reasonable, accurate, and timely notice of, and to be present at, all public proceedings involving the criminal conduct, including, but not limited to, trial, plea, sentencing, or adjudication, even if the victim will be a witness at the proceeding, notwithstanding any rule to the contrary. A victim shall also be provided reasonable, accurate, and timely notice of any release or escape of the defendant or delinquent, and any proceeding during which a right of the victim is implicated.

b.The right to be heard in any public proceeding involving pretrial or other release from any form of legal constraint, plea, sentencing, adjudication, or parole, and any proceeding during which a right of the victim is implicated.

c.The right to confer with the prosecuting attorney concerning any plea agreements, participation in pretrial diversion programs, release, restitution, sentencing, or any other disposition of the case.

d.The right to provide information regarding the impact of the offenders conduct on the victim and the victims family to the individual responsible for conducting any presentence investigation or compiling any presentence investigation report, and to have any such information considered in any sentencing recommendations submitted to the court.

e.The right to receive a copy of any presentence report, and any other report or record relevant to the exercise of a victims right, except for such portions made confidential or exempt by law.

f.The right to be informed of the conviction, sentence, adjudication, place and time of incarceration, or other disposition of the convicted offender, any scheduled release date of the offender, and the release of or the escape of the offender from custody.

g.The right to be informed of all postconviction processes and procedures, to participate in such processes and procedures, to provide information to the release authority to be considered before any release decision is made, and to be notified of any release decision regarding the offender. The parole or early release authority shall extend the right to be heard to any person harmed by the offender.

h.The right to be informed of clemency and expungement procedures, to provide information to the governor, the court, any clemency board, and other authority in these procedures, and to have that information considered before a clemency or expungement decision is made ; and to be notified of such decision in advance of any release of the offender.

( 7 ) The rights of the victim, as provided in subparagraph ( 6 ) a., subparagraph ( 6 ) b., or subparagraph ( 6 ) c., that apply to any first appearance proceeding are satisfied by a reasonable attempt by the appropriate agency to notify the victim and convey the victims views to the court.

( 8 ) The right to the prompt return of the victims property when no longer needed as evidence in the case.

( 9 ) The right to full and timely restitution in every case and from each convicted offender for all losses suffered, both directly and indirectly, by the victim as a result of the criminal conduct.

( 10 ) The right to proceedings free from unreasonable delay, and to a prompt and final conclusion of the case and any related postjudgment proceedings.

a.The state attorney may file a good faith demand for a speedy trial and the trial court shall hold a calendar call, with notice, within fifteen days of the filing demand, to schedule a trial to commence on a date at least five days but no more than sixty days after the date of the calendar call unless the trial judge enters an order with specific findings of fact justifying a trial date more than sixty days after the calendar call.

b.All state-level appeals and collateral attacks on any judgment must be complete within two years from the date of appeal in non-capital cases and within five years from the date of appeal in capital cases, unless a court enters an order with specific findings as to why the court was unable to comply with this subparagraph and the circumstances causing the delay. Each year, the chief judge of any district court of appeal or the chief justice of the supreme court shall report on a case-by-case basis to the speaker of the house of representatives and the president of the senate all cases where the court entered an order regarding inability to comply with this subparagraph. The legislature may enact legislation to implement this subparagraph.

( 11 ) The right to be informed of these rights, and to be informed that victims can seek the advice of an attorney with respect to their rights. This information shall be made available to the general public and provided to all crime victims in the form of a card or by other means intended to effectively advise the victim of their rights under this section.

( c ) The victim, the retained attorney of the victim, a lawful representative of the victim, or the office of the state attorney upon request of the victim, may assert and seek enforcement of the rights enumerated in this section and any other right afforded to a victim by law in any trial or appellate court, or before any other authority with jurisdiction over the case, as a matter of right. The court or other authority with jurisdiction shall act promptly on such a request, affording a remedy by due course of law for the violation of any right. The reasons for any decision regarding the disposition of a victims right shall be clearly stated on the record.

( d ) The granting of the rights enumerated in this section to victims may not be construed to deny or impair any other rights possessed by victims. The provisions of this section apply throughout criminal and juvenile justice processes, are self-executing, and do not require implementing legislation. This section may not be construed to create any cause of action for damages against the state or a political subdivision of the state, or any officer, employee, or agent of the state or its political subdivisions.

( e ) As used in this section, a victim is a person who suffers direct or threatened physical, psychological, or financial harm as a result of the commission or attempted commission of a crime or delinquent act or against whom the crime or delinquent act is committed. The term victim includes the victims lawful representative, the parent or guardian of a minor, or the next of kin of a homicide victim, except upon a showing that the interest of such individual would be in actual or potential conflict with the interests of the victim. The term victim does not include the accused. The terms crime and criminal include delinquent acts and conduct.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I recently conducted a review of my credit report and found several items that have caused me significant distress. These items appear to be unverifiable, inaccurate, and questionable. Your agency has failed to ensure the accuracy of the information as required under 15 U.S. Code 1681e ( b ) Accuracy of Reports. This statute mandates that consumer reporting agencies must follow reasonable procedures to ensure the maximum possible accuracy of the information they report.

Furthermore, under 15 U.S. Code 1681i ( 5 ) Treatment of Inaccurate or Unverifiable Information, you are required to promptly delete or modify any information found to be inaccurate, incomplete, or unverifiable during a reinvestigation. If you are unable to provide me with verifiable proof of the accuracy of the disputed items within 15 days of your investigation, these accounts and the related information must be removed from my credit report.

Additionally, under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), I do not recognize any of the alleged creditors or debt collectors. I have never entered into a valid contract with any of these entities, nor have I engaged in any transactions with them. As such, these accounts are fraudulent and and inaccurate information.

Moreover, under the Fair Credit Billing Act, my right to privacy has been violated, and this breach infringes upon my rights as outlined in The Privacy Act of 1974. Removing the inaccurate and fraudulent information from my credit report will help restore my privacy and prevent further violations.

FINAL NOTICE! I have contacted this companies that I am distressed that you have included the information below in my credit profile and that you have failed to maintainreasonable procedures in your operations to assure maximum possible accuracy in the credit reports you publish. Credit reporting laws ensure that bureaus report only 100 % accurate credit information. YOU ARE VIOLATING FCRA REGULATIONS and UNITED STATES of AMERICA FEDERAL LAW.

Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act this disputed item may not appear on my credit report if it can not be supported by any evidence.

15 U.S. Code 1681n Civil liability for willful noncompliance and 15 U.S. Code 1681o Civil liability for negligent noncompliance and 15 U.S. Code 1692k civil liability In multiple violations and Im entitled to monetary compensation under FCRA 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( 6 ) Notice of Results of Reinvestigation. ( A ) In general. A consumer reporting agency shall provide written notice to a consumer of the results of a reinvestigation under this subsection not later than 5 business days after the completion of the reinvestigation, by mail or, if authorized by the consumer for that purpose, by other means available to the agency ( B ) Contents. As part of, or in addition to, the notice under subparagraph ( A ), a consumer reporting agency shall provide to a consumer in writing before the expiration of the 5-day period referred to in subparagraph ( A ) ( I ) a statement that the reinvestigation is completed. 
In accordance with the FCRA, a consumer report excludes any report solely detailing transactions or interactions between the consumer and the reporting entity. Any inclusion of late payments or derogatory statuses constitutes a clear infringement of 15 USC 1681a ( d ) ( 1 ), as this information relates to the consumers experiences.

Accounts listed below in green color highlighted and tag as in violation under 15 U.S. Code 1666 ( b ) billing error are inaccurate late payment history, must be updated to paid on time as never been late as agreed.

Item Number Company Name Account Number Comments XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  4 late payments.

Also, 15 USC Section 1681i ( d ) requires that you notify me when the items have been deleted. Under 15 USC Section 1681j, there should be no charge for this notification or for the corrected copy of my report. Finally, please send me the names and addresses of all individuals you contacted so that I may follow up with them directly. Thank you for your assistance in this matter.

Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), I am submitting a formal complaint regarding my attempts to resolve an issue with XXXX concerning inaccurate credit reporting and the failure to provide a required 1099-C form for a charged-off account. 

Here is a summary of the situation : Account Status : XXXX has reported an account of mine as " charged off '' on my credit report for several years. However, despite this reporting, XXXX has failed to issue a 1099-C form, which is required when a debt is forgiven. 
Attempts to Resolve : I have reached out to XXXX multiple times to inquire about this issue. 
Specifically, I have contacted XXXX in XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX, seeking clarification and requesting the necessary 1099-C form. 
Despite my repeated attempts, I have yet to receive a response or the requested form. The company has not provided any documentation or explanation for the charged-off status. 
Impact on My Credit : The failure to provide the 1099-C form or to resolve this matter has caused confusion regarding my credit report and has left me in a state of uncertainty about the true status of my account with XXXX. 
I have made every effort to address this matter directly with XXXX, but without success. I am now seeking the assistance of the CFPB in ensuring that XXXX provides the required 1099-C form and corrects any potential inaccuracies in the reporting of this account. 

Please let me know if any additional information is needed to assist with this matter. 

Thank you for your attention to this issue.

Consumer complaint narrative:
RE : Formal Demand to Remove Inaccurate Child Support Account from Credit Report To Whom It May Concern, This letter serves as my third and final demand that you immediately remove the inaccurate child support account information from my credit report. I have previously notified you of the inaccuracies, yet no corrective action has been taken. This ongoing violation of federal law demonstrates negligence and disregard for your legal responsibilities.

Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681, you are legally obligated to ensure that all information you report is accurate, complete, and verifiable. Specifically : 1 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies must follow reasonable procedures to ensure maximum possible accuracy in the information they report.

2 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) : Upon notice of a dispute, you are required to conduct a prompt and thorough reinvestigation to verify or remove the contested information.

3 15 U.S.C. 1681n : Noncompliance with the FCRA subjects you to civil liability, including actual damages, statutory damages of {$1000.00} per violation, punitive damages, and attorney fees.

In addition to your violations of the FCRA, multiple court rulings have affirmed the illegality of reporting inaccurate or unverified child support accounts to credit bureaus XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX : The court ruled that the federal government wrongfully reported child support arrears to credit bureaus and ordered the records expungedXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX   ) : The court found that the child support agency violated the paying parents due process rights by reporting arrears without proper notice.

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX The court reversed a decision to report child support arrears due to a lack of evidence and improper procedures.

I have solid evidence that the child support account information you are reporting is false and was provided without proper verification or notice.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
XX/XX/XXXX Subject : Formal Complaint Regarding Inaccurate Late Payments on XXXX  XXXX Account Dear CFPB, I am writing to formally dispute inaccurate late payments reported on my credit file for the XXXX XXXX account ( Account Number : XXXX ). These late payments, specifically a 30-day late payment for XX/XX/XXXX and a 60-day late payment for XX/XX/XXXX, are erroneous and do not reflect my actual payment history. 
Nature of the Complaint : Inaccurate Reporting : The listed late payments are incorrect as I have consistently made my payments on time through autopay. 
Violation of FCRA ( 15 USC 1681i and 1681s-2 ) : Credit reporting agencies and furnishers are required to ensure maximum accuracy in consumer files. The failure to correct these inaccuracies constitutes noncompliance with federal law.

Violation of FDCPA ( 15 USC 1692e ) : Reporting incorrect information about payments may qualify as deceptive or misleading practices under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act.

Violation of TILA ( 15 USC 1601 ) : The Truth in Lending Act mandates accurate reporting of credit terms and histories.

Civil Liability Under FCRA ( 15 USC 1681n and 1681o ) : Noncompliance with these provisions subjects the responsible parties to legal liabilities, including actual damages, punitive damages, and legal fees. 
Summary of Discrepancies TransUnion : Reported 30-day late payment for XX/XX/XXXX and 60-day late payment for XX/XX/XXXX. 
These are incorrect as the account history reflects consistent payments with no delinquencies. 
Requested Resolution : I request the following : Conduct a thorough investigation into the discrepancies on this account. 
Remove the inaccurate late payment entries from my credit file. 
Provide written confirmation of the corrections within 30 days, as required under 15 USC 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ). 
Failure to comply with this request may result in further actions to enforce my rights as a consumer under federal law. Attached, you will find supporting documentation, including payment records and statements, to substantiate my claim. 
Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
XX/XX/XXXX Subject : Dispute of Inaccurate Late Payments on Credit Report Dear CFPB, I am submitting this complaint regarding inaccurate late payments that are reported on my credit file maintained by TransUnion. I believe these late payments are erroneous and do not accurately reflect my payment history. 
Nature of the Complaint : Inaccurate Reporting : The late payments listed on my credit report for XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX are inaccurate. My payment history reflects consistent on-time payments, and I have been enrolled in autopay for this account. 
Violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : The inaccurate reporting of these late payments violates my rights under the FCRA ( 15 USC 1666 ( b ) ), as they misrepresent my creditworthiness.

Potential Violation of Fair Debt Collections Practices Act ( FDCPA ) : The reporting of false late payments may also constitute a violation of the FDCPA, which protects consumers from misrepresentation regarding their accounts. 
Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) : I assert that the reporting practices violate the TILA, which mandates accurate reporting of credit information. 
Additionally, the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically sections 15 U.S. Code 1681i and 15 U.S. Code 1681s-2, mandates that credit reporting agencies and information furnishers correct any inaccurate or incomplete information in credit reports and ensure the maximum accuracy of information contained in consumer files. 
Summary of Errors and Discrepancies : The account reflects late payments in XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX, which are inaccurate. 
Payment history should reflect 100 % on-time payments. 
The discrepancies misrepresent my creditworthiness and violate consumer protection laws. 
Requested Resolution : I request that TransUnion conduct a thorough investigation into this matter and remove the inaccurate late payments from my credit report. I ask that all such entries be updated to reflect my true payment history of 100 % on-time payments. 
I expect to receive written documentation confirming the removal of these entries within 30 days of this complaint submission. Failure to resolve this issue may lead to further action to protect my rights as a consumer. 
Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to dispute the accuracy and validity of a charge-off account that has been reported on my consumer report. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681 et seq., I have the right to accurate and complete information in my credit reports. I believe the information regarding this charge-off account is inaccurate and/or incomplete, and I request an immediate investigation into this matter. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX Inaccuracies and Issues 1. Account Type and Description Discrepancy : o TransUnion : " Business Credit Card. '' o XXXX : " Charge Account. '' o This inconsistency in account type descriptions raises concerns about data accuracy. 
2. High Credit and Credit Limit Discrepancies : o High Credit : {$3200.00} ( consistent across reports ). 
o Credit Limit : {$3000.00} ( TransUnion and XXXX ). 
o Past Due Balance : {$3600.00}. 
o The past due balance exceeds the high credit and credit limit, which is an anomaly requiring verification. 
3. Comments Conflict : o TransUnion : " Charged off as bad debt. Dispute resolved ; reported by grantor. '' o XXXX : " Unpaid balance reported as a loss by the credit grantor. '' o XXXX : " CONSUMER STATEMENT ITEM IN DISPUTE BY CONSUMER. '' o These comments reflect inconsistent handling of disputes and charge-offs. 

4. Date Discrepancies : o Date Last Active : TransUnion : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Date of Last Payment : TransUnion and XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o These inconsistencies should be clarified and corrected. 
5. Payment History Errors : o The Two-Year Payment History shows " CO '' ( Charge Off ) consistently across all bureaus. If this account was disputed or resolved, these entries should reflect the resolution accurately. 


XXXX  XXXX XXXX Inaccuracies and Issues XXXX. XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX : o Balance : {$4100.00} ( TransUnion and XXXX ). 
o Credit Limit : {$3700.00} ( all bureaus ). 
o The balance exceeds the credit limit, which is an anomaly that needs verification. 
2. Comments Discrepancies : o TransUnion : " Charged off as bad debt. Dispute resolved : reported by grantor. '' o XXXX : " Account was in dispute, now resolved - reported by subscriber. '' o XXXX : " CONSUMER STATEMENT ITEM IN DISPUTE BY CONSUMER. '' o Comments lack consistency regarding the resolution status and how the dispute was handled. 
3. Date Discrepancies : o Date Last Active : TransUnion : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Date of Last Payment : TransUnion : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o There is a slight discrepancy in the " Date Last Active '' between TransUnion and XXXX. 
4. Future Reporting Dates : o Last Reported : TransUnion : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Reporting future dates violates the FCRA 's accuracy and timeliness requirements.

5. Payment History Inconsistencies : o The Two-Year Payment History shows continuous " CO '' ( Charge Off ) statuses. If the account dispute was resolved, these entries should reflect the resolution XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Key Inaccuracies and Issues : 1. Balance Exceeding Credit Limit : o Balance : {$7800.00}.

o Credit Limit : {$7100.00}. 
o The balance exceeds the credit limit, which is inconsistent with standard account reporting practices and needs verification. 
2. Comments Discrepancies : o TransUnion : " Charged off as bad debt. Account information disputed by consumer, meets FCRA requirements. '' o XXXX : " Customer disputed account - reported by subscriber. Unpaid balance reported as a loss by the credit grantor. '' o XXXX : " CONSUMER STATEMENT ITEM IN DISPUTE BY CONSUMER. '' o These comments vary significantly and do not provide a clear resolution status. 
3. Future Reporting Dates : o Last Reported : TransUnion : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Reporting future dates violates the FCRA 's accuracy requirements. 
4. Date Discrepancies : o Date Last Active : TransUnion : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Date of Last Payment : All bureaus : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Discrepancies in the " Date Last Active '' should be clarified. 
5. Payment History Errors : o The Two-Year Payment History shows " CO '' ( Charge Off ) consistently for all months. If the account was disputed or resolved, the history should reflect this. 


1. Verification Requirement ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ) : - The FCRA mandates that all disputed information be verified within 30 days of a consumers dispute. If the information can not be verified, it must be corrected or deleted.

2. Obligation of Accuracy ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ) : - Consumer reporting agencies must ensure maximum possible accuracy of the information in consumer reports. The inaccurate or unverifiable information regarding the charge-off account violates this requirement.

3. Re-Aging of Debt ( 15 U.S.C. 1681c ) : - The FCRA prohibits re-aging of old debt. If the date of first delinquency is inaccurately reported, the charge-off may appear on my credit report longer than the allowed 7 years.

4. Validation of Debt ( Fair Debt Collection Practices Act, 15 U.S.C. 1692g ) : - Under the FDCPA, if the debt is being collected by a third party, I have the right to request validation of the debt, including proof of ownership and the amount owed. If the creditor or collection agency can not validate the debt, it must be removed.

Consumer complaint narrative:
There are multiple inquiries reporting on my TransUnion XXXX XXXX credit report which i never authorized or applied for myself. i have contacted each bureau and informed them that these inquiries are a result of identity theft and have yet to hear back from either bureau and said inquiries are still being reported on my credit report.

As per 15 U.S. Code 1681c2 of the fair credit reporting act : Except as otherwise provided in this section, a consumer reporting agency shall block the reporting of any information in the file of a consumer that the consumer identifies as information that resulted from an alleged identity theft, not later than 4 business days after the date of receipt.

i am requesting the immediate removal of said inquiries from my TransUnion XXXX XXXX Credit report in accordance with 15 U.S. Code 1681c2 of the fair credit reporting act TRANSUNION XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  All of these inquiries stated above were not authorized by me and as such are a result of identity theft, they are still being reported on my credit reports as of XXXX & are negatively affecting me in. 

I demand these Inquiries be removed from my report immediately in accordance with 15 U.S. Code 1681c2 or i will be forced to proceed litigation against the bureaus with which they are being reported.

Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
Recently, I did an investigation on my credit report and found several items on there to be inaccurate. 

Under 15 U.S Code 1681e ( b ) Accuracy of report Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report. It shall follow reasonable procedures to assure the maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates.

15 U.S. Code 1691i ( 5 ) Treatment of inaccurate or unverifiable information ( A ) In general if, after any reinvestigation under paragraph ( 1 ) of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency shall ( i ) promptly delete that item of information from the file of the consumer, or modify that item of information as appropriate, based on the results of the investigation; and ( ii ) promptly notify the furnisher of that information that the information has been modified or deleted from the file of the consumer.

Items that need attention : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Date Opened : XX/XX/XXXX Balance : {$25000.00} Charged off Inquiries in Dispute : XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
RE : Formal Demand to Remove Inaccurate XXXX XXXX Account from Credit Report To Whom It May Concern, This letter serves as my third and final demand that you immediately remove the inaccurate XXXX XXXX account information from my credit report. I have previously notified you of the inaccuracies, yet no corrective action has been taken. This ongoing violation of federal law demonstrates negligence and disregard for your legal responsibilities. 

Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681, you are legally obligated to ensure that all information you report is accurate, complete, and verifiable. Specifically : 1 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies must follow reasonable procedures to ensure maximum possible accuracy in the information they report. 
2 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) : Upon notice of a dispute, you are required to conduct a prompt and thorough reinvestigation to verify or remove the contested information.

3 15 U.S.C. 1681n : Noncompliance with the FCRA subjects you to civil liability, including actual damages, statutory damages of {$1000.00} per violation, punitive damages, and attorney fees. 
In addition to your violations of the FCRA, multiple court rulings have affirmed the illegality of reporting inaccurate or unverified XXXX XXXX accounts to credit bureaus : XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX United States ( XXXX ) : The court ruled that the federal government wrongfully reported XXXX XXXX arrears to credit bureaus and ordered the records expunged. 
XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) : The court found that the XXXX XXXX agency violated the paying parents due process rights by reporting arrears without proper notice. 
XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX ( XXXX ) : The court reversed a decision to report XXXX XXXX  arrears due to a lack of evidence and improper procedures. 

I have solid evidence that the XXXX XXXX account information you are reporting is false and was provided without proper verification or notice. I have never provided my consent for this account to be reported, which is an additional violation of my rights. 

As a result of your continued failure to comply with federal law, I have suffered significant harm, including financial damages and emotional distress. Therefore, I am demanding : 1 Immediate removal of the inaccurate XXXX XXXX account from my credit report. 
2 Payment of {$1000.00} in statutory damages per bureau for failing to comply with the FCRA, payable to me at the address listed above. 

If you fail to comply with this demand, I will have no choice but to initiate litigation against all three credit bureaus for willful violations of the FCRA and associated damages. In court, I will seek the maximum allowable damages, including statutory damages, punitive damages, and attorney fees. 

This is your final notice. I strongly urge you to take this matter seriously and fulfill your legal obligations. Contact me via email only. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Contact via email only XXXX All rights reserved

Dear XXXX, FINAL NOTICE! I have contacted this companies that I am distressed that you have included the information below in my credit profile and that you have failed to maintain reasonable procedures in your operations to assure maximum possible accuracy in the credit reports you publish. ( A ) In general. A consumer reporting agency shall provide written notice to a consumer of the results of a reinvestigation under this subsection not later than 5 business days after the completion of the reinvestigation, by mail or, if authorized by the consumer for that purpose, by other means available to the agency ( B ) Contents. As part of, or in addition to, the notice under subparagraph ( A ), a consumer reporting agency shall provide to a consumer in writing before the expiration of the 5-day period referred to in subparagraph ( A ) ( I ) a statement that the reinvestigation is completed.

In accordance with the FCRA, a consumer report excludes any report solely detailing transactions or interactions between the consumer and the reporting entity. Consumer complaint narrative:
Three accounts were charged off but they still appear on my credit report in a negative status. The companies did not issue a 1099C although they have already charged off the amounts an of course take a loss on their financial statements for these items. I have requested removal of these negative information from my credit reports and/or the issuance of 1099C without success.

I have also refuted some of these balances as most times the original lender sold the account to a collection agency for pennies on the dollars. This then result in a collection agency hounding us like a bulldog to collect moneys that have already been written off.

All these issues paint a negative picture on the credit reporting agencies which effectively effect creditability and affect my ability to get credit at a lower interest rate or no credit at all

Product: Debt collection
Issue: Attempts to collect debt not owed
Consumer complaint narrative:
To Whom It May Concern, This formal complaint is regarding inaccurate and derogatory information reported on my credit file by NATIONAL CREDIT ADJUSTERS , L.L.C. This misinformation, which appears on my credit reports from multiple agencies, violates numerous federal laws, industry standards, and state-level consumer protection regulations. I am requesting immediate investigation, removal of the inaccuracies, and confirmation of compliance with federal law across all credit reporting agencies, both primary and secondary. 

Details of the Disputed Information Account Name : NATIONAL CREDIT ADJUSTERS , L.L.C Account Number : XXXX Agencies Reporting the Error : o Primary Bureaus : XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX Secondary Bureaus : XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, and any other relevant credit reporting agencies. 
Nature of the Error : [ Describe the error, e.g., " This account is inaccurately reported as delinquent, despite being paid in full on [ date ]. The furnisher has failed to validate this data under the law. '' ] Violations of Federal Laws 1. Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) o 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies must follow reasonable procedures to ensure the maximum possible accuracy of consumer reports. The continued publication of this inaccurate information violates this section.

o 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) : The CRAs have failed to properly investigate and correct this error within the required 30 days, as required by federal law.

o 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) : Any unve
rifiable information must be deleted or corrected immediately. The CRAs have violated this by retaining unverifiable data.

o 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) : The furnisher has failed to ensure that the information they report is accurate, as required by this section.

o 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( b ) : The furnisher did not conduct a reasonable reinvestigation after I disputed this account.

o 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) : Obsolete information ( e.g., older than seven years for derogatory marks ) remains on my credit report in violation of federal law.

2. Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) o 15 U.S.C. 1692e : Reporting false and misleading information about a debt constitutes a violation of this section.

o 15 U.S.C. 1692f : Reporting inaccurate derogatory
marks constitutes an unfair practice.

3. XXXX XXXX Reporting Standards o The inaccurate data fails to meet XXXX XXXX  guidelines, which set the industry standard for accurate and consistent credit reportin
g.

4. FACTA ( Fair and Accurate Credit Transactions Act ) o Under this law, the CRAs and furnishers are required to address inaccuracies related to identity theft and other reporting errors promptly. 


Impact of These Violations The inaccurate reporting has caused significant harm, including : Increased interest rates and denial of credit applications. 
Damage to my financial reputation, preventing me from securing favorable financial terms. 
Increased vulnerability to identity theft due to incorrect data being shared across multiple agencies.

Relief Requested I respectfully request the CFPB to take the following actions : 1. Investigate and Enforce Compliance : o Required to verify the accuracy of the information reported to all primary and secondary credit reporting agencies.

o Enforce compliance with all federal laws, including FCRA, FDCPA, and FACTA, as well as XXXX XXXX reporting standards.

2. Remove Inaccurate Data Across All Agencies : o Mandate the removal of this inaccurate information from all credit reporting agencies, including but not limited to : XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX. 
XXXX. Correct and Notify Affected Parties : o Require the CRAs to notify all entities that accessed my credit file in the last six months of the corrected information.

4. Statutory Damages : o Assess penalties for willful violations under 15 U.S.C. 1681n and negligent violations under 15 U.S.C. 1681o.

5. Confirm Updates in Writing : o Provide me with confirmation of the removals and corrections, along with updated credit reports from all agencies, at no cost to me.

Conclusion The actions of the furnisher and the credit reporting agencies constitute clear violations of federal and state laws, causing me ongoing harm. I request the CFPB 's assistance to ensure my rights are upheld and to prevent further damage to my financial reputation. If this matter is not resolved promptly, I reserve the right to pursue additional legal remedies. 
Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your prompt response. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
The information listed below is a result of identity theft and is fraudulent. I have never authorized, or opened the accounts listed. This information is frivolous. I request an investigation into fraudulent activities related with my SSN and personal information. Pursuant to the provisions of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( Public Law 91-506, Title VI, Section 611 ) ; Formal Request for Information : I am formally requesting the names and business addresses of each individual or entity you communicated with for verification purposes in relation to the fraudulent transactions identified in my credit report. This request aligns with my right to follow up on the information provided and to assist in this identity theft investigation. Attached is a copy of my government-issued identification and a copy of the identity theft report. I am requesting these fraudulent items removed immediately from my credit files. 
Fraudulent Account : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX It is unacceptable, and a violation of federal consumer protection laws, that I continue to face harassment and fictitious debts due to the unauthorized account and unauthorized inquiries. Your agency failure to delete these fraudulent entries will be direct violation of my rights under FCRA Section 605B ( 15 USC 1681c-2 ) ( a ). The FCRA requires immediate removal of fraudulent information from credit reports following a valid identity theft report, which I have provided. Such inaction is further aggravating the distress caused by this identity theft. There has been no legal proof of the marks has been provided or proven. I have reported the theft of my identity to the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) and have enclosed copies of the supporting documents, including the FTC Identity Theft Affidavit & Other documents. This unauthorized reporting has negatively impacted my credit standing. I respectfully request that the FTC, FDIC, & CFPB investigate this matter and take appropriate action to ensure that the erroneous and derogatory information is removed from my credit report. I am also pursuing complaints at federal levels to address these violations.

Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
I have an ongoing issue with TransUnion 's reporting of the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX account ( Account Number : XXXX ) on my credit report. TransUnion has failed to comply with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ), which requires credit reporting agencies to ensure maximum possible accuracy. 

The account contains incomplete and inconsistent information, including missing balance details, payment terms, and contradictory payment history. For example, the account shows late payments ( XX/XX/XXXX : 60 days past due ; XX/XX/XXXX : 30 days past due ) despite being listed as " Paid, Closed. '' These inaccuracies render the account unverifiable and misleading. 

I filed multiple disputes with TransUnion, including the following dispute reports : Report Number : XXXX ( XX/XX/XXXX ) Report Number : XXXX ( XX/XX/XXXX ) Report Number : XXXX ( XX/XX/XXXX ) Report Number : XXXX ( XX/XX/XXXX ) Report Number : XXXX ( XX/XX/XXXX ) Report Number : XXXX ( XX/XX/XXXX ) Despite these efforts, TransUnion has failed to correct the errors or provide verification of the account 's accuracy. Their responses have been generic and inadequate, failing to address the specific inaccuracies I identified. 

TransUnion has also violated 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ), which requires them to conduct a reasonable reinvestigation of disputed information. They continue to report the same incomplete and inconsistent data, which has caused harm to my creditworthiness, including credit denials, higher financial costs, and emotional distress. 

I request that the CFPB take immediate action to ensure TransUnion complies with the FCRA by : Permanently deleting the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX account from my credit report due to its unverifiable and inaccurate nature. 
Conducting a comprehensive audit of their procedures to ensure compliance with 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ). 
Providing a written explanation of how they verified the account or why they failed to correct it.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative: This complaint serves as my formal request for a comprehensive explanation of how your investigation was conducted, along with your method of verification. As outlined in consumer protection laws, proper verification requires sufficient documentary evidence to confirm the accuracy of the reported information. Failure to review essential documents, such as an account application, constitutes a violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), as established in cases like XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. I request that your response include the following details : What evidence did your representatives uncover that led them to conclude the item is reported accurately? What certified documents were reviewed as part of the investigation? Provide a full copy of all information shared with the data furnisher during the investigation. What expenses were incurred by your company to obtain the necessary documents for this investigation? Proof of your timely acquisition of certified documents. Did you speak directly to any representative of the company reporting this information to verify its accuracy? If yes : i. Who was contacted? ii. What was the date of contact? iii. How long was the conversation? iv. What was the representative 's position? v. What telephone number was used? vi. What is the role of the employee from your company who contacted the representative? vii. How long has that employee been with your company? XXXX. What specific training was provided to this employee for handling investigations of this nature? ix. Were there any emails or written communications exchanged between your company and the representative? If so, provide copies of all related correspondence and documents proving that a reasonable investigation was conducted. Additionally, please provide : The date the delinquency began. The exact date when this item will no longer be reported. I also request a notarized affidavit affirming that all the information you provide is true and accurate, in accordance with my civil rights under federal law. This matter requires a detailed and specific response, not a generic form letter. My original dispute clearly addressed the account in question, and a template response will not suffice. If you are unable to provide all the requested information within the time frame specified by applicable laws, including the FCRA, I demand the immediate and permanent removal of this item from my credit report. The continued reporting of this erroneous entry is harming my credit rating and has caused significant financial and emotional distress. If you fail to provide either the requested deletion or the documentation supporting your investigation, I will enforce my rights through formal legal discovery and depositions. Please be aware that I am knowledgeable about consumer protection laws and civil/federal court procedures, and I am prepared to represent myself pro se to seek a jury trial if necessary. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Balance : {$1000.00}

Consumer complaint narrative: According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act 15 USC 1681 section 602 a states " There is a need to insure that consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and a respect for the consumers right to privacy. '' XXXX and XXXX are consumer reporting agencies and I am the Consumer. I have the right to make sure my private information isn't shared which is backed by 15 USC 6801 which states '' It is the policy of the Congress that each financial institution has an affirmative and continuing obligation to respect the privacy of its customers and to protect the security and confidentiality of those customers nonpublic personal information. '' ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) is a financial institution by definition under that title. 15 USC 1681 section 604 a section 2 states that " In general Subject to subsection ( c ), any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report under the following circumstances and no other : in accordance with the written instructions of the consumer to whom it relates. '' ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) the financial institution and the Consumer reporting agencies XXXX and XXXX do not have my consent to furnish this information and they surely do not have my written consent. Any and all consent to XXXX, XXXX, ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) whether it be verbal, non-verbal, written, implied or otherwise is revoked. 15 USC 6802 ( b ) ( c ) states that " A financial institution may not disclose nonpublic personal information to a nonaffiliated third party unless the consumer is given an explanation of how the consumer can exercise that nondisclosure option. '' ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) Never informed me of my right to exercise my nondisclosure option. Not only that 15 USC 1681C ( a ) ( 5 ) states '' Except as authorized under subsection ( b ), no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years. '' This account is an adverse item they are reporting again without my permission which is against the law. 15 U.S. Code 1681s2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A states " A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. 15 U.S. Code 1681e states '' Every consumer reporting agency shall maintain reasonable procedures designed to avoid violations of section 1681c of this title and to limit the furnishing of consumer reports to the purposes listed under section 1681b of this title. XXXX and XXXX are not maintaining reasonable procedures. Also 12 CFR 1016.7 states that " A consumer may exercise the right to opt out at any time. '' I am opting out of your reporting services.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to dispute the accuracy and validity of a charge-off account that has been reported on my consumer report. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681 et seq., I have the right to accurate and complete information in my credit reports. I believe the information regarding this charge-off account is inaccurate and/or incomplete, and I request an immediate investigation into this matter. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX Inaccuracies and Issues 1. Account Type and Description Discrepancy : o TransUnion : " Business Credit Card. '' o XXXX : " Charge Account. '' o This inconsistency in account type descriptions raises concerns about data accuracy. 
2. High Credit and Credit Limit Discrepancies : o High Credit : {$3200.00} ( consistent across reports ). 
o Credit Limit : {$3000.00} ( TransUnion and XXXX ). 
o Past Due Balance : {$3600.00}. 
o The past due balance exceeds the high credit and credit limit, which is an anomaly requiring verification. 
3. Comments Conflict : o TransUnion : " Charged off as bad debt. Dispute resolved ; reported by grantor. '' o XXXX : " Unpaid balance reported as a loss by the credit grantor. '' o XXXX : " CONSUMER STATEMENT ITEM IN DISPUTE BY CONSUMER. '' o These comments reflect inconsistent handling of disputes and charge-offs. 

4. Date Discrepancies : o Date Last Active : TransUnion : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Date of Last Payment : TransUnion and XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o These inconsistencies should be clarified and corrected. 
5. Payment History Errors : o The Two-Year Payment History shows " CO '' ( Charge Off ) consistently across all bureaus. If this account was disputed or resolved, these entries should reflect the resolution accurately. 


XXXX  XXXX XXXX Inaccuracies and Issues 1. Balance vs. Credit Limit Conflict : o Balance : {$4100.00} ( TransUnion and XXXX ). 
o Credit Limit : {$3700.00} ( all bureaus ). 
o The balance exceeds the credit limit, which is an anomaly that needs verification. 
2. Comments Discrepancies : o TransUnion : " Charged off as bad debt. Dispute resolved : reported by grantor. '' o XXXX : " Account was in dispute, now resolved - reported by subscriber. '' o XXXX : " CONSUMER STATEMENT ITEM IN DISPUTE BY CONSUMER. '' o Comments lack consistency regarding the resolution status and how the dispute was handled. 
XXXX. Date Discrepancies : o Date Last Active : TransUnion : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Date of Last Payment : TransUnion : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o There is a slight discrepancy in the " Date Last Active '' between TransUnion and XXXX. 
4. Future Reporting Dates : o Last Reported : TransUnion : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Reporting future dates violates the FCRA 's accuracy and timeliness requirements.

5. Payment History Inconsistencies : o The Two-Year Payment History shows continuous " CO '' ( Charge Off ) statuses. If the account dispute was resolved, these entries should reflect the resolution XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Key Inaccuracies and Issues : 1. Balance Exceeding Credit Limit : o Balance : {$7800.00}.

o Credit Limit : {$7100.00}. 
o The balance exceeds the credit limit, which is inconsistent with standard account reporting practices and needs verification. 
2. Comments Discrepancies : o TransUnion : " Charged off as bad debt. Account information disputed by consumer, meets FCRA requirements. '' o XXXX : " Customer disputed account - reported by subscriber. Unpaid balance reported as a loss by the credit grantor. '' o XXXX : " CONSUMER STATEMENT ITEM IN DISPUTE BY CONSUMER. '' o These comments vary significantly and do not provide a clear resolution status. 
3. Future Reporting Dates : o Last Reported : TransUnion : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Reporting future dates violates the FCRA 's accuracy requirements.

4. Date Discrepancies : o Date Last Active : TransUnion : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Date of Last Payment : All bureaus : XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Discrepancies in the " Date Last Active '' should be clarified. 
5. Payment History Errors : o The Two-Year Payment History shows " CO '' ( Charge Off ) consistently for all months. If the account was disputed or resolved, the history should reflect this. 


1. Verification Requirement ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ) : - The FCRA mandates that all disputed information be verified within 30 days of a consumers dispute. If the information can not be verified, it must be corrected or deleted.

2. Obligation of Accuracy ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ) : - Consumer reporting agencies must ensure maximum possible accuracy of the information in consumer reports. The inaccurate or unverifiable information regarding the charge-off account violates this requirement.

3. Re-Aging of Debt ( 15 U.S.C. 1681c ) : - The FCRA prohibits re-aging of old debt. If the date of first delinquency is inaccurately reported, the charge-off may appear on my credit report longer than the allowed 7 years.

4. Validation of Debt ( Fair Debt Collection Practices Act, 15 U.S.C. 1692g ) : - Under the FDCPA, if the debt is being collected by a third party, I have the right to request validation of the debt, including proof of ownership and the amount owed. If the creditor or collection agency can not validate the debt, it must be removed.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative: To whom it may concern : According to the FCRA Section 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681 ( l ) and the accepted STANDARD of metro 2 data field reporting, I have the right to dispute any information on my credit report that I believe is not correct. When it comes to my credit report, I reserve the right to dispute any information that I deem to be inaccurate. I won't stand for any misinformation being associated with my name and financial history.If there's something on my credit report that doesn't seem right, you can bet that I'll be taking action to get it removed.I can not recognize or accept the allegation of delinquency without factual proof. There must be some sort of evidence to back up the claim. Otherwise, I can not and will not recognize or accept the allegation.According to federal and state law, you must report any allegations with the greatest compliance and accuracy possible.You should not report any claims that you know or should know are not in compliance with regulations and the law. If you do report such claims, you could be subject to fines or other penalties. Furthermore, reporting claims that you know are not in compliance could damage the reputation of your company.I am writing to inform you that you need to make sure all your claims are factual and certified before reporting them. This is required by the Metro 2 reporting standard. I request that you provide evidence to support the existence of the account and evidence that the account was used for a permissible purpose. Please provide any documents or records you may have that can help corroborate the account and its permissible purpose.I am giving you 30 days to investigate the matter and determine whether it is still being reported accurately and in compliance with regulations. If it is not, I want it removed from the report.I hereby authorize you to take whatever steps are necessary to correct my credit. Please send me physical proof of any actions taken on my behalf. I appreciate your help in making sure my credit is in good standing.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute inaccurate late payment entries on my credit report regarding my account with XXXX XXXX  ( Account # XXXX ). These late payments appear to be reported in error, as the account is marked as Current across all bureaus and there is no valid evidence to support these entries. This is a violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and my rights as a consumer. 
Details of Dispute : Account Name : XXXX XXXX  Account Number : XXXX Disputed Late Payment Entries : o TransUnion XXXX XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX With discrepancies o XXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX With discrepancies o XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX With Discrepancies Additional Inaccuracies and Issues XXXX. XXXX XXXX Dates : o TransUnion and XXXX : Last Reported is XX/XX/XXXX. 
o XXXX : Last Reported is XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Reporting dates in the future violates the FCRA 's accuracy and timeliness requirements. 
XXXX. Payment History Discrepancies : o TransUnion and XXXX : Show several months with " XXXX late payments ''. 
o XXXX : Shows no similar late payment entries. 
o If the account is listed as " Current, '' there should be no late payments reported. 

XXXX. Comments Conflicts : o TransUnion and XXXX : State " Consumer Statement Item in Dispute by Consumer. '' o XXXX : States " Consumer disputes - reinvestigation in progress. '' o These conflicting comments indicate unresolved or inconsistent handling of disputes. 
XXXX. Number of Months ( Terms ) Inconsistency : o TransUnion and XXXX : Show 564 months. 
o XXXX : Shows 0 months, which is inaccurate or incomplete. 
XXXX. High Credit vs. Balance : o Balance : {$480000.00}.

o High Credit : {$500000.00}. 
o The balance does not exceed the high credit, but it requires proper documentation to ensure accuracy. 
XXXX. Date Discrepancies : o Date Last Active : TransUnion : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : Missing. 
o Date of Last Payment : TransUnion and XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : Missing. 



Violation of Consumer Protection Laws : Violations of 15 U.S.C. 1681 ( FCRA ) : 1. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies are required to ensure maximum possible accuracy of consumer information. Reporting late payments on a current account violates this standard.

2. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : I have the right to dispute any inaccurate information on my credit report. The bureau must conduct a reasonable reinvestigation to verify its accuracy.

3. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) : If the disputed information can not be verified as accurate, it must be promptly deleted or corrected.

4. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : Information furnishers, such as creditors, are prohibited from knowingly reporting inaccurate information.

5. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( b ) : Upon receiving notice of a dispute, the furnisher must investigate, review relevant information, and report its findings to the credit bureaus.

FCRA Section 607 ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies are required to ensure maximum possible accuracy when reporting consumer information. The reporting of late payments on a current account fails to meet this standard.

FCRA Section 611 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : I have the right to dispute any inaccurate information on my credit report and demand a thorough reinvestigation.

FCRA Section 611 ( a ) ( 5 ) : If the information can not be verified as accurate, it must be deleted promptly.

CFPB Standards : The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau mandates that credit bureaus and furnishers maintain fair and accurate reporting practices.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I have an ongoing issue with TransUnion 's reporting of the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX account ( Account Number : XXXX ) on my credit report. TransUnion has failed to comply with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ), which requires credit reporting agencies to ensure maximum possible accuracy. 

The account contains incomplete and inconsistent information, including missing balance details, payment terms, and contradictory payment history. For example, the account shows late payments ( XX/XX/XXXX : 60 days past due ; XX/XX/XXXX : 30 days past due ) despite being listed as " Paid, Closed. '' These inaccuracies render the account unverifiable and misleading. 

I filed multiple disputes with TransUnion, including the following dispute reports : Report Number : XXXX ( XX/XX/XXXX ) Report Number : XXXX ( XX/XX/XXXX ) Report Number : XXXX ( XX/XX/XXXX ) Report Number : XXXX ( XX/XX/XXXX ) Report Number : XXXX ( XX/XX/XXXX ) Report Number : XXXX ( XX/XX/XXXX ) Despite these efforts, TransUnion has failed to correct the errors or provide verification of the account 's accuracy. Their responses have been generic and inadequate, failing to address the specific inaccuracies I identified. 

TransUnion has also violated 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ), which requires them to conduct a reasonable reinvestigation of disputed information. They continue to report the same incomplete and inconsistent data, which has caused harm to my creditworthiness, including credit denials, higher financial costs, and emotional distress. 

I request that the CFPB take immediate action to ensure TransUnion complies with the FCRA by : Permanently deleting the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX account from my credit report due to its unverifiable and inaccurate nature. 
Conducting a comprehensive audit of their procedures to ensure compliance with 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ). 
Providing a written explanation of how they verified the account or why they failed to correct it.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to dispute the inaccurate reporting of a XXXX  item ( # XXXX ) on my credit report. This item was disputed and correctly deleted and removed from the systems of the original data furnisher, XXXX on XX/XX/year> as confirmed by correspondence in my possession ( See Attachment ). Despite this, your agency has claimed the item as verified upon re-investigation, thereby validating inaccurate and misleading information. 
In addition to this violation, I have not provided permissible purpose as required under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1681b ) for this item to be reported on my consumer report. This is a clear breach of my consumer rights, and the continued reporting of this item constitutes unauthorized and unlawful activity.

Under the FCRA, you are obligated to : 1. Ensure the maximum possible accuracy of the information you report ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ).

2. Conduct a reasonable investigation into disputes ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ).

3. Only report information for which a permissible purpose exists ( 15 U.S.C. 1681b ).

Your failure to comply with these legal requirements has caused significant harm to my creditworthiness, impacting me and my family financially. 



I demand the following actions : XXXX. XXXX deletion of the inaccurate XXXX  item ( # XXXX ) from my credit report.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Formal Dispute for Aggravated Identity Theft - Request for Immediate Account Removal I am writing to dispute an account on my file that is the result of aggravated identity theft. The name and address associated with this account do not match the information on file with the credit bureaus or my personal records. I believe this account was fraudulently opened in my name by an unauthorized individual.

I have taken immediate steps to address this matter, including : Applicable Laws Supporting My Request for Account Removal Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), Section 605B ( 15 U.S.C. 1681c-2 ) : Under the FCRA, you are required to block fraudulent information resulting from identity theft from appearing on my credit file within four business days of receiving the following documentation : A copy of my identity theft report.

Proof of my identity.

A written statement regarding the fraudulent account.

Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act ( 18 U.S.C. 1028A ) : Aggravated identity theft is a federal crime, and the law requires that businesses take action to assist victims in clearing fraudulent accounts.

Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), Section 805 ( b ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1692c ( b ) ) : Debt collectors are prohibited from pursuing debts resulting from identity theft.

FACTA Identity Theft Red Flags Rule ( Fair and Accurate Credit Transactions Act ) : Financial institutions and creditors are required to take proactive measures when identity theft indicators, such as mismatched name and address information, are present.

Requested Actions Immediately investigate and remove the fraudulent account from my records.

Provide written confirmation of the removal and resolution within 30 days.

Notify any third parties who were provided the fraudulent information to correct their records.

Enclosures : Copy of my FTC Identity Theft Report.

Copy of the police report.

Proof of my identity ( e.g., drivers license, utility bill, or Social Security card ).

Additional supporting documents as required.

This incident has caused undue stress and inconvenience.

I have filed file a complaint with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and consider further legal action.

Please contact me at if you require any further information.

My identity has been stolen you are hereby put on notice.

Aggravated Identity Theft pursuant to 18 U.S.C. 1028A.

( 1 ) In general.

Whoever, during and in relation to any felony violation enumerated in subsection ( c ), knowingly transfers, possesses, or uses, without lawful authority, a means of identification of another person shall, in addition to the punishment provided for such felony, be sentenced to a term of imprisonment of 2 years.

An identification of me has been used without my permission to open several accounts that have damaged my reputation and damaged my mode of living because you furnished a consumer report without my written permission as stated by Federal Law 15 USC 1681b Permissible purpose of consumer reports IN GENERAL Subject to subsection ( c ) any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report under the following circumstances and no other : ( 2 ) In accordance with the written instructions of the consumer to whom it relates. 


YOU TRANSUNION, XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX have aided this Fraud by reporting these accounts and are ACTIVELY PARTICIPATING IN AGGRAVATED IDENTITY THEFT.

Congress states 15 USC 1681 Fair Credit Reporting Act ( a ) Accuracy and fairness of credit reports ( 4 ) There is a need to insure that consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and a respect for the consumers right to privacy.

List of Accounts : Charge -Off : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX {$21000.00} Date opened XX/XX/year> Charge Off - By Definition The IRS Clearly says a Cancelled debt or Charge off is Income. The reporting of this

account as a debt is inaccurate. 15 USC 1681 s-2 Says ( XXXX, TRANSUNION, XXXX, XXXX XXXX ) is a furnisher of information to / and/ or a consumer reporting agency.

You ARE PROHIBITED BY LAW to furnish and/or report inaccurate information. I demand you to Cease and Desist the reporting of incorrect/ inaccurate information immediately.

15 USC 1681 s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate You are hereby put on NOTICE that you are furnishing incorrect inaccurate information and further/knowingly participating in Aggravated Identity Theft Pursuant 15 U.S. Code 1681c2 - Block of information resulting from identity theft.

Except as otherwise provided in this section, a consumer reporting agency shall block the reporting of any information in the file of a consumer that the consumer identifies as information that resulted from an alleged identity theft, not later than 4 business days after the date of receipt by such agency of ( 1 ) appropriate proof of the identity of the consumer ; ( 2 ) a copy of an identity theft report ; ( 3 ) the identification of such information by the consumer; and ( 4 ) a statement by the consumer that the information is not information relating to any transaction by the consumer.

I have attached all the relevant documents pursuant the above Section of the law.

I demand all the above Fraudulent accounts DELETED immediately.

I Demand an updated copy of my Consumer file reflecting these changes ( 15 USC 1681 c-1 2 Access to free reports ) ( 2 ) Access to free reports In any case in which a consumer reporting agency includes a fraud alert in the file of a consumer pursuant to this subsection, the consumer reporting agency shall ( A ) disclose to the consumer that the consumer may request a free copy of the file of the consumer pursuant to section 1681j ( d ) of this title ;

Consumer complaint narrative:
XX/XX/XXXX Subject : Formal Complaint Regarding Inaccurate Late Payments on XXXX XXXX Account Dear CFPB, I am writing to formally dispute inaccurate late payments reported on my credit file for the XXXX XXXX account ( Account Number : XXXX ). These late payments, specifically a 30-day late payment for XX/XX/XXXX and a 60-day late payment for XX/XX/XXXX, are erroneous and do not reflect my actual payment history. 
Nature of the Complaint : Inaccurate Reporting : The listed late payments are incorrect as I have consistently made my payments on time through autopay. 
Violation of FCRA ( 15 USC 1681i and 1681s-2 ) : Credit reporting agencies and furnishers are required to ensure maximum accuracy in consumer files. The failure to correct these inaccuracies constitutes noncompliance with federal law. 
Violation of FDCPA ( 15 USC 1692e ) : Reporting incorrect information about payments may qualify as deceptive or misleading practices under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act.

Violation of TILA ( 15 USC 1601 ) : The Truth in Lending Act mandates accurate reporting of credit terms and histories. 
Civil Liability Under FCRA ( 15 USC 1681n and 1681o ) : Noncompliance with these provisions subjects the responsible parties to legal liabilities, including actual damages, punitive damages, and legal fees. 
Summary of Discrepancies TransUnion : Reported 30-day late payment for XX/XX/XXXX and 60-day late payment for XX/XX/XXXX. 
These are incorrect as the account history reflects consistent payments with no delinquencies. 
Requested Resolution : I request the following : Conduct a thorough investigation into the discrepancies on this account. 
Remove the inaccurate late payment entries from my credit file. 
Provide written confirmation of the corrections within 30 days, as required under 15 USC 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ). 
Failure to comply with this request may result in further actions to enforce my rights as a consumer under federal law. Attached, you will find supporting documentation, including payment records and statements, to substantiate my claim. 
Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

I am writing regarding accounts that has been charged offs are listed on my credit report. The details of the account are as follows : Account Name : XXXX  Account Number : XXXX Account Name : XXXX  Account Number : XXXX Dispute Summary : Under 15 U.S.C. 1601, 15 U.S.C. 1666, and 15 U.S.C. 1692c ( c ), I am exercising my rights to dispute this account and request specific documentation regarding the status of this debt.

Request for 1099-C Form : These accounts has been charged off and the debt canceled or forgiven, I am requesting a copy of the 1099-C Cancellation of Debt form that was not issued to me and filed with the Internal Revenue Service ( IRS ) . The issuance of a 1099-C form confirms that the creditor has discharged the debt and may have considered it as income for tax purposes.

Again, neither creditor 1099-C form has not been issued, I request written confirmation that the debt has not been canceled and clarification of the charge-off status. 

Legal Basis for Request : 15 U.S.C. 1601 ( Truth in Lending Act ) : Ensures transparency in the reporting of financial obligations. 
15 U.S.C. 1666 ( Fair Credit Billing Act ) : Entitles consumers to dispute errors in billing and request clarification of account details. 
15 U.S.C. 1692c ( c ) ( Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ) : Provides consumers the right to request cessation of collection activities and validation of disputed debts. 

Additional Requests : Any documents evidencing the transfer or sale of the debt to a third party, if applicable. 
Verification of the charge-off date and the amount at the time of charge-off. 
If the requested documentation, including the 1099-C form, can not be provided, I demand that the account be removed from my credit report as it would constitute a violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) due to inaccurate or incomplete reporting. 

I kindly ask for a response within 30 days of receiving this letter. Please send all correspondence to the address listed above. 

Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I have an ongoing issue with TransUnion 's reporting of the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX account ( Account Number : XXXX ) on my credit report. TransUnion has failed to comply with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ), which requires credit reporting agencies to ensure maximum possible accuracy. 

The account contains incomplete and inconsistent information, including missing balance details, payment terms, and contradictory payment history. For example, the account shows late payments ( XX/XX/XXXX : 60 days past due ; XX/XX/XXXX : 30 days past due ) despite being listed as " Paid, Closed. '' These inaccuracies render the account unverifiable and misleading. 

I filed multiple disputes with TransUnion, including the following dispute reports : Report Number : XXXX ( XX/XX/XXXX ) Report Number : XXXX ( XX/XX/XXXX ) Report Number : XXXX ( XX/XX/XXXX ) Report Number : XXXX ( XX/XX/XXXX ) Report Number : XXXX ( XX/XX/XXXX ) Report Number : XXXX ( XX/XX/XXXX ) Despite these efforts, TransUnion has failed to correct the errors or provide verification of the account 's accuracy. Their responses have been generic and inadequate, failing to address the specific inaccuracies I identified. 

TransUnion has also violated 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ), which requires them to conduct a reasonable reinvestigation of disputed information. They continue to report the same incomplete and inconsistent data, which has caused harm to my creditworthiness, including credit denials, higher financial costs, and emotional distress. 

I request that the CFPB take immediate action to ensure TransUnion complies with the FCRA by : Permanently deleting the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX account from my credit report due to its unverifiable and inaccurate nature. 
Conducting a comprehensive audit of their procedures to ensure compliance with 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ). 
Providing a written explanation of how they verified the account or why they failed to correct it.

Under 15 USC 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) subject to subsection ( f ) and except as provided in subsection ( g ), If the completeness or accuracy of any item of information contained in a consumer 's file at a consumer reporting agency is disputed by the consumer and the consumer notifies the agency directly or indirectly through a reseller, of such dispute, the agency shall, free of charge, conduct a reasonable reinvestigation to determine whether the disputed information is inaccurate and record the current status of the disputed information, or delete the item from the file in accordance with paragraph ( 5 ), before the end of the 30-day period beginning on the date on which the agency receives the notice of the dispute from the consumer or reseller.
