Product: Money transfer, virtual currency, or money service
Consumer complaint narrative:
I opened a Robinhood account in early XXXX XXXX XXXX. I deposited cash ( around {$10000.00} ) from my checking account and a Savings account, then I started making stock and crypto trades normally. On XX/XX/XXXX, I suddenly received a message within the Robinhood app " Your account is temporarily restricted. Submit documents to verify your info so we can resolve your restrictions. 
Submit documents '' This is unusual, as I have not been asked for this information from other brokers where I have accounts, but I comply. 

The other documents are banks statements from the 2 banks I made transfers from and they want a selfie. I upload the selfie. They have my driver 's license on file. Somehow, they have a way to retrieve the bank statements because there isn't an option to upload them but they are " checked '' as accepted. I submit the info and they said : " Weve received your documents Well review your documents and notify you about your account restrictions by XX/XX/XXXX. '' I'm already skeptical about this as they haven't really taken the bank statements, but I wait until the next day. 

The following day the restricted message is still in the app with the same messages to submit the documents. I go through that process again and this time it says : " Well review your documents and notify you about your account restrictions by XX/XX/XXXX. '' At this point, I'm starting to lose money because I can't make any moves in my account. 

This process continues up until today, XX/XX/year>. The latest message is : " Well review your documents and notify you about your account restrictions by XX/XX/XXXX. '' I'm starting to think Robinhood has stolen my money. 

I reached out to support several times through the app. You can't directly chat with anyone or call anyone about this. Eventually I got an email from support saying " Your account is restricted due to a recent review. We'll contact you by phone and email soon to request any information needed to complete your review. '' There's no explanation of why they did this with no urgency to resolve it and I'm losing money. Isn't it illegal to highjack someone's funds like this?

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally file a complaint regarding inaccurate and adverse information that has been reported on my credit report. Despite my efforts to resolve this matter with the consumer reporting agencies, XXXX, XXXX, and TransUnion. My private information continues to appear on my credit file in violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). I am seeking your assistance in rectifying this issue. 
1. Violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) Under 15 U.S.C. 1681b and 15 U.S.C. 1681a, consumer reporting agencies are prohibited from furnishing information without the express consent of the consumer. I have not given written consent for the reporting of the account in question, nor have I authorized the financial institution that furnished this information to report it to the credit bureaus. In fact, I have revoked any such consent, as outlined below.

2. Revocation of Consent As of the date of this letter, I am formally revoking any and all consent, whether implied or explicit, to the furnishing of this information to the credit reporting agencies. I have not provided any written consent for this account to be reported. This revocation is in full accordance with 15 U.S.C. 1681b ( a ) ( 2 ), which requires written consent from the consumer for information to be furnished to a consumer reporting agency. As such, I request that this information be immediately removed from my credit report.

3. Failure to Inform Me of My Rights Furthermore, the furnisher of the information,, has never informed me of my right to exercise my non-disclosure option as required under 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ). This failure to inform me of my rights violates the obligations placed upon them by the Fair Credit Reporting Act. I was not notified that I could object to or limit the disclosure of this account to consumer reporting agencies, as mandated under 12 CFR 1016.7.

4. Adverse Information Continues to Be Reported Without Consent Despite my objections and revocation of consent, the adverse account information has continued to be reported by the credit bureaus, which constitutes a further violation of the FCRA. As stated in 15 U.S.C. 1681 Section 602, " There is a need to ensure that consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and a respect for the consumers right to privacy. '' The continued reporting of this account, despite the lack of my consent, represents a failure to uphold these responsibilities.

5. Request for Immediate Action I made an attempt to resolve this issue directly by sending written notice of these issues to XXXX, XXXX, and TransUnion on XX/XX/scrub>XXXX However, the information has not been removed. As such, I am now seeking the assistance of the CFPB to rectify this matter.In 15 USC 1681C ( a ) ( 5 ) states '' Except as authorized under subsection ( b ), no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years. '' This account is an adverse item they are reporting without my permission.

I have attached copies of all relevant documentation, including some of my correspondence with the credit reporting agencies, as well as any relevant account details. I look forward to your investigation and resolution of this matter.

Thank you for your time and attention to this important issue. 

Best wishes, Without Prejudice XXXX XXXX XXXX, Authorized Rep All Rights Reserved

Recently, I did an investigation on my credit report and found several items on there to be inaccurate. 

Under 15 U.S. Code 1681e ( b ) Accuracy of report Whenever a consumer reporting agency generates a consumer report, it must follow reasonable procedures to ensure the maximum possible accuracy of the information related to the individual to whom the report pertains.

15 U.S. Code 1681i ( 5 ) Treatment of inaccurate or unverifiable information ( A ) In general if, following a reinvestigation under paragraph ( 1 ) of any disputed information by a consumer, an item is determined to be inaccurate, incomplete, or unverifiable, the consumer reporting agency must ( i ) promptly delete the disputed item from the consumer 's file, or appropriately modify the information based on the reinvestigation results; and ( ii ) promptly inform the furnisher of the information that the item has been modified or deleted from the consumer 's file. 

Please remove the following items from my credit report immediately : Professional Debt Me U S Dept of EDXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX All Debt Solutions ComenityBank/Victoria

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
XX/XX/XXXX Subject : Dispute of Inaccurate Late Payments on Credit Report Dear CFPB, I am submitting this complaint regarding inaccurate late payments that are reported on my credit file maintained by Equifax. I believe these late payments are erroneous and do not accurately reflect my payment history. 
Nature of the Complaint : Inaccurate Reporting : The late payments listed on my credit report for XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX are inaccurate. My payment history reflects consistent on-time payments, and I have been enrolled in autopay for this account. 
Violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : The inaccurate reporting of these late payments violates my rights under the FCRA ( 15 USC 1666 ( b ) ), as they misrepresent my creditworthiness.

Potential Violation of Fair Debt Collections Practices Act ( FDCPA ) : The reporting of false late payments may also constitute a violation of the FDCPA, which protects consumers from misrepresentation regarding their accounts.

Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) : I assert that the reporting practices violate the TILA, which mandates accurate reporting of credit information.

Additionally, the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically sections 15 U.S. Code 1681i and 15 U.S. Code 1681s-2, mandates that credit reporting agencies and information furnishers correct any inaccurate or incomplete information in credit reports and ensure the maximum accuracy of information contained in consumer files.

Summary of Errors and Discrepancies : The account reflects late payments in XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX, which are inaccurate. 
Payment history should reflect 100 % on-time payments. 
The discrepancies misrepresent my creditworthiness and violate consumer protection laws. 
Requested Resolution : I request that Equifax conduct a thorough investigation into this matter and remove the inaccurate late payments from my credit report. I ask that all such entries be updated to reflect my true payment history of 100 % on-time payments. 
I expect to receive written documentation confirming the removal of these entries within 30 days of this complaint submission. Failure to resolve this issue may lead to further action to protect my rights as a consumer. 
Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

And according to 15 USC 1681 5 they are suppose to do this ( 5 ) Treatment of inaccurate or unverifiable information ( A ) In generallf, after any reinvestigation under paragraph ( 1 ) of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency shall ( i ) promptly delete that item of information from the file of the consumer, or modify that item of information, as appropriate, based on the results of the reinvestigation; and ( ii ) promptly notify the furnisher of that information that the information has been modified or deleted from the file of the consumer.

and according to 15 USC 1681s-2 they are suppose to not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  Equifax Dispute Resolution Team XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Subject : Formal Demand for Deletion of Inaccurate Credit Report Information Dear Equifax Dispute Resolution Team , This letter serves as a formal demand to delete the inaccurate information on my credit report immediately, pursuant to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and applicable Pennsylvania state laws. Your failure to provide a satisfactory resolution to my recent CFPB complaint highlights significant compliance issues. The disputed items remain factually incorrect, unverifiable, or incomplete and must be removed without further delay. 

The specific accounts in question include : XXXX XXXX XXXX ( Account Number : XXXX ) Your response to my complaint states updates were made to fields such as Scheduled Payment, Past Due, and Account History. However, these updates are inconsistent with the accounts actual payment history and status. The ongoing reporting of charge-offs across multiple months is not only inaccurate but also misleading, violating FCRA 1681e ( b ), which requires consumer reporting agencies to ensure maximum possible accuracy. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX ) You claim this account is accurately reported, yet discrepancies persist in the historical account balances, payment schedule, and charge-off date. The reported information does not align with the data provided by the furnisher or the billing records I hold, rendering it unverifiable and noncompliant with FCRA 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) ( A ).

Legal Basis for My Demands Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 U.S.C. 1681 ) : Under the FCRA, you are obligated to delete unverifiable or inaccurate information within 30 days of a dispute. Failure to comply subjects your agency to statutory damages, actual damages, and legal action.

Pennsylvania Unfair Trade Practices and Consumer Protection Law ( 73 P.S. 201-1 ) : The ongoing misrepresentation of my financial obligations violates Pennsylvania state law, exposing your agency to additional liability.

My Demands I demand that the following actions be taken immediately : Delete the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX accounts from my credit report due to their inaccuracies and unverifiable nature. 

Provide written confirmation that these items have been removed within 15 days of receiving this letter. 

Deliver a detailed explanation of the investigative process and specific evidence used to justify any continued reporting of these items if you refuse deletion. 

Consequences of Non-Compliance Failure to delete these items or provide sufficient evidence of their accuracy will result in : Filing of complaints with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and the Pennsylvania Attorney Generals Office. 
Pursuit of legal remedies for violations of the FCRA and Pennsylvania state law, including claims for statutory and punitive damages. 

Escalation to federal and state oversight authorities to audit your compliance procedures. 

I will not tolerate further delays or evasions. You are required by law to act promptly and accurately, and I expect full compliance with my demands. If you need additional documentation, you may contact me at the information provided above. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX Enclosures : Credit Report with Highlighted Errors Supporting Billing Records

Consumer complaint narrative:
I have reached out to Equifax in regards to these XXXX account- XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX I have the Equifax reporting number- XXXX -I have explained to them that these accounts are reporting inaccurate and are not reporting the same on neither credit bureau XXXX XXXX, XXXXXXXX XXXX, and self lender all have different late payment, different reporting date for the payments and more. I have reached out to XXXX and they confirmed they are reporting accurate but it is the credit bureaus who reports their information. My accounts with XXXX and XXXX and XXXX each had their own cfpb complaint as they verified correct but are actually wrong. I have documentation from each bureau listing different information. Equifax also did there investigation a whole back and actually verified the correct information,. These accounts need to be removed, XXXX shows a charge off for XXXX XXXXXXXX, it has actually been showing charge off for years. the credit reporting agencies overlooked that multiple times. I was recently denied due to their misleading reports. Charge off are reported once these accounts have more than one charge off.

It has come to my attention that the charge-off is being reported month after month on my payment history, which is incorrect. According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), negativeinformation such as a charge-off should only be reported once, corresponding to the date it was charged off. The FCRA requires that credit reporting agencies ensure the accuracy of the information they report ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ). Repeatedly reporting the charge-off each month results in a misleading and inaccurate credit report, which has significantly harmed my credit score. Additionally, the statute of limitations for reporting a charge-off is seven years from the date of the first delinquency that led to the charge-off ( 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) ( 4 ) ). Continuously reporting this charge-off as a new event each month does not reset the statute of limitations and is improper. Im also requesting payment for damages I have received due to the inaccurate reporting an misleading reports from these creditors. Under 15 U.S. Code 1681n - Civil liability for willful noncompliance-If any credit reporting agency or furnisher willfully fails to comply with the terms of the FCRA, it is liable to the consumer for actual damages or statutory damages between {$100.00} and {$1000.00}, punitive damages, and the consumers reasonable attorneys fees and costs.

If a furnisher or credit reporting agency negligently fails to comply with the terms of the FCRA, it is liable to the consumer for actual damages and the consumers reasonable gattorneys fees and costs.

Below I will attach the supporting documents showing there information is reporting different on all three credit bureaus. an also will show how the charge off should report under fcra. I request these accounts to be removed as the creditor failed to comply with fcra laws a verified and confirmed they are reporting accurate when they are not.

I have dispute with each creditor individually with cfpb and they airfield they were reporting information an its still wrong as I provided the information below. These accounts need to be removed if not removed can pay for the damagers for non compliance. You guys have modified messed up my credit score and more each time you all willingly knowing put wrong information on my report. this needs to be removed before I take further legal action an report to other government for complaints on violating fcra laws for the consumers Below will list each bureaus and how those account report different information and wrong information.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally file a complaint regarding inaccurate and adverse information that has been reported on my credit report. Despite my efforts to resolve this matter with the consumer reporting agencies, Equifax, XXXX, and XXXX. My private information continues to appear on my credit file in violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). I am seeking your assistance in rectifying this issue.

1. Violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) Under 15 U.S.C. 1681b and 15 U.S.C. 1681a, consumer reporting agencies are prohibited from furnishing information without the express consent of the consumer. I have not given written consent for the reporting of the account in question, nor have I authorized the financial institution that furnished this information to report it to the credit bureaus. In fact, I have revoked any such consent, as outlined below.

2. Revocation of Consent As of the date of this letter, I am formally revoking any and all consent, whether implied or explicit, to the furnishing of this information to the credit reporting agencies. I have not provided any written consent for this account to be reported. This revocation is in full accordance with 15 U.S.C. 1681b ( a ) ( 2 ), which requires written consent from the consumer for information to be furnished to a consumer reporting agency. As such, I request that this information be immediately removed from my credit report.

3. Failure to Inform Me of My Rights Furthermore, the furnisher of the information,, has never informed me of my right to exercise my non-disclosure option as required under 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ). This failure to inform me of my rights violates the obligations placed upon them by the Fair Credit Reporting Act. I was not notified that I could object to or limit the disclosure of this account to consumer reporting agencies, as mandated under 12 CFR 1016.7.

4. Adverse Information Continues to Be Reported Without Consent Despite my objections and revocation of consent, the adverse account information has continued to be reported by the credit bureaus, which constitutes a further violation of the FCRA. As stated in 15 U.S.C. 1681 Section 602, " There is a need to ensure that consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and a respect for the consumers right to privacy. '' The continued reporting of this account, despite the lack of my consent, represents a failure to uphold these responsibilities.

5. Request for Immediate Action I made an attempt to resolve this issue directly by sending written notice of these issues to Equifax, XXXX, and XXXX on XXXX However, the information has not been removed. As such, I am now seeking the assistance of the CFPB to rectify this matter.In 15 USC 1681C ( a ) ( 5 ) states '' Except as authorized under subsection ( b ), no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years. '' This account is an adverse item they are reporting without my permission.

I have attached copies of all relevant documentation, including some of my correspondence with the credit reporting agencies, as well as any relevant account details. I look forward to your investigation and resolution of this matter. 

Thank you for your time and attention to this important issue. 

Best wishes, Without Prejudice XXXX XXXX XXXX, Authorized Rep All Rights Reserved

Under the FCRA, if disputed items can not be verified, they must be removed from my report. As per 15 U.S. Code 1681n ( Civil Liability for Willful Noncompliance ) and 15 U.S. Code 1681o ( Civil Liability for Negligent Noncompliance ), your agency may be held liable for failing to comply with federal law. Additionally, 15 U.S. Code 1692k holds entities accountable for violations related to debt collection. Any continued failure to address these inaccuracies in a timely manner will result in further legal action.

Collection Accounts Collection accounts listed below is in violation of 15 U.S. Code 1681b ( Permissible Purposes of Consumer Reports ). These must be DELETED in my report immediately.

o XXXX : Shows no similar late payment entries.

o If the account is listed as " Current, '' there should be no late payments reported.

Violation of Consumer Protection Laws : Violations of 15 U.S.C. 1681 ( FCRA ) : 1. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies are required to ensure maximum possible accuracy of consumer information. Reporting late payments on a current account violates this standard.

2. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : I have the right to dispute any inaccurate information on my credit report. The bureau must conduct a reasonable reinvestigation to verify its accuracy.

3. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) : If the disputed information can not be verified as accurate, it must be promptly deleted or corrected.

4. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : Information furnishers, such as creditors, are prohibited from knowingly reporting inaccurate information.

5. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( b ) : Upon receiving notice of a dispute, the furnisher must investigate, review relevant information, and report its findings to the credit bureaus.

FCRA Section 607 ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies are required to ensure maximum possible accuracy when reporting consumer information. The reporting of late payments on a current account fails to meet this standard.

FCRA Section 611 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : I have the right to dispute any inaccurate information on my credit report and demand a thorough reinvestigation.

FCRA Section 611 ( a ) ( 5 ) : If the information can not be verified as accurate, it must be deleted promptly.

CFPB Standards : The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau mandates that credit bureaus and furnishers maintain fair and accurate reporting practices.

Consumer complaint narrative: I did not give anyone authorization or consent to use my personal information. I hereby exercise my legal rights enacted by Congress and The Federal Trade Commission, which explicitly states when a victim of identity-theft disputes a fraudulent account on his/her credit report it shall be honored by all credit bureaus and all fraudulent information should be blocked within 4 days and proper notification shall be given to all data furnishers pursuant to section 605b of The Federal Fair Credit Reporting Act. Failure to comply shall lead to complaints being filed with XXXX with the Attorney General stating your Companys unlawful collection practices, misrepresentation of creditworthiness, defamation of character, and noncompliance to abide by laws enacted by Congress to protect victims of identity-theft whose credit been impacted by acts of fraud. Because I know my rights under THE FAIR CREDIT REPORTING ACT, CONSUMER CREDIT PROTECTION ACT ( CCPA ), and FAIR and ACCURATE CREDIT TRANSACTION ACT of 2003 ( FACTA ) SEC.312. Procedures to enhance the accuracy and integrity of information furnished to consumer reporting agencies. ( b ) duty of furnishers to provide accurate information. Section 623 ( a ) ( 1 ) of THE FAIR CREDIT REPORTING ACT ( 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) is amended ( 1 ) in subparagraph ( A ), by striking knows or consciously avoids knowing the information is inaccurate and inserting knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate, and ( 2 ) by adding at the end of the following : ( D ) DEFINITION For purposes of subparagraph ( A ), the term reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. Therefore, my position is being clearly stated, these accounts do not belong to me, meaning that you are reporting inaccurate account information within my credit file. The fact that these are inaccurate account information means that you, this credit-reporting agency, are reporting incorrect accounts. 1.BARCLAYS ( XXXX ) I am well aware of my rights as a consumer. The Fair Credit Reporting Act requires that you, the credit-reporting agency report accurate and/or correct account information within my credit file. My credit issues are very specific, these accounts and/or items do not belong to me. This means that you are reporting incorrect account information within my credit report. It is this in mind that I request that these listed accounts and items be Blocked and Deleted. According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act FCRA, Section 1681c ( 2 ) Block of information resulting from identity theft. 1.Block. Except as otherwise provided in this section, a consumer reporting shall block the reporting of any information in the file of a consumer that the consumer identifies as information that resulted from alleged identity theft, not later than four ( 4 ) business days. I am requesting full validation such as, original transfer rights to collect, confirmation of legal timeline to report on credit and/or collection procedures, validation of licensing requirements, posted bonding requirements, oversight on monthly payment histories, proper subscriber agreement compliance with credit reporting agencies, and overall compliance with all Fair Credit Reporting Act and Fair Debt Collection Practices Act bylaws as mandated by federal laws. If all of these requirements are not in order, then I have the legal right to request the deletion of this tradeline accordingly. I especially desire compliance under the 84-month timeline for deletion of negative information, with the deletion of the account details altogether. My dispute is quite specific in the exception area posted below : 605. Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
Recently, I did an investigation on my credit report and found several items on there to be inaccurate. 

Under 15 U.S Code 1681e ( b ) Accuracy of report Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report. It shall follow reasonable procedures to assure the maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates.

15 U.S. Code 1691i ( 5 ) Treatment of inaccurate or unverifiable information ( A ) In general if, after any reinvestigation under paragraph ( 1 ) of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency shall ( i ) promptly delete that item of information from the file of the consumer, or modify that item of information as appropriate, based on the results of the investigation; and ( ii ) promptly notify the furnisher of that information that the information has been modified or deleted from the file of the consumer.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative: Reference Accounts : XXXX I am writing to formally dispute inaccurate information on my credit report, pursuant to Section 605B of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681c-2, and request the immediate removal of any fraudulent accounts associated with my name and personal information. In accordance with this law, I have provided the necessary FTC Identity Theft Report to support my claim of fraudulent activity and data breach. I recently discovered that my personal information was compromised as part of a data breach involving Equifax. As a direct result of this breach, I am now facing fraudulent collections accounts on my credit report. The unauthorized use of my personal information has led to these collections being wrongly attributed to me. Under the FCRA, specifically Section 605B, I am entitled to request the removal of these fraudulent accounts from my credit file, as they do not reflect any legitimate debt I owe. 2. Request for Immediate Removal of Fraudulent Information : Under Section 605B of the FCRA, I request that you immediately remove all accounts that were opened fraudulently or are associated with identity theft from my credit report. These accounts were not authorized by me and have been opened as a result of the data breach involving Equifax. I have included a copy of my FTC Identity Theft Report, which details the fraudulent activity and confirms the theft of my personal information. 3. Legal Timeframe for Removal : Under Section 605B of the FCRA, when a consumer submits a valid FTC Identity Theft Report, credit reporting agencies must take action to investigate and remove fraudulent accounts within 4 business days. Therefore, I request that you immediately remove these fraudulent accounts from my credit report and correct the inaccuracies. Failure to comply with this requirement will leave me no choice but to pursue further legal actions, including filing complaints with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ). 4. Failure to Verify Fraudulent Accounts : As per 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ), when a consumer disputes information on their credit report, the credit bureaus must conduct a reasonable investigation into the disputed items. However, I have reason to believe that the fraudulent accounts, stemming from the data breach, have not been properly investigated or removed. Despite my prior dispute, these accounts remain on my credit report, which is causing severe damage to my credit score. 5. Request for Removal Due to Inaccuracy or Fraud : As these accounts are the result of identity theft and a data breach, I am requesting that you immediately remove them from my credit file in accordance with the FCRA. Under 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ), if information can not be verified or is found to be inaccurate or incomplete, it must be deleted. This includes accounts opened fraudulently due to a data breach. 6. FTC Report Submission : Enclosed with this letter is a copy of my FTC Identity Theft Report, which I filed to support my claim. According to the FCRA and guidelines of the Federal Trade Commission, this report serves as evidence that I have been a victim of identity theft and data breach, and it should be sufficient for the removal of fraudulent accounts from my credit report. I kindly ask that you complete your investigation and remove the fraudulent accounts from my credit report within 4 business days, as required by law. If you do not comply with the FCRA, I will escalate the matter by filing a formal complaint with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and may consider pursuing further legal action. Please provide written confirmation that these fraudulent accounts have been removed and that my credit report has been updated to reflect the accurate information. Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I look forward to your timely response.

15 U.S.C 1681 section 602 A. States I have the right to privacy.

15 U.S.C 1681 Section 604 A Section 2 : It also states a consumer reporting agency can not furnish a account without my written instructions 15 U.S.C 1681c. ( a ) ( 5 ) Section States : no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years.

15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I recently conducted a review of my credit report and found several items that have caused me significant distress. These items appear to be unverifiable, inaccurate, and questionable. Your agency has failed to ensure the accuracy of the information as required under 15 U.S. Code 1681e ( b ) Accuracy of Reports. This statute mandates that consumer reporting agencies must follow reasonable procedures to ensure the maximum possible accuracy of the information they report.

Furthermore, under 15 U.S. Code 1681i ( 5 ) Treatment of Inaccurate or Unverifiable Information, you are required to promptly delete or modify any information found to be inaccurate, incomplete, or unverifiable during a reinvestigation. If you are unable to provide me with verifiable proof of the accuracy of the disputed items within 15 days of your investigation, these accounts and the related information must be removed from my credit report. 

Additionally, under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), I do not recognize any of the alleged creditors or debt collectors. I have never entered into a valid contract with any of these entities, nor have I engaged in any transactions with them. As such, these accounts are fraudulent and and inaccurate information. 

Moreover, under the Fair Credit Billing Act, my right to privacy has been violated, and this breach infringes upon my rights as outlined in The Privacy Act of XXXX  Removing the inaccurate and fraudulent information from my credit report will help restore my privacy and prevent further violations.

Consumer complaint narrative: In XXXX, while reviewing My consumer credit report, I noticed an several unauthorized accounts. On XX/XX/scrub>XXXX XXXX XXXX I provided XXXX notice of these unauthorized accounts. In said notice, I requested the following information : " Provide all of the following information and submit the appropriate forms and paperwork back to Me along with the Affidavit signed in accordance with 28 United States Code Section 1746 within thirty days from the date of your receipt of this request for validation and proof of claim : i. Alleged Name and Address of Creditor : ii. Name on File of alleged debtor : iii. Alleged Account Number : iv. Amount of alleged debt : v. Date that this alleged debt became payable : vi. Date of original charge off or delinquency : vii. Amount paid if debt was purchased : viii. Please attach a copy of any signed agreement debtor has made with debt collector, or other verifiable proof that debtor has a contractual obligation to pay debt collector ; ix. Furnish a copy of the original promissory note/agreement redacting My social security number to prevent identity theft and state that your client named above is the holder in due course of the note agreement and will produce the original for My own and a judges inspection should there be a trial to contest these matters ; x. Produce the account and general ledger statement showing the full accounting of the alleged obligation that you are now attempting to collect ; xi. Identify by name and address all persons, corporations, associations, or any other parties having an interest in legal proceedings regarding the alleged debt ; xii. Verify as a third party debt collector, you have not purchased evidence of the alleged debt and are proceeding with collection activity in the name of the original maker of the note ; xiii. Verify you know and understand that certain clauses in a contract of adhesion, such as a so-called forum selection clause, are unenforceable unless the party to whom the contract is extended could have rejected the clause without impunity ; xiv. Verify you know and understand that credit card contracts are a series of continuing offers to contract and as such are non-transferable ; xv. Provide verification from the stated creditor that you are authorized to act for them ; xvi. Verify that you know and understand that contacting Me again after receipt of this notice without providing procedurally proper validation of the debt constitutes the use of interstate communications in a scheme of fraud by advancing a writing, which you know is false with the intention that others rely on the written communication to their detriment a violation of 18 United States Code Section 1341. '' I was not provided the requested information nor resolution to this matter. It is a violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act for XXXX to knowingly and willfully report invalid reports on My credit report.

Consumer complaint narrative:
As I was checking my Equifax report I noticed something an inaccurate account on my report. XXXX XXXX XXXX  shows I owe them {$650.00} open : XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX account is not showing maximum possible accuracy according to 15 USC 1681e ( b ), the open date, date last active is not accurate. - Delete Account Immediately for violation of 15 USC 1681e ( b ) According to FCRA Under 15 USC 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) Subject to subsection ( f ) and except as provided in subsection ( g ), if the completeness or accuracy of any item of information contained in a consumer 's file at a consumer reporting agency is disputed by the consumer and the consumer notifies the agency directly, or indirectly through a reseller, of such dispute, the agency shall, free of charge, conduct a reasonable reinvestigation to determine whether the disputed information is inaccurate and record the current status of the disputed information, or delete the item from the file in accordance with paragraph ( 5 ), before the end of the 30-day period beginning on the date on which the agency receives the notice of the dispute from the consumer or reseller. 


I'm a natural person, I am a living being, I have rights under 15 USC 1681.or 15 U.S.C 1681 section 602 A. states I have the right to privacy. In accordance with the fair Credit Reporting act 15 U.S.C 1681 section 604 A. section 2 : It also states a consumer reporting agency can not furnish an account without my written instructions 15 U.S.C 1681c. ( a ) ( 5 ) Section states : no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. 15 U.S.C. 1666b A Creditor may not treat a payment on a credit card account under an open-end consumer credit plan as late any reasons. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I have the right to know exactly how disputed items are verified. I expect you to provide me with complete transparency about the following : The exact process or method your bureau uses to verify disputed items. 
The identity of the entity/entities responsible for carrying out this verification. 
Any documentation or evidence used to support the accuracy of the disputed items. 
I am fully aware of my rights under the FCRA, and I expect full compliance with this request. If you can not provide verifiable proof for these items.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
This letter serves as a formal demand for compliance under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681 et seq., regarding fraudulent information appearing on my credit report due to identity theft. I have provided the necessary documentation to support my dispute and expect immediate action to remove all fraudulent data.

Failure to Block Information Resulting from Identity Theft ( 15 U.S.C. 1681c-2 ) : Under this section, you must block any information identified as a result of identity theft within four ( 4 ) business days of receiving my dispute and required documentation. Failure to do so constitutes a violation of federal law. 

Failure to Reinvestigate Disputed Information ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ) : If you fail to reinvestigate the disputed items within 30 days, you are in violation of this section. 
If you reinstate the fraudulent information without notifying me or conducting a reasonable investigation, you may be in further violation. 
Failure to Notify Data Furnishers ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 2 ) ) : Upon receiving my dispute, you must notify the furnishers of the fraudulent information within five ( 5 ) business days.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
The information listed below is a result of identity theft and is fraudulent. I have never authorized, or opened the accounts listed. This information is frivolous. I request an investigation into fraudulent activities related with my SSN and personal information. Pursuant to the provisions of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( Public Law 91-506, Title VI, Section 611 ) ; Formal Request for Information : I am formally requesting the names and business addresses of each individual or entity you communicated with for verification purposes in relation to the fraudulent transactions identified in my credit report. This request aligns with my right to follow up on the information provided and to assist in this identity theft investigation. Attached is a copy of my government-issued identification and a copy of the identity theft report. I am requesting these fraudulent items removed immediately from my credit files. 
Fraudulent Account : XXXX XXXX : Account # XXXX : Balance : {$1300.00} Fraudulent Account : XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX : Account # XXXX : Balance : {$890.00} Fraudulent Account : State Employees : Account # XXXX : Balance : {$4200.00} Fraudulent Account : XXXX XXXX  : Account # XXXX : Balance : {$4700.00} Fraudulent Account : XXXX XXXX  : Account # XXXX : Balance : {$4400.00} It is unacceptable, and a violation of federal consumer protection laws, that I continue to face harassment and fictitious debts due to the unauthorized account and unauthorized inquiries. Your agency failure to delete these fraudulent entries will be direct violation of my rights under FCRA Section 605B ( 15 USC 1681c-2 ) ( a ). The FCRA requires immediate removal of fraudulent information from credit reports following a valid identity theft report, which I have provided. Such inaction is further aggravating the distress caused by this identity theft. There has been no legal proof of the marks has been provided or proven. I have reported the theft of my identity to the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) and have enclosed copies of the supporting documents, including the FTC Identity Theft Affidavit & Other documents. This unauthorized reporting has negatively impacted my credit standing. I respectfully request that the FTC, FDIC, & CFPB investigate this matter and take appropriate action to ensure that the erroneous and derogatory information is removed from my credit report. I am also pursuing complaints at federal levels to address these violations.

I am writing to formally file a complaint against XXXX and Equifax for false reporting on my credit report, which has significantly damaged my credit score and adversely affected my livelihood.

Inability to secure better financial terms or loans. 

Detrimental effects on my ability to maintain and improve my livelihood. 

Impact on My Livelihood As a result of these inaccuracies, my livelihood has been severely affected. The wrongful classification of my creditworthiness has : Limited my ability to secure essential resources and services. 

Created undue stress and financial hardship.

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
XX/XX/XXXX Subject : Formal Complaint Regarding Inaccurate Late Payments on XXXX XXXXXXXX Account Dear CFPB, I am writing to dispute inaccurate late payments reported on my credit file for the XXXX XXXX account ( Account Number : XXXX ). These late payments, specifically a 30-day late payment for XX/XX/XXXX, a 60-day late payment for XX/XX/XXXX, and a 90-day late payment for XX/XX/XXXX, are incorrect and misrepresent my payment history. 
Nature of the Complaint : Inaccurate Reporting : These late payments are false and inconsistent with my payment records, as I have consistently made on-time payments through autopay. 
Violation of FCRA ( 15 USC 1681i and 1681s-2 ) : Reporting and failing to correct inaccurate information violates the Fair Credit Reporting Act.

Violation of FDCPA ( 15 USC 1692e ) : Reporting incorrect payment history may constitute a deceptive or misleading practice.

Violation of TILA ( 15 USC 1601 ) : The Truth in Lending Act requires the accurate reporting of credit and payment terms.

Civil Liability Under FCRA ( 15 USC 1681n and 1681o ) : Noncompliance with these requirements subjects the responsible parties to legal penalties.

Summary of Discrepancies Equifax Reported 30-day late payment for XX/XX/XXXX, 60-day late payment for XX/XX/XXXX, and 90-day late payment for XXXX XXXX  
Payments were consistently made on time, and no delinquencies occurred. 
Requested Resolution : I request the following : Conduct a thorough investigation and remove the erroneous late payment entries.

Update my credit file to reflect accurate and truthful information.

Provide written confirmation of the corrections within 30 days, as required by the FCRA. 
Enclosed are supporting documents, including payment records, to validate my claim. I expect your prompt attention to resolve this matter. 
Thank you for your immediate cooperation. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/year> i requested validation for the this account -- - **Subject : ** Follow-Up Regarding Disputed Debt : US DEPT OF THE TREASURY Dear Equifax , Thank you for responding to my formal dispute submitted through the CFPB Complaint Portal XXXX While you have stated that the item " Trade : US DEPT OF THE TREASURY '' was verified as belonging to me, your response did not address my specific request for detailed validation of this debt as required under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ).

To clarify, I am requesting : 1. **Evidence Used for Verification : ** Please provide all documentation and evidence relied upon during the investigation, including communication with the furnisher of the information.

2. **Validation Details : ** Specific information regarding the debt, including : - The exact amount owed.

- The name of the creditor to whom the debt is owed.

- The date the debt was incurred. 
- Documentation demonstrating that I am legally responsible for this debt. 
- Proof of assignment or transfer, if applicable. 
- A copy of the original contract or agreement, if available. 

Under the FCRA, you are required to ensure the accuracy and completeness of all information reported in my credit file. Simply stating that the debt was " verified '' is insufficient without providing the requested details to substantiate the claim. 

Additionally, if you can not provide this information, I demand that this item be removed from my credit file immediately. I also request that this debt be marked as " disputed '' until resolution is reached, as per federal law. 

If this matter is not resolved promptly and satisfactorily, I will consider filing a complaint with the CFPB, the FTC, and other relevant regulatory authorities. I reserve the right to pursue further action to protect my rights under the law. 

Please confirm receipt of this correspondence and provide a timeline for your response. I look forward to your prompt attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX ---

Consumer complaint narrative:
XX/XX/XXXX Subject : Dispute of Inaccurate Late Payments on Credit Report Dear CFPB, I am submitting this complaint regarding inaccurate late payments that are reported on my credit file maintained by Equifax. I believe these late payments are erroneous and do not accurately reflect my payment history. 
Nature of the Complaint : Inaccurate Reporting : The late payments listed on my credit report for XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX are inaccurate. My payment history reflects consistent on-time payments, and I have been enrolled in autopay for this account. 
Violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : The inaccurate reporting of these late payments violates my rights under the FCRA ( 15 USC 1666 ( b ) ), as they misrepresent my creditworthiness.

Potential Violation of Fair Debt Collections Practices Act ( FDCPA ) : The reporting of false late payments may also constitute a violation of the FDCPA, which protects consumers from misrepresentation regarding their accounts. 
Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) : I assert that the reporting practices violate the TILA, which mandates accurate reporting of credit information. 
Additionally, the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically sections 15 U.S. Code 1681i and 15 U.S. Code 1681s-2, mandates that credit reporting agencies and information furnishers correct any inaccurate or incomplete information in credit reports and ensure the maximum accuracy of information contained in consumer files. 
Summary of Errors and Discrepancies : The account reflects late payments in XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX, which are inaccurate. 
Payment history should reflect 100 % on-time payments. 
The discrepancies misrepresent my creditworthiness and violate consumer protection laws. 
Requested Resolution : I request that Equifax conduct a thorough investigation into this matter and remove the inaccurate late payments from my credit report. I ask that all such entries be updated to reflect my true payment history of 100 % on-time payments. 
I expect to receive written documentation confirming the removal of these entries within 30 days of this complaint submission. Failure to resolve this issue may lead to further action to protect my rights as a consumer. 
Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

XX/XX/XXXX Subject : Formal Complaint Regarding Inaccurate Late Payment Reporting Dear CFPB, I am filing a formal complaint against Equifax for failing to correct inaccurate information regarding late payments reported on my credit report. Despite multiple requests for correction ( letters dated XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX ), no changes have been made to resolve this issue, in violation of both the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ). Since my last dispute, nothing has changed, and the errors remain on my credit report. 
FCRA Violations : Under 15 U.S. Code 1666b, creditors must send periodic statements at least 21 days before the payment due date. The inaccurate late payment reporting suggests a failure to comply with this requirement. 
15 U.S. Code 1681i mandates that credit reporting agencies ensure the accuracy of information in consumer files. This obligation has not been upheld in my case. 
TILA Violations : The Truth in Lending Act requires creditors to provide accurate and timely disclosures to consumers. The incorrect reporting of late payments has caused significant harm to my creditworthiness and financial well-being. 
Summary of Errors and Discrepancies : The reported late payments for this account are inconsistent and inaccurate across different months and reporting periods. Specific discrepancies include : Late payments incorrectly reported for the following months : XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX. 
Different late payment statuses reported across credit bureaus. 
Dates of delinquency that do not align with the accounts actual payment history. 
These errors significantly misrepresent my credit history and have negatively impacted my creditworthiness. 
Desired Resolution : Immediate removal of the inaccurate late payment notations from my credit report. 
Written confirmation of the correction. 
If this issue is not resolved promptly, I will escalate my complaint further, including potential legal action and filing additional complaints with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and other relevant agencies. 
I look forward to your prompt response to this matter. Please send confirmation of the corrections to the address provided above. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear Sir or Madam : I am a victim of identity theft. I recently learned that my personal information was used to open an account at your company. I did not open or authorize this account, and I therefore request that it be closed immediately. I also request that your company absolve me of all charges on the account, and that you take all appropriate steps to remove information about this account from my credit files. 

Enclosed is a copy of my Identity Theft Report supporting my position, and a copy of my credit report showing the fraudulent items related to your company that are the result of identity theft. Also enclosed is a copy of the CFPBs Notice to Furnishers of Information, which details your responsibilities as an information furnisher to credit reporting agencies ( CRAs ). As a furnisher, upon receipt of a consumers written request that encloses an Identity Theft Report, you are required to cease furnishing the information resulting from identity theft to any CRA.

The Notice also specifies your responsibilities when you receive notice from a CRA, under section 605B of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, that information you provided to the CRA may be the result of identity theft. Those responsibilities include ceasing to provide the inaccurate information to any CRAs and ensuring that you do not attempt to sell or transfer the fraudulent debts to another party for collection. 
Please investigate this matter, close the account and absolve me of all charges, take the steps required under the Fair Credit Reporting Act, and send me a letter explaining your findings and actions. 
Sincerely, [ XXXX XXXX XXXX ]

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
XX/XX/XXXX Subject : Dispute of Inaccurate Late Payments on Credit Report Dear CFPB, I am submitting this complaint regarding inaccurate late payments that are reported on my credit file maintained by Equifax. I believe these late payments are erroneous and do not accurately reflect my payment history. 
Nature of the Complaint : Inaccurate Reporting : The late payments listed on my credit report for XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX are inaccurate. My payment history reflects consistent on-time payments, and I have been enrolled in autopay for this account. 
Violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : The inaccurate reporting of these late payments violates my rights under the FCRA ( 15 USC 1666 ( b ) ), as they misrepresent my creditworthiness.

Potential Violation of Fair Debt Collections Practices Act ( FDCPA ) : The reporting of false late payments may also constitute a violation of the FDCPA, which protects consumers from misrepresentation regarding their accounts.

Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) : I assert that the reporting practices violate the TILA, which mandates accurate reporting of credit information.

Additionally, the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically sections 15 U.S. Code 1681i and 15 U.S. Code 1681s-2, mandates that credit reporting agencies and information furnishers correct any inaccurate or incomplete information in credit reports and ensure the maximum accuracy of information contained in consumer files. 
Summary of Errors and Discrepancies : The account reflects late payments in XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX, which are inaccurate. 
Payment history should reflect 100 % on-time payments. 
The discrepancies misrepresent my creditworthiness and violate consumer protection laws. 
Requested Resolution : I request that Equifax conduct a thorough investigation into this matter and remove the inaccurate late payments from my credit report. I ask that all such entries be updated to reflect my true payment history of 100 % on-time payments. 
I expect to receive written documentation confirming the removal of these entries within 30 days of this complaint submission. Failure to resolve this issue may lead to further action to protect my rights as a consumer. 
Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Dear CFPB, I am writing to file a formal complaint against Equifax for inaccurate reporting of a collection account on my credit report. The inaccurate and incomplete information has caused significant harm to my credit standing and violates the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). 

Key Issues : Inaccurate Reporting of Collection Account : Equifax is reporting a collection account from XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX with a balance of {$840.00}. 
This account is associated with an alleged debt from XXXX XXXX XXXX. that I dispute. 
Failure to Update or Correct Information : The account remains on my credit report despite being disputed previously, with no resolution or evidence provided to validate the debt. 
Equifax has failed to verify the accuracy of the information and continues to report this account as derogatory. 
Violation of FCRA Obligations : Under the FCRA, credit reporting agencies are required to ensure the accuracy of the information they report. Equifax has failed in its duty to investigate and correct this erroneous entry. 
Impact on My Credit Report and Financial Standing : The inaccurate reporting of this account as a collection item has caused severe damage to my credit score, affecting my financial stability and ability to secure credit.

Resolution Requested : Immediate Removal of the Inaccurate Account : I request that Equifax remove the XXXX XXXX XXXX collection account from my credit report due to insufficient documentation and validation of the debt. 
Compliance with FCRA Requirements : Equifax must ensure compliance with the FCRA by verifying the accuracy of all reported information and taking necessary steps to correct any inaccuracies promptly. 
Detailed Investigation and Report : I request that Equifax provide a detailed explanation of its investigation process and the steps it will take to ensure this issue is resolved and does not reoccur. 
Supporting Documents Enclosed : A copy of my Equifax credit report showing the inaccurate reporting of the XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX 
Prior correspondence and documentation related to disputes of this debt with XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 
Impact and Final Request : The inaccurate reporting by Equifax has caused undue financial and emotional stress. I kindly request the CFPBs assistance in ensuring that Equifax resolves this matter promptly and that my credit report is corrected to reflect accurate and validated information. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
XX/XX/XXXX Subject : Formal Complaint Regarding Inaccurate Late Payment Reporting Dear CFPB, I am filing a formal complaint against Equifax for failing to correct inaccurate information regarding late payments reported on my credit report. Despite multiple requests for correction ( letters dated XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX ), no changes have been made to resolve this issue, in violation of both the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ). Since my last dispute, nothing has changed, and the errors remain on my credit report. 
FCRA Violations : Under 15 U.S. Code 1666b, creditors must send periodic statements at least 21 days before the payment due date. The inaccurate late payment reporting suggests a failure to comply with this requirement. 
15 U.S. Code 1681i mandates that credit reporting agencies ensure the accuracy of information in consumer files. This obligation has not been upheld in my case. 
TILA Violations : The Truth in Lending Act requires creditors to provide accurate and timely disclosures to consumers. The incorrect reporting of late payments has caused significant harm to my creditworthiness and financial well-being. 
Summary of Errors and Discrepancies : The reported late payments for this account are inconsistent and inaccurate across different months and reporting periods. Specific discrepancies include : Late payments incorrectly reported for the following months : XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX. 
Different late payment statuses reported across credit bureaus. 
Dates of delinquency that do not align with the accounts actual payment history. 
These errors significantly misrepresent my credit history and have negatively impacted my creditworthiness. 
Desired Resolution : Immediate removal of the inaccurate late payment notations from my credit report. 
Written confirmation of the correction. 
If this issue is not resolved promptly, I will escalate my complaint further, including potential legal action and filing additional complaints with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and other relevant agencies. 
I look forward to your prompt response to this matter. Please send confirmation of the corrections to the address provided above. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
I recently conducted a review of my credit report and found several items that have caused me significant distress. These items appear to be unverifiable, inaccurate, and questionable. Your agency has failed to ensure the accuracy of the information as required under 15 U.S. Code 1681e ( b ) Accuracy of Reports. This statute mandates that consumer reporting agencies must follow reasonable procedures to ensure the maximum possible accuracy of the information they report.

Furthermore, under 15 U.S. Code 1681i ( 5 ) Treatment of Inaccurate or Unverifiable Information, you are required to promptly delete or modify any information found to be inaccurate, incomplete, or unverifiable during a reinvestigation. If you are unable to provide me with verifiable proof of the accuracy of the disputed items within 15 days of your investigation, these accounts and the related information must be removed from my credit report.

Additionally, under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), I do not recognize any of the alleged creditors or debt collectors. I have never entered into a valid contract with any of these entities, nor have I engaged in any transactions with them. As such, these accounts are fraudulent and and inaccurate information. 

Moreover, under the Fair Credit Billing Act, my right to privacy has been violated, and this breach infringes upon my rights as outlined in The Privacy Act of 1974. Removing the inaccurate and fraudulent information from my credit report will help restore my privacy and prevent further violations.

I am entitled to monetary compensation under 15 U.S. Code 1681i ( 6 ), which requires consumer reporting agencies to notify consumers of the results of reinvestigations within five business days after completion. You failed to correct these errors indicates noncompliance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ).

Under the FCRA, if disputed items can not be verified, they must be removed from my report. As per 15 U.S. Code 1681n ( Civil Liability for Willful Noncompliance ) and 15 U.S. Code 1681o ( Civil Liability for Negligent Noncompliance ), your agency may be held liable for failing to comply with federal law. Additionally, 15 U.S. Code 1692k holds entities accountable for violations related to debt collection. Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX ] XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX [ XXXX ] [ XXXX ] XX/XX/year> Equifax Information Services LLC XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Subject : Formal Pre-Arbitration Notice Violations of FCRA and Infringement of Consumer Rights Dear Equifax Information Services LLC , I am writing in response to your correspondence dated XX/XX/year>, which I received on XX/XX/year>. The letter stated that you were unable to locate my credit file due to issues such as my alleged lack of credit activity, lack of application for credit, or failure to reside in the United States. This correspondence is yet another example of Equifaxs ongoing refusal and deliberate hindrance in addressing my requests, constituting further violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). 

Despite your claims in the XX/XX/XXXX letter, I have provided Equifax with numerous verified and comprehensive identification documents through various channels, including the Equifax platform, CFPB, XXXX, and FTC. These documents include : Long-form and short-form birth certificates W-2 form with my complete Social Security Number ( SSN ) Lease agreement showing my current address Utility bills and other documents verifying my current residence The information provided clearly confirms my legal name as XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, with the XXXX always capitalized, and my current address as XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX. Furthermore, both XXXX and XXXX have maintained and displayed this same correct information in my credit files. 

Your continued refusal to accurately locate, update, or maintain my credit file has caused substantial harm and is in direct violation of federal law. 

Additional Infringements Identified The correspondence dated XX/XX/year>, exacerbates the situation by demonstrating the following additional violations of the FCRA : 1. Failure to Provide Clear and Accurate Reasons for File Denial ( 15 U.S.C. 1681g ) : Equifax is required to disclose accurate and complete information regarding why a credit file can not be located or accessed. Your letter provided vague and contradictory reasons, such as a lack of credit activity, despite the fact that I have actively used credit and provided documentation to prove it. 
2. Failure to Conduct a Proper Investigation ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ) : By issuing this letter without properly reviewing the documentation I submitted, Equifax has failed to perform the reasonable investigation mandated by the FCRA when a dispute or issue is raised by a consumer. 
3. Unjustified Delay in Resolution ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ) : It has been over 60 days since my initial dispute, yet Equifax has continued to delay resolving my credit file issues, which is well beyond the 30-day timeframe required by the FCRA. 
4. Failure to Provide Access to My File ( 15 U.S.C. 1681g ) : Your inability to locate my file, despite the extensive and verified documentation I provided, directly violates my right to access my own consumer credit file. 
5. Failure to Correct Inaccurate or Missing Information ( 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ) : Equifax has failed to update my file with new credit accounts and transactions since XX/XX/year>, despite the availability of accurate information from other reporting agencies and the submissions I provided. 

Harm Caused by Equifaxs Negligence Your ongoing refusal to locate and update my credit file, as well as the repeated issuance of vague and incorrect correspondence, has caused me significant harm, including : Financial Damage : Multiple denials for credit due to Equifaxs inability to maintain or provide an accurate credit file. 
Business Losses : Harm to my ability to pursue business financing and professional opportunities. 
Emotional Distress : Frustration and stress caused by Equifaxs continued failure to resolve these issues despite my compliance with every request for documentation. 

Demand for Resolution To rectify this matter, I demand that Equifax take the following actions immediately : 1. Locate and Correct My Credit File : Ensure that my credit file accurately reflects my legal name as XXXX XXXX XXXX and my address as XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 
2. Update My Credit File : Include all new accounts, transactions, and other relevant information since XX/XX/year>. 
3. Provide a Detailed Explanation : Provide a full written explanation of why Equifax has repeatedly failed to locate my credit file despite the verified documentation submitted. 
4. Confirm Compliance : Send written confirmation that my credit file has been located, corrected, and updated in compliance with the FCRA. 

Final Notice This letter serves as formal notice of my intent to pursue arbitration if this matter is not resolved within 10 business days of receipt. Failure to comply will result in further action, including filing formal complaints with the CFPB, FTC, and other regulatory bodies, as well as seeking legal remedies for damages incurred due to your negligence and FCRA violations. 

You may contact me directly at [ XXXX ] or [ XXXX ] to confirm receipt of this letter and provide updates on the resolution. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Sub-issue: Was not notified of investigation status or results
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute inaccurate late payment entries on my credit report regarding my account with XXXX XXXX ( Account # XXXX ). These late payments appear to be reported in error, as the account is marked as Current across all bureaus and there is no valid evidence to support these entries. This is a violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and my rights as a consumer. 
Details of Dispute : Account Name : XXXX XXXX  Account Number : XXXX Disputed Late Payment Entries : o XXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX With discrepancies o Equifax XXXX XX/XX/XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXX/XX/XXXX With discrepancies o XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX With Discrepancies Additional Inaccuracies and Issues XXXX. Future Reporting Dates : o XXXX and XXXX : Last Reported is XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Equifax : Last Reported is XX/XX/XXXX. 
o Reporting dates in the future violates the FCRA 's accuracy and timeliness requirements. 
XXXX. Payment History Discrepancies : o XXXX and Equifax : Show several months with " XXXX late payments ''. 
o XXXX : Shows no similar late payment entries. 
o If the account is listed as " Current, '' there should be no late payments reported. 

XXXX. Comments Conflicts : o XXXX and XXXX : State " Consumer Statement Item in Dispute by Consumer. '' o Equifax : States " Consumer disputes - reinvestigation in progress. '' o These conflicting comments indicate unresolved or inconsistent handling of disputes. 
XXXX. Number of Months ( Terms ) Inconsistency : o XXXX and XXXX : Show 564 months. 
o Equifax : Shows 0 months, which is inaccurate or incomplete. 
XXXX. XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX : o Balance : {$480000.00}. 
o XXXX XXXX : {$500000.00}. 
o The balance does not exceed the high credit, but it requires proper documentation to ensure accuracy. 
XXXX. Date Discrepancies : o Date Last Active : XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : XX/XX/XXXX. 
Equifax : Missing. 
o Date of Last Payment : XXXX and Equifax : XX/XX/XXXX. 
XXXX : Missing.

Violation of Consumer Protection Laws : Violations of 15 U.S.C. 1681 ( FCRA ) : 1. 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies are required to ensure maximum possible accuracy of consumer information. Reporting late payments on a current account violates this standard.

2. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : I have the right to dispute any inaccurate information on my credit report. The bureau must conduct a reasonable reinvestigation to verify its accuracy.

3. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) : If the disputed information can not be verified as accurate, it must be promptly deleted or corrected.

4. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : Information furnishers, such as creditors, are prohibited from knowingly reporting inaccurate information.

5. 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( b ) : Upon receiving notice of a dispute, the furnisher must investigate, review relevant information, and report its findings to the credit bureaus.

FCRA Section 607 ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies are required to ensure maximum possible accuracy when reporting consumer information. The reporting of late payments on a current account fails to meet this standard.

FCRA Section 611 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : I have the right to dispute any inaccurate information on my credit report and demand a thorough reinvestigation.

FCRA Section 611 ( a ) ( 5 ) : If the information can not be verified as accurate, it must be deleted promptly. 
CFPB Standards : The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau mandates that credit bureaus and furnishers maintain fair and accurate reporting practices.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative: According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act 15 USC 1681 section 602 a states " There is a need to insure that consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and a respect for the consumers right to privacy. '' Equifax and XXXX are consumer reporting agencies and I am the Consumer. I have the right to make sure my private information isn't shared which is backed by 15 USC 6801 which states '' It is the policy of the Congress that each financial institution has an affirmative and continuing obligation to respect the privacy of its customers and to protect the security and confidentiality of those customers nonpublic personal information. '' ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) is a financial institution by definition under that title. 15 USC 1681 section 604 a section 2 states that " In general Subject to subsection ( c ), any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report under the following circumstances and no other : in accordance with the written instructions of the consumer to whom it relates. '' ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) the financial institution and the Consumer reporting agencies Equifax and XXXX do not have my consent to furnish this information and they surely do not have my written consent. Any and all consent to Equifax, XXXX, ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) whether it be verbal, non-verbal, written, implied or otherwise is revoked. 15 USC 6802 ( b ) ( c ) states that " A financial institution may not disclose nonpublic personal information to a nonaffiliated third party unless the consumer is given an explanation of how the consumer can exercise that nondisclosure option. '' ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) Never informed me of my right to exercise my nondisclosure option. Not only that 15 USC 1681C ( a ) ( 5 ) states '' Except as authorized under subsection ( b ), no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years. '' This account is an adverse item they are reporting again without my permission which is against the law. 15 U.S. Code 1681s2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A states " A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. 15 U.S. Code 1681e states '' Every consumer reporting agency shall maintain reasonable procedures designed to avoid violations of section 1681c of this title and to limit the furnishing of consumer reports to the purposes listed under section 1681b of this title. Equifax and XXXX are not maintaining reasonable procedures. Also 12 CFR 1016.7 states that " A consumer may exercise the right to opt out at any time. '' I am opting out of your reporting services.

The details of this dispute are outlined below : Background Information : Previous Deletion : In 2023, the information provided by XXXX. XXXX, XXXX was deleted from my credit report after being found inaccurate. 

Re-reporting Without Notice : Despite the previous deletion, XXXX. XXXX, XXXX has re-reported this inaccurate information on my credit report without sending me the required 15-day notice, as mandated by the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). This is a clear violation of my rights. 

Violation of Privacy and Lack of Consent : As a consumer, I have the right to privacy, and I did not give XXXX. XXXX, XXXX permission to obtain or report any information related to my credit or personal data. Under 15 U.S.C. 1681b, no third party, including XXXX. XXXX, XXXX, may access my credit report or report information to the credit bureaus without my express written consent.

The re-reporting of this information without my consent is not only a violation of my privacy rights, but it may also be considered identity theft under applicable consumer protection laws.

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your timely response and resolution of this dispute.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Recently, I did an investigation on my credit report and found several items on there to be inaccurate.

Under 15 U.S Code 1681e ( b ) Accuracy of report Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report. It shall follow reasonable procedures to assure the maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates.

15 U.S. Code 1691i ( 5 ) Treatment of inaccurate or unverifiable information ( A ) In general if, after any reinvestigation under paragraph ( 1 ) of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency shall ( i ) promptly delete that item of information from the file of the consumer, or modify that item of information as appropriate, based on the results of the investigation; and ( ii ) promptly notify the furnisher of that information that the information has been modified or deleted from the file of the consumer.
