Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Debt collection
Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX DUVERA BILLING SERVICES, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Duvera Financial XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Account Number XXXX XXXXXXXX Dear Sir/Madam, Re : Cease and Desist Demand for Inaccurate Reporting / Unauthorized Action on My Credit Report I am writing to formally demand that DUVERA BILLING SERVICES, LL immediately cease and desist from the unlawful or inaccurate actions regarding my credit report. 
I have recently reviewed my credit report from your bureau and found that DUVERA BILLING SERVICES, LL is reporting. These inaccuracies or actions are in violation of my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), which requires credit reporting agencies to maintain accurate and complete information in consumer credit files. 
Specifically, you are in violation of the following provisions : * Section 607 of the FCRA : Ensuring that all information reported is accurate.

* Section 609 of the FCRA : The right to dispute and demand correction of any inaccuracies.

* 15 U.S.C 1692C : If a consumer notifies a debt collector in writing that the consumer refuses to pay a debt or that the consumer wishes the debt collector to cease further communication with the consumer, the debt collector shall not communicate further with the consumer with respect to such debt. 
I request that you : 1. Immediately cease reporting the inaccurate or unauthorized information.

2. Provide me with a written confirmation that the erroneous entry or unauthorized action has been corrected.

3. Cease any further attempts to report or act on inaccurate or disputed information unless verified as correct. 
If this matter is not resolved promptly, I will have no choice but to escalate the issue by filing formal complaints with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), and any other relevant authorities. I also reserve the right to take legal action to enforce my rights under the FCRA and seek any damages or remedies available. 
Please treat this letter as a formal demand to cease all actions related to the disputed information. I expect written confirmation of the resolution within 30 days. 
This letter is sent without prejudice to my rights and remedies, all of which are expressly reserved. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Product: Debt collection
Consumer complaint narrative:
To Whom It May Concern, This formal complaint is regarding inaccurate and derogatory information reported on my credit file by RESURGENT/LVNV FUNDING. This misinformation, which appears on my credit reports from multiple agencies, violates numerous federal laws, industry standards, and state-level consumer protection regulations. I am requesting immediate investigation, removal of the inaccuracies, and confirmation of compliance with federal law across all credit reporting agencies, both primary and secondary. 

Details of the Disputed Information Account Name : RESURGENT/LVNV FUNDING Account Number : XXXX Agencies Reporting the Error : o Primary Bureaus : XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX Bureaus : XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, and any other relevant credit reporting agencies. 
Nature of the Error : [ Describe the error, e.g., " This account is inaccurately reported as delinquent, despite being paid in full on [ date ]. The furnisher has failed to validate this data under the law. '' ] Violations of Federal Laws 1. Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) o 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) : Credit reporting agencies must follow reasonable procedures to ensure the maximum possible accuracy of consumer reports. The continued publication of this inaccurate information violates this section.

o 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) : The CRAs have failed to properly investigate and correct this error within the required 30 days, as required by federal law.

o 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) : Any unverifiable information must be deleted or corrected immediately. The CRAs have violated this by retaining unverifiable data.

o 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) : The furnisher has failed to ensure that the information they report is accurate, as required by this section.

o 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( b ) : The furnisher did not conduct a reasonable reinvestigation after I disputed this account.

o 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( a ) : Obsolete information ( e.g., older than seven years for derogatory marks ) remains on my credit report in violation of federal law.

2. Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) o 15 U.S.C. 1692e : Reporting false and misleading information about a debt constitutes a violation of this section.

o 15 U.S.C. 1692f : Reporting inaccurate derogatory marks constitutes an unfair practice.

3. Metro 2 Reporting Standards o The inaccurate data fails to meet Metro 2 guidelines, which set the industry standard for accurate and consistent credit reporting.

4. FACTA ( Fair and Accurate Credit Transactions Act ) o Under this law, the CRAs and furnishers are required to address inaccuracies related to identity theft and other reporting errors promptly.

Impact of These Violations The inaccurate reporting has caused significant harm, including : Increased interest rates and denial of credit applications.

Damage to my financial reputation, preventing me from securing favorable financial terms.

Increased vulnerability to identity theft due to incorrect data being shared across multiple agencies.

________________________________________ Relief Requested I respectfully request the CFPB to take the following actions : 1. Investigate and Enforce Compliance : o Require [ Creditor/Furnisher Name ] to verify the accuracy of the information reported to all primary and secondary credit reporting agencies.

o Enforce compliance with all federal laws, including FCRA, FDCPA, and FACTA, as well as XXXX XXXX  reporting standards.

2. Remove Inaccurate Data Across All Agencies : o Mandate the removal of this inaccurate information from all credit reporting agencies, including but not limited to : XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX. 
XXXX. Correct and Notify Affected Parties : o Require the CRAs to notify all entities that accessed my credit file in the last six months of the corrected information.

4. Statutory Damages : o Assess penalties for willful violations under 15 U.S.C. 1681n and negligent violations under 15 U.S.C. 1681o.

5. Confirm Updates in Writing : o Provide me with confirmation of the removals and corrections, along with updated credit reports from all agencies, at no cost to me. 

Conclusion The actions of the furnisher and the credit reporting agencies constitute clear violations of federal and state laws, causing me ongoing harm. I request the CFPB 's assistance to ensure my rights are upheld and to prevent further damage to my financial reputation. If this matter is not resolved promptly, I reserve the right to pursue additional legal remedies. 
Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your prompt response. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative: To Chase Bank RE : Form 1099-C Cancellation of Debt I know that reading my credit report that you say i have a chargeoff which is debt that has been discharged and you took a tax write on. After contacting the IRS they explained that it was illegal that you were reporting this information to my credit report trying to collect or having a charged off status. This is called tax fraud upon the irs and you will be reported for such. Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing in response to your request regarding my complaint against LVNV Funding LLC. Below is a summary of the actions I have taken and the ongoing issues with LVNV Funding LLCs handling of my personal information and credit reporting. 

Timeline of Events and Actions Taken : Debt Validation Letter ( XX/XX/XXXX ) : On XX/XX/XXXX, I sent LVNV Funding LLC a Debt Validation letter requesting validation of the alleged debt they are attempting to collect. This is my right under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ). The letter explicitly requested that LVNV Funding LLC provide verification of the debt, including the original creditor, the amount, and other relevant details. 
No response was received from LVNV Funding LLC within the required 30-day period. This lack of response is a violation of my rights under the FDCPA, which mandates that they must provide this validation before continuing any collection activities. 
Cease and Desist Letter ( XX/XX/XXXX ) : On XX/XX/XXXX, I sent a Cease and Desist letter to LVNV Funding LLC, demanding that they immediately stop accessing or reporting my personal information to credit bureaus without my consent. 
This letter also reiterated my rights under 15 U.S.C. 1681b ( Fair Credit Reporting Act ), which requires consumer consent before any third party can access or report my credit information. I have not given LVNV Funding LLC permission to obtain or report my personal or credit information. 
Despite this request, no response has been received from LVNV Funding LLC, and they continue to report inaccurate and unauthorized information on my credit report. 

Key Issues : Unauthorized Access and Reporting : LVNV Funding LLC has been reporting on my credit report without my consent. Under 15 U.S.C. 1681b, they are not permitted to obtain my personal information or report it to credit bureaus without my explicit permission. Their actions are not only a violation of my privacy rights but may also constitute identity theft. 
Failure to Respond : Both my Debt Validation letter and my Cease and Desist letter were sent in good faith, requesting that LVNV Funding LLC provide the necessary documentation and cease their unauthorized actions. However, as of today, they have failed to respond to either request, which further compounds the violation of my rights. 
Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your prompt resolution of this complaint and confirmation that LVNV Funding LLC is taking the appropriate corrective actions. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
I sent LVNV FUNDING a validation letter with no response.

LVNV FUNDING/XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, SC XXXX ACCT # XXXX SUBJECT : Cease and Desist-Request for Deletion of Collection Account Dear LVNV FUNDING I am writing to formally request that you immediately cease all reporting of the collection associated with my name, which appears on my credit report. 

This request is made under the privacy protection afforded to me by 15USC1681I. 
I have reviewed my credit report and noticed that your company is reporting a collection account that is inaccurate or incomplete. 

According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act. I am entitled to dispute any information that I believe to be erroneous, If you do not cease reporting this account. I am formally requesting " Proper Validation and Proof of Claim '' as per the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act. ( FDCPA ) I seek comprehensive validation of the alleged debt, including evidence establishing that I am the party obligated to settle this debt and that there exists a legally binding contractual obligated compelling me to do so. For clarity, I request that all communications be limited to written correspondence until adequate validation of the purported debt is provided. To assist you in meeting this request, please furnish the following required documentation : 1. A copy of the original contract or agreement under which the debt arose.

2. A detailed account statement showing the amount not the debt, including any fees or interest.

3. Date of Last Activity 4. Full accurate social security number that may help to identify me as the correct person you are trying to collect from.

5, Documentation confirming that you have the legal right to collect this debt.

6. Any correspondence related to this account that includes my signature or consent.

I demand that you take the following actions : 1. Immediately cease reporting the collection account associated with my name.

2. Confirm in writing within15 days that this account has been deleted from all credit reporting agencies or provide the requested validation.

Please understand that failure to comply with this request may result in further actions on my part, including but not limited to filing a complaint with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and seeking legal action to protect my rights.

Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter.

Sincerely ( a ) Definitions and rules of construction set forth in this section are applicable for the purposes of this subchapter.

( b ) The term person means any individual, partnership, corporation, trust, estate, cooperative, association, government or governmental subdivision or agency, or other entity.

( c ) The term consumer means an individual.

( d ) Consumer Report.

( 1 ) In general.The term consumer report means any written, oral, or other communication of any information by a consumer reporting agency bearing on a consumers credit worthiness, credit standing, credit capacity, character, general reputation, personal characteristics, or mode of living which is used or expected to be used or collected in whole or in part for the purpose of serving as a factor in establishing the consumers eligibility for ( A ) credit or insurance to be used primarily for personal, family, or household purposes ; ( B ) employment purposes ; or ( C ) any other purpose authorized under section 1681b of this title.

( 2 ) Exclusions.Except as provided in paragraph ( 3 ), the term consumer report does not include ( A ) subject to section 1681s3 of this title, any ( i ) report containing information solely as to transactions or experiences between the consumer and the person making the report ; ( ii ) communication of that information among persons related by common ownership or affiliated by corporate control ; or ( iii ) communication of other information among persons related by common ownership or affiliated by corporate control, if it is clearly and conspicuously disclosed to the consumer that the information may be communicated among such persons and the consumer is given the opportunity, before the time that the information is initially communicated, to direct that such information not be communicated among such persons ; ( B ) any authorization or approval of a specific extension of credit directly or indirectly by the issuer of a credit card or similar device ; ( C ) any report in which a person who has been requested by a third party to make a specific extension of credit directly or indirectly to a consumer conveys his or her decision with respect to such request, if the third party advises the consumer of the name and address of the person to whom the request was made, and such person makes the disclosures to the consumer required under section 1681m of this title ; or ( D ) a communication described in subsection ( o ) or ( x ). [ 1 ] ( 3 ) Restriction on sharing of medical information.Except for information or any communication of information disclosed as provided in section 1681b ( g ) ( 3 ) of this title, the exclusions in paragraph ( 2 ) shall not apply with respect to information disclosed to any person related by common ownership or affiliated by corporate control, if the information is ( A ) medical information ; ( B ) an individualized list or description based on the payment transactions of the consumer for medical products or services ; or ( C ) an aggregate list of identified consumers based on payment transactions for medical products or services.

( e ) The term investigative consumer report means a consumer report or portion thereof in which information on a consumers character, general reputation, personal characteristics, or mode of living is obtained through personal interviews with neighbors, friends, or associates of the consumer reported on or with others with whom he is acquainted or who may have knowledge concerning any such items of information. However, such information shall not include specific factual information on a consumers credit record obtained directly from a creditor of the consumer or from a consumer reporting agency when such information was obtained directly from a creditor of the consumer or from the consumer.

( f ) The term consumer reporting agency means any person which, for monetary fees, dues, or on a cooperative nonprofit basis, regularly engages in whole or in part in the practice of assembling or evaluating consumer credit information or other information on consumers for the purpose of furnishing consumer reports to third parties, and which uses any means or facility of interstate commerce for the purpose of preparing or furnishing consumer reports.

( g ) The term file, when used in connection with information on any consumer, means all of the information on that consumer recorded and retained by a consumer reporting agency regardless of how the information is stored.

( h ) The term employment purposes when used in connection with a consumer report means a report used for the purpose of evaluating a consumer for employment, promotion, reassignment or retention as an employee.

( i ) Medical Information.The term medical information ( 1 ) means information or data, whether oral or recorded, in any form or medium, created by or derived from a health care provider or the consumer, that relates to ( A ) the past, present, or future physical, mental, or behavioral health or condition of an individual ; ( B ) the provision of health care to an individual ; or ( C ) the payment for the provision of health care to an individual. [ 2 ] ( 2 ) does not include the age or gender of a consumer, demographic information about the consumer, including a consumers residence address or e-mail address, or any other information about a consumer that does not relate to the physical, mental, or behavioral health or condition of a consumer, including the existence or value of any insurance policy.

( j ) Definitions Relating to Child Support Obligations.

( 1 ) Overdue support.

The term overdue support has the meaning given to such term in section 666 ( e ) of title 42.

( 2 ) State or local child support enforcement agency.

The term State or local child support enforcement agency means a State or local agency which administers a State or local program for establishing and enforcing child support obligations.

( k ) Adverse Action.

( 1 ) Actions included.The term adverse action ( A ) has the same meaning as in section 1691 ( d ) ( 6 ) of this title ; and ( B ) means ( i ) a denial or cancellation of, an increase in any charge for, or a reduction or other adverse or unfavorable change in the terms of coverage or amount of, any insurance, existing or applied for, in connection with the underwriting of insurance ; ( ii ) a denial of employment or any other decision for employment purposes that adversely affects any current or prospective employee ; ( iii ) a denial or cancellation of, an increase in any charge for, or any other adverse or unfavorable change in the terms of, any license or benefit described in section 1681b ( a ) ( 3 ) ( D ) of this title ; and ( iv ) an action taken or determination that is ( I ) made in connection with an application that was made by, or a transaction that was initiated by, any consumer, or in connection with a review of an account under section 1681b ( a ) ( 3 ) ( F ) ( ii ) of this title ; and ( II ) adverse to the interests of the consumer.

( 2 ) Applicable findings, decisions, commentary, and orders.

For purposes of any determination of whether an action is an adverse action under paragraph ( 1 ) ( A ), all appropriate final findings, decisions, commentary, and orders issued under section 1691 ( d ) ( 6 ) of this title by the Bureau or any court shall apply.

( l ) Firm Offer of Credit or Insurance.The term firm offer of credit or insurance means any offer of credit or insurance to a consumer that will be honored if the consumer is determined, based on information in a consumer report on the consumer, to meet the specific criteria used to select the consumer for the offer, except that the offer may be further conditioned on one or more of the following : ( 1 ) The consumer being determined, based on information in the consumers application for the credit or insurance, to meet specific criteria bearing on credit worthiness or insurability, as applicable, that are established ( A ) before selection of the consumer for the offer; and ( B ) for the purpose of determining whether to extend credit or insurance pursuant to the offer.

( 2 ) Verification ( A ) that the consumer continues to meet the specific criteria used to select the consumer for the offer, by using information in a consumer report on the consumer, information in the consumers application for the credit or insurance, or other information bearing on the credit worthiness or insurability of the consumer; or ( B ) of the information in the consumers application for the credit or insurance, to determine that the consumer meets the specific criteria bearing on credit worthiness or insurability.

( 3 ) The consumer furnishing any collateral that is a requirement for the extension of the credit or insurance that was ( A ) established before selection of the consumer for the offer of credit or insurance; and ( B ) disclosed to the consumer in the offer of credit or insurance.

( m ) Credit or Insurance Transaction That Is Not Initiated by the Consumer.The term credit or insurance transaction that is not initiated by the consumer does not include the use of a consumer report by a person with which the consumer has an account or insurance policy, for purposes of ( 1 ) reviewing the account or insurance policy ; or ( 2 ) collecting the account.

( n ) State.

The term State means any State, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, the District of Columbia, and any territory or possession of the United States.

( o ) Excluded Communications.A communication is described in this subsection if it is a communication ( 1 ) that, but for subsection ( d ) ( 2 ) ( D ), would be an investigative consumer report ; ( 2 ) that is made to a prospective employer for the purpose of ( A ) procuring an employee for the employer ; or ( B ) procuring an opportunity for a natural person to work for the employer ; ( 3 ) that is made by a person who regularly performs such procurement ; ( 4 ) that is not used by any person for any purpose other than a purpose described in subparagraph ( A ) or ( B ) of paragraph ( 2 ) ; and ( 5 ) with respect to which ( A ) the consumer who is the subject of the communication ( i ) consents orally or in writing to the nature and scope of the communication, before the collection of any information for the purpose of making the communication ; ( ii ) consents orally or in writing to the making of the communication to a prospective employer, before the making of the communication ; and ( iii ) in the case of consent under clause ( i ) or ( ii ) given orally, is provided written confirmation of that consent by the person making the communication, not later than 3 business days after the receipt of the consent by that person ; ( B ) the person who makes the communication does not, for the purpose of making the communication, make any inquiry that if made by a prospective employer of the consumer who is the subject of the communication would violate any applicable Federal or State equal employment opportunity law or regulation ; and ( C ) the person who makes the communication ( i ) discloses in writing to the consumer who is the subject of the communication, not later than 5 business days after receiving any request from the consumer for such disclosure, the nature and substance of all information in the consumers file at the time of the request, except that the sources of any information that is acquired solely for use in making the communication and is actually used for no other purpose, need not be disclosed other than under appropriate discovery procedures in any court of competent jurisdiction in which an action is brought ; and ( ii ) notifies the consumer who is the subject of the communication, in writing, of the consumers right to request the information described in clause ( i ).

( p ) Consumer Reporting Agency That Compiles and Maintains Files on Consumers on a Nationwide Basis.The term consumer reporting agency that compiles and maintains files on consumers on a nationwide basis means a consumer reporting agency that regularly engages in the practice of assembling or evaluating, and maintaining, for the purpose of furnishing consumer reports to third parties bearing on a consumers credit worthiness, credit standing, or credit capacity, each of the following regarding consumers residing nationwide : ( 1 ) Public record information.

( 2 ) Credit account information from persons who furnish that information regularly and in the ordinary course of business.

( q ) Definitions Relating to Fraud Alerts.

( 1 ) Active duty military consumer.The term active duty military consumer means a consumer in military service who ( A ) is on active duty ( as defined in section 101 ( d ) ( 1 ) of title 10 ) or is a reservist performing duty under a call or order to active duty under a provision of law referred to in section 101 ( a ) ( 13 ) of title 10 ; and ( B ) is assigned to service away from the usual duty station of the consumer.

( 2 ) Fraud alert ; active duty alert.The terms fraud alert and active duty alert mean a statement in the file of a consumer that ( A ) notifies all prospective users of a consumer report relating to the consumer that the consumer may be a victim of fraud, including identity theft, or is an active duty military consumer, as applicable ; and ( B ) is presented in a manner that facilitates a clear and conspicuous view of the statement described in subparagraph ( A ) by any person requesting such consumer report.

( 3 ) Identity theft.

The term identity theft means a fraud committed using the identifying information of another person, subject to such further definition as the Bureau may prescribe, by regulation.

( 4 ) Identity theft report.The term identity theft report has the meaning given that term by rule of the Bureau, and means, at a minimum, a report ( A ) that alleges an identity theft ; ( B ) that is a copy of an official, valid report filed by a consumer with an appropriate Federal, State, or local law enforcement agency, including the United States Postal Inspection Service, or such other government agency deemed appropriate by the Bureau ; and ( C ) the filing of which subjects the person filing the report to criminal penalties relating to the filing of false information if, in fact, the information in the report is false.

( 5 ) New credit plan.

The term new credit plan means a new account under an open end credit plan ( as defined in section 1602 ( i ) 1 of this title ) or a new credit transaction not under an open end credit plan.

( r ) Credit and Debit Related Terms ( 1 ) Card issuer.The term card issuer means ( A ) a credit card issuer, in the case of a credit card ; and ( B ) a debit card issuer, in the case of a debit card.

( 2 ) Credit card.

The term credit card has the same meaning as in section 1602 of this title.

( 3 ) Debit card.

The term debit card means any card issued by a financial institution to a consumer for use in initiating an electronic fund transfer from the account of the consumer at such financial institution, for the purpose of transferring money between accounts or obtaining money, property, labor, or services.

( 4 ) Account and electronic fund transfer.

The terms account and electronic fund transfer have the same meanings as in section 1693a of this title.

( 5 ) Credit and creditor.

The terms credit and creditor have the same meanings as in section 1691a of this title.

( s ) Federal Banking Agency.

The term Federal banking agency has the same meaning as in section 1813 of title 12.

( t ) Financial Institution.

The term financial institution means a State or National bank, a State or Federal savings and loan association, a mutual savings bank, a State or Federal credit union, or any other person that, directly or indirectly, holds a transaction account ( as defined in section 461 ( b ) of title 12 ) belonging to a consumer.

( u ) Reseller.The term reseller means a consumer reporting agency that ( 1 ) assembles and merges information contained in the database of another consumer reporting agency or multiple consumer reporting agencies concerning any consumer for purposes of furnishing such information to any third party, to the extent of such activities ; and ( 2 ) does not maintain a database of the assembled or merged information from which new consumer reports are produced.

( v ) Commission.

The term Commission means the Bureau. [ 3 ] ( w ) The term Bureau means the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection.

( x ) Nationwide Specialty Consumer Reporting Agency.The term nationwide specialty consumer reporting agency means a consumer reporting agency that compiles and maintains files on consumers on a nationwide basis relating to ( 1 ) medical records or payments ; ( 2 ) residential or tenant history ; ( 3 ) check writing history ; ( 4 ) employment history; or ( 5 ) insurance claims.

( y ) Exclusion of Certain Communications for Employee Investigations.

( 1 ) Communications described in this subsection.A communication is described in this subsection if ( A ) but for subsection ( d ) ( 2 ) ( D ), the communication would be a consumer report ; ( B ) the communication is made to an employer in connection with an investigation of ( i ) suspected misconduct relating to employment ; or ( ii ) compliance with Federal, State, or local laws and regulations, the rules of a self-regulatory organization, or any preexisting written policies of the employer ; ( C ) the communication is not made for the purpose of investigating a consumers credit worthiness, credit standing, or credit capacity ; and ( D ) the communication is not provided to any person except ( i ) to the employer or an agent of the employer ; ( ii ) to any Federal or State officer , agency, or department, or any officer, agency, or department of a unit of general local government ; ( iii ) to any self-regulatory organization with regulatory authority over the activities of the employer or employee ; ( iv ) as otherwise required by law ; or ( v ) pursuant to section 1681f of this title.

( 2 ) Subsequent disclosure.

After taking any adverse action based in whole or in part on a communication described in paragraph ( 1 ), the employer shall disclose to the consumer a summary containing the nature and substance of the communication upon which the adverse action is based, except that the sources of informati

Consumer complaint narrative: On XX/XX/year> I called to dispute a transaction from XXXX for never receiving any products and then them cancelling an annual subscription. I found out I was charged twice on top of it for an amount of {$550.00}. Credit Karma closed the dispute stating no error was made. Ive called them several times and have spent countless hours trying to resolve this matter between XXXX and Credit Karma to no avail. Ive called them again on XX/XX/XXXX to reopen the dispute and having further documentation to show Ive never received anything from XXXX, but I keep being told that someone will call me, but no one has. Its been yet almost another month and nothing has been done. Ive lost {$550.00} to Credit Karma. XXXX has been very cooperative and provided screenshots with their payment processing service showing that they too do not have the funds and that the financial institution ( Credit Karma ) does, yet they refuse to return the funds to me and constantly give me a run around. Upon me calling on the XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, they never reopened the dispute whatsoever. I cant believe any financial institution could behave in this manner. I have a surplus of documentation to support my claim, but they still do nothing. They took the money from XXXX and also refuse to return it to me. Please tell me how this is lawful and acting with integrity. It is not. I feel that this company is practicing in a fraudulent manner, and after so much distress and anguish, I just want this resolved. I want my money back. I am a XXXX XXXX  barely making ends meet and had hoped to purchase the subscription as a XXXX gift, but never received anything and because of Credit Karma, never got my money back either. Please help and stop them from doing this to others. I have also requested copies of any documents they used to make a determination, but they refuse to provide them. They say a supervisor will call me, but they never do. I have nowhere to go for help but here, and I do hope youll help. Please. {$550.00} is a lot for a XXXX person. Especially at XXXX time.

Product: Credit card
Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Consumer complaint narrative:
I accidentally sent a payment through XXXX XXXX from my XXXX XXXX account to a closed credit card account at Chase, which was closed in XXXX. I requested a refund for the payment, but Chase informed me that they could not find a credit card account with them, and it is not linked to my Social Security number. I am seeking clarification on why this payment was processed to a closed account and how I can get the payment refunded. 

I first visited a Chase branch where XXXX assisted me by calling a representative. They couldnt find my credit card account using my Social Security number and said they needed my credit card account number, which I didnt have because the account was closed. I was told they could not find a credit card account with them. I had to look up my credit history at XXXX to find my account number. Once I provided it, Chase said I would have to mail them proof that the funds had been taken from my XXXX XXXX account. 

After a week, I didnt receive anything, so I called customer service, but they couldnt assist me. I went back to the branch, and they reiterated that because my credit card account number wasnt linked to my Social Security number, there was nothing they could do, and I would need to go back to XXXX XXXX to request the money back. 

I visited XXXX XXXX in person, and they confirmed the payment was processed correctly. They declined my claim and said I needed to go back to Chase, as they should have kept my account in the system for over 10 years.

Product: Debt collection
Issue: Attempts to collect debt not owed
Consumer complaint narrative:
This letter is in response to your recent correspondence dated XX/XX/year> regarding the disputed account and your continued communication despite my explicit request for a cease and desist. 

I must reiterate that I formally notified your office on [ Insert Date of Original Letter ] under 15 USC 1692C ( c ) that I refuse to pay the debt in question and that all forms of communication, including reporting this account to any consumer credit reporting agencies, must cease immediately. The only communication I permitted was written correspondence mailed to my address to confirm the deletion of this account from your records. 

Despite this, your letter suggests that you either did not receive my previous request or are willfully ignoring it. Additionally, your communication via phone and your suggestion to continue reaching you via telephone are direct violations of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), which prohibits further contact after a valid cease-and-desist request has been made. 

Furthermore, while you claim to be working with the creditor, you have failed to provide the detailed information I requested to validate this debt under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). I have yet to receive the following : Details of the Investigation : Evidence uncovered to confirm the accuracy and legality of reporting this account. 
Certified Documentation : Copies of certified documents used to validate the account. 
Communication Details : Complete documentation of all communication between your office and the creditor, including dates, participants, and nature of discussions.

Verification Costs : An itemized breakdown of the costs incurred in obtaining the required documentation for verification.

Employee Competency : Names, titles, and qualifications of employees involved in handling the investigation. 
Delinquency Information : Specific date the delinquency commenced and the expected date for cessation of reporting for this account. 
Your failure to provide this information constitutes a violation of my rights under the FDCPA and FCRA, and your ongoing communication disregards my clear refusal to pay the alleged debt. 

Additionally, you acknowledged that the account is currently under review due to identity theft documentation recently submitted. This further underscores the need for you to cease all reporting activity on this account immediately and to conduct a meaningful and thorough investigation as required by law. 

Formal Demands : Immediate Cease of All Communication and Reporting : You must immediately cease all communication regarding this matter, including reporting the account to consumer credit reporting agencies. 
Complete and Specific Verification : You must provide all the requested verification and investigation details outlined in my prior correspondence. 
Written Confirmation : I demand written confirmation of the permanent deletion of this account from all records, including credit reports. 
Failure to comply with these demands will result in formal complaints to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), and appropriate state authorities. I also reserve the right to pursue legal action for violations of my consumer rights under the FDCPA and FCRA. 

This matter must be resolved in full compliance with all applicable federal laws. I expect your response to this letter, along with all requested information, to be sent via written correspondence to my address no later than [ Insert Deadline, e.g., 15 business days from the date of this letter ].

Product: Payday loan, title loan, personal loan, or advance loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint regarding an unresolved issue with Klarna. Recently, I made payments for purchases using Klarna and subsequently received a refund. However, instead of the refund being returned to my original payment method ( my card ), it was deposited into my Klarna wallet/balance. 

I never enabled this option for refunds to go into my Klarna wallet. Despite reaching out to Klarna support multiple times and repeatedly requesting that the refund be sent to my original payment method, I was met with unhelpful responses. Their representative insisted that the feature must have been enabled on my account, even though I did not authorize or activate this option. 

I escalated the issue to speak with a supervisor several times, but Klarna failed to address my concern adequately. They continue to refuse to transfer my refund back to my card, which is the default expectation for refunds. Instead, they are keeping the funds locked in the Klarna wallet, forcing me to use it for future purchases, which I do not want. 

This experience has been frustrating and feels unfair. Klarnas inability to resolve this issue is unacceptable, and I believe they are not acting in good faith. 

I kindly request your assistance in ensuring Klarna refunds the amount to my original payment method as I initially requested. I have attached screenshots of my communication with their support team as evidence.

Product: Mortgage
Sub-issue: Trying to communicate with the company to fix an issue while managing or servicing your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
Our conventional mortgage loan was service transferred from XXXXXXXX XXXX to Mr. Cooper / Nationstar Mortgage with an effective transfer date of XX/XX/XXXX. We were set up with bi-weekly XXXX payments with XXXX and have been attempting to get set back up with bi-weekly XXXX payments with Mr. Cooper / Nationstar Mortgage. 

Our complaint isn't with the servicing transfer, it's with Mr. Cooper / Nationstar 's servicing operations... specifically payment process, escrow operations and customer contact ( phone and XXXX XXXX ). 

We submitted a bi-weekly XXXX  payment request form with Mr. Cooper / Nationstar, as soon as our loan was live, which was acknowledged by Mr. Cooper / Nationstar on XX/XX/XXXX. 

Our {$2700.00} XX/XX/XXXX mortgage payment was received and applied by Mr. Cooper / Nationstar on XX/XX/XXXX. 

We remitted the XX/XX/XXXX payment of {$2700.00} which was received on XX/XX/XXXX and incorrectly applied as a principal only payment. We were told by the Mr. Cooper / Nationstar customer service rep prior to submitting the XX/XX/XXXX payment ( to get XXXX payment ahead to initiate the go forward bi-weekly XXXX payments ) that Mr. Cooper / Nationstar would recognize it as the XX/XX/XXXX payment since our bi-weekly autopay request was on file and not apply it as a principal only payment. 

We had to contact Mr. Cooper / Nationstar on XX/XX/XXXX to have the principal only payment reversed. At that time we noticed that our mortgage payment had increased to {$3000.00} on the Mr. Cooper / Nationstar website due to an Escrow shortage at the time of transfer. In reversing the {$2700.00} principal only payment, we requested that Mr. Cooper / Nationstar apply the {$2700.00} to our escrow account and run a new escrow analysis to recalculate our go forward payment amount. 

We contacted Mr. Cooper / Nationstar on XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX to inquire on the status or escrow shortage payment application and escrow analysis rerun, at which time still had not been rerun. During the last contact on XX/XX/XXXX, I attempted to call Mr. Cooper / Nationstar 3 times and was disconnected all 3 times. I had to resort to using the XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) who was antagonistic and took an hour+ longer to address my questions with the back and forth typing and wait times, than a phone call would have taken to resolve. 

We were attempting to have the bi-weekly XXXX autopay payments begin on Friday XX/XX/XXXX. 

During this time our account was flagged with a past due payment message indicating that late charges were being incurred, even though we are still inside the XXXX transfer grace period. We were even receiving late payment email and text communication pushes, after having communicated with Mr. Cooper / Nationstar at each contact that we were waiting for their system to reflect the correct payment application and amount due. 

At this time we still have not been able to make our XX/XX/XXXX payment as we are waiting for the Mr. Cooper / Nationstar servicing system to reflect the adjusted payment amount. We will need to wait for the XX/XX/XXXX payment to post correctly... then make the XX/XX/XXXX payment and verify that it has posted correctly as a payment and not a principal only payment, and then possibly make the XX/XX/XXXX payment and verify the posting ... before resubmitting the bi-weekly autopay request again to hopefully begin the correct drafting cycle in XX/XX/XXXX.

Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative: I did not give anyone authorization or consent to use my personal information. I hereby exercise my legal rights enacted by Congress and The Federal Trade Commission, which explicitly states when a victim of identity-theft disputes a fraudulent account on his/her credit report it shall be honored by all credit bureaus and all fraudulent information should be blocked within 4 days and proper notification shall be given to all data furnishers pursuant to section 605b of The Federal Fair Credit Reporting Act. Failure to comply shall lead to complaints being filed with XXXX with the Attorney General stating your Companys unlawful collection practices, misrepresentation of creditworthiness, defamation of character, and noncompliance to abide by laws enacted by Congress to protect victims of identity-theft whose credit been impacted by acts of fraud. Because I know my rights under THE FAIR CREDIT REPORTING ACT, CONSUMER CREDIT PROTECTION ACT ( CCPA ), and FAIR and ACCURATE CREDIT TRANSACTION ACT of 2003 ( FACTA ) SEC.312. Procedures to enhance the accuracy and integrity of information furnished to consumer reporting agencies. ( b ) duty of furnishers to provide accurate information. Section 623 ( a ) ( 1 ) of THE FAIR CREDIT REPORTING ACT ( 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) is amended ( 1 ) in subparagraph ( A ), by striking knows or consciously avoids knowing the information is inaccurate and inserting knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate, and ( 2 ) by adding at the end of the following : ( D ) DEFINITION For purposes of subparagraph ( A ), the term reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. Therefore, my position is being clearly stated, these accounts do not belong to me, meaning that you are reporting inaccurate account information within my credit file. The fact that these are inaccurate account information means that you, this credit-reporting agency, are reporting incorrect accounts. 1.WELLS FARGO ( XXXX ) I am well aware of my rights as a consumer. The Fair Credit Reporting Act requires that you, the credit-reporting agency report accurate and/or correct account information within my credit file. My credit issues are very specific, these accounts and/or items do not belong to me. This means that you are reporting incorrect account information within my credit report. It is this in mind that I request that these listed accounts and items be Blocked and Deleted. According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act FCRA, Section 1681c ( 2 ) Block of information resulting from identity theft. 1.Block. Except as otherwise provided in this section, a consumer reporting shall block the reporting of any information in the file of a consumer that the consumer identifies as information that resulted from alleged identity theft, not later than four ( 4 ) business days. I am requesting full validation such as, original transfer rights to collect, confirmation of legal timeline to report on credit and/or collection procedures, validation of licensing requirements, posted bonding requirements, oversight on monthly payment histories, proper subscriber agreement compliance with credit reporting agencies, and overall compliance with all Fair Credit Reporting Act and Fair Debt Collection Practices Act bylaws as mandated by federal laws. If all of these requirements are not in order, then I have the legal right to request the deletion of this tradeline accordingly. I especially desire compliance under the 84-month timeline for deletion of negative information, with the deletion of the account details altogether. My dispute is quite specific in the exception area posted below : 605. Requirements relating to information contained in consumer reports [ 15 U.S.C. 1681c ], Section 609 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), Disclosures to consumers [ 15 U.S.C. 1681g ] ; Section 610 ( a ) ( 1 ) [ 1681h ], and 611.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear CFPB, I am filing this complaint regarding TransUnion 's failure to provide access to my credit report. Despite multiple attempts to retrieve my report through their online platform, I have been met with consistent errors stating that " Your online credit report isnt available at this time, '' as shown in the attached screenshot. 

Key Issues : Inability to Access Credit Report : TransUnions system has consistently prevented me from accessing my credit report. This includes attempts to log out and try again, as their platform suggested.

No alternative method has been provided, and I have been unable to verify or review the information TransUnion is reporting about my credit history.

Lack of Transparency and Assistance : Despite their acknowledgment of this error on their platform, TransUnion has not provided adequate assistance or explanations to resolve this issue.

Violation of Consumer Rights : Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I am entitled to access my credit report to ensure its accuracy and dispute any errors. TransUnions failure to provide my credit report denies me this right and jeopardizes my ability to manage my financial well-being. 
Resolution Requested : Immediate Access to Credit Report : I request that TransUnion resolve the issue and provide immediate access to my credit report via their online platform or alternative methods ( e.g., by mail ).

Investigation into System Errors : TransUnion must investigate the cause of the persistent error and provide a detailed explanation of the steps they will take to prevent such issues from reoccurring.

Assistance in Resolving Disputes : If any inaccuracies are found in my credit report once accessed, I request that TransUnion assist in resolving these issues promptly in compliance with the FCRA.

Supporting Documentation : Attached is a screenshot of the error message displayed on TransUnions platform when attempting to access my credit report. 
Impact and Final Request : This issue has caused significant frustration and has prevented me from exercising my rights under the FCRA. I kindly request the CFPBs assistance in ensuring that TransUnion resolves this matter promptly and provides access to my credit report without further delay. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, FL XXXX Phone : ( XXXX ) XXXX Email : XXXX XXXX

The Fair Credit Reporting Act requires that you, the credit-reporting agency report accurate and/or correct account information within my credit file. My credit issues are very specific, these accounts and/or items do not belong to me. This means that you are reporting incorrect account information within my credit report. It is this in mind that I request that these listed accounts and items be Blocked and Deleted. If all of these requirements are not in order, then I have the legal right to request the deletion of this tradeline accordingly. I especially desire compliance under the 84-month timeline for deletion of negative information, with the deletion of the account details altogether. My dispute is quite specific in the exception area posted below : 605. Consumer complaint narrative:
I was charged {$130.00} for personal training on XX/XX/XXXX by XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX The merchant is located at XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX. The merchant claimed in there statement response to Citibank that I did not request cancellation. I however requested cancellation on 4 separate occasions. Gym 's can be notorious for declining to process a customers cancellation request in an effort extend the recurring charges to the member. 

( A ) On XX/XX/XXXX I prepaid for four individual weeks total personal training sessions ( month of XXXX ). 

( B ) On XX/XX/XXXX, the gym opened. 

( C ) On XX/XX/XXXX, I was charged {$130.00} for two personal training sessions to begin in the month of XXXX. This charge occurred after I requested cancellation in person at the gym facility, with a representative by the name of XXXX on XX/XX/XXXX. This is more than 30 days advance of the month of XXXX, which is what the {$130.00} charge on XX/XX/XXXX was applicable for. 

First time I requested cancellation in person on XX/XX/XXXX. This request was not processed by XXXX XXXX due to employee error. 

Second time I requested cancellation on XX/XX/XXXX. 

Third time I requested cancellation on XX/XX/XXXX. 

Fourth time requested cancellation on XX/XX/XXXX, and it was only after this charge that the cancellation request was processed. This gym facility opened on XX/XX/XXXX and I do not believe the staff was adequately trained to handle my cancellation request hence the reason it took four separate attempts to cancel. 

The {$130.00} charge incurred on XX/XX/XXXX was for prepayment of personal training sessions on XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX. I was charged the {$130.00} for personal training charges for services that were not rendered as my last session with my personal training was on XX/XX/XXXX and the statement from XXXX XXXX also indicates that my last personal training session was on XX/XX/XXXX. 

I have provided supporting documentation to Citibank and my dispute status is still indicated in favor of the merchant ( XXXX XXXX ) who claim no notice of cancellation was received. I have no other credit disputes on my card with Citibank in the last XXXX years so it is not common for me to dispute a charge with a merchant. However, in this instance, the staff did not process my cancellation request and it took three additional requests before the merchant finally cancelled the recurring charges. 

Citibank Customer Service po box XXXX XXXX XXXX, SD XXXX XXXX CITIBANK CASE ID : XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
I have auto and renters insurance with USAA and on XX/XX/year> I was prompt to select my USAA dividends choice for the 2024 disbursement. My choice was a deposit to my XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. 
On XX/XX/year> the amount of {$77.00} for the USAA dividend disbursement was posted as a credit to my auto insurance balance. 
On XX/XX/year> I requested through a XXXX  complaint that USAA  review my dividend choices and provide me with an explanation on how a credit to my auto insurance balance was determined, rather then a deposit to my XXXX  checking account as I originally selected on XX/XX/year>. 
By XX/XX/year> I had not yet received any correspondences or phone calls from USAA in regards to that request, so I contacted USAA through their XXXX number to get an update on the status of my request and was advised that my case was being handled by a representative named XXXX. 
I was then connected to XXXX XXXX and when I asked for explanation on how the dividends credit was redirected and posted to my auto insurance balance, I requested that USAA guidelines be provided to me in writing, so she sent me an email with inaccurate information where it states that my XXXX  checking account was inactive or closed, however, my XXXX checking account is open and active. 
As we switched concerns to my auto insurance billing and payments, at XXXXne point of our conversation I no longer felt comfortable with her tone, so I advised her that I was going to end our conversation then and disconnected my call. 
A few minutes after I ended our conversation, XXXX XXXX proceeded to call me again, so I advised her a second time that I did not want to continue discussing my case with her. 
I immediately contacted USAA and spoke to another representative named XXXX. 
I explained to him the situation and requested that XXXX XXXX do not further contact me. I also put a request with him that another representative be assigned to take over my case, as still have questions and concerns about my insurance billing and dividends explanation. 
On XX/XX/year> I received XXXX USAA emails from XXXX XXXX. 
I am confident that XXXX XXXX is an excellent professional, but since I did not feel comfortable discussing my account and billing with her, and I still have questions and concerns to be clarified, I request that she be removed from my case and my concerns be re-assigned and directed to a different USAA representative to further discuss my account history and payment information. 
Screenshots are attached for further review.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
To Whom It May Concern, I am submitting this complaint regarding Experians failure to address and correct the inaccuracies on my credit report. I am requesting immediate action to resolve the discrepancies I have encountered. 

After reviewing my credit report, I discovered multiple inaccuracies related to my personal identifying information. Specifically, there are several variations of my name, address, and date of birth that are incorrect. As these inaccuracies can significantly impact my financial standing and creditworthiness, I requested that Experian correct these issues by removing the erroneous entries. 

On XX/XX/year>, I sent a request to Experian to address these inaccuracies. Despite my detailed and direct request, Experian has failed to take the necessary steps to resolve the matter. In response, I have only received automated messages that do not properly address the substance of my dispute. From my understanding, automated responses to disputes are prohibited under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). According to Section 1681i of the FCRA, credit reporting agencies must investigate disputes and provide a meaningful response within 30 days. However, Experian has failed to respond appropriately, and it is clear that my disputes have been auto-verified without an actual investigation into my concerns.

I have provided clear and sufficient information in my dispute letters, including multiple variations of my identification documents, my Social Security Number, and my date of birth, all of which were attached to each of my letters. I have made it impossible for Experian to claim that they are unable to verify my identity. The lack of a direct response to my specific concerns, and the continued request for the same personal information, shows a lack of proper attention to my dispute. 

These stall tactics are a violation of my rights as a consumer. Under the FCRA, I am entitled to accurate and up-to-date information being reported on my credit report. Experians failure to address these inaccuracies is impacting my financial standing and causing unnecessary delays and complications with my credit applications. This ongoing issue is in violation of my consumer rights under the FCRA, which ensures the accuracy and integrity of the information reported on my credit report. 

In addition, Experians failure to comply with XXXX XXXX standards, which are used for the accurate reporting of credit data, further contributes to the ongoing issue. The discrepancies on my credit report have caused significant harm to my ability to secure credit, as financial institutions have been unable to properly verify my identity. 

I request that the CFPB take appropriate action to ensure that Experian complies with the law and addresses these inaccuracies on my credit report. A proper resolution would be for Experian to remove all variations of the following personal identifying information that do not match the correct information below : Correct Information : Name : XXXX XXXX Address : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX, XXXX, NC XXXX I expect Experian to promptly correct this issue and provide a meaningful response that addresses the discrepancies. If Experian continues to fail to comply with the law, I request that appropriate legal actions be taken to hold them accountable for their failure to maintain accurate credit reporting. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I look forward to a resolution and a response at your earliest convenience. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Product: Student loan
Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
in CFPB complaint # XXXX I reported that the aggregate student loan totals being reported by the NSLDS were incorrect due to the fact that capitalized interest was being added to the loan total balances. I should still be eligible to receive {$24000.00} in direct student loans to continue my education. I asked NSLDS to correct the issue. The response I received from NSLDS confirmed my complaint. The response from NSLDS is as follows : -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- " This is an interesting one, but I can assure you that our code is doing nothing incorrectly and capitalized interest is not being added to the aggregate for any consolidation loan. I attached my worksheet where I compared their loans with our aggregate limits and their aggregate totals ; everything is accurate. 

The issue is that NSLDS cant find a link between their consolidation loans and their consolidated loans ( PN status ). The respective dates are too far apart for us to calculate a link between the open consolidation loans the consolidated loans and we dont have any valid reported linkages in our system ( this would be a servicer issue to report status date correctly ). 

Because we cant find an association, we ignore the consolidated loans and take the OPB of the consolidation loan at face-value and reflect it in the recipients XXXX totals. That explains why theyre exceeding their XXXX Subsidized and Combined Limits, but for their Graduate totals, theres not much nuance. They have XXXX XXXX loans that have a Graduate academic level and were calculating each of their respective Aggregate OPB correctly and reflecting it in the Graduate Unsubsidized Total. 

Only two loans are being impacted by Capitalized Interest amounts, both are Direct Stafford Unsubsidized ( NOT Consolidation ) loans. And for their PLUS Additional Unsub loans, theyre all Graduate loans, and we only increase their limits when the recipient is a Dependent Undergraduate. So nothing impacted there. '' -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- LEGAL REPORT TO THE COURT I. Introduction Comes now the undersigned counsel, on behalf of the student borrower ( Plaintiff ), to address the improper accounting methods used by the loan servicer and/or relevant educational agency ( Defendant ( s ) ) in calculating the Plaintiffs student loan aggregate limits. Despite Plaintiff having remaining loan eligibility of approximately {$24000.00}, Defendant ( s ) have improperly reduced Plaintiffs eligibility by including capitalized interest in the loan principal for the purpose of aggregate loan limit calculations. This practice violates the Higher Education Act of 1965 ( HEA ), as amended, and its implementing regulations under Title 34 of the Code of Federal Regulations ( C.F.R. ), and deprives Plaintiff of financial aid to which they are legally entitled. 

II. Statement of Relevant Facts Plaintiff maintains multiple federal student loans, including Direct Subsidized, Direct Unsubsidized, and certain Direct Consolidation Loans. 
According to Defendant ( s ) own admissions, only two of Plaintiffs Unsubsidized loans have capitalized interest. Nonetheless, the total capitalized interest is being counted toward Plaintiffs aggregate loan limits.

Defendant ( s ) also acknowledge the lack of proper linkages between the consolidation loans and the underlying loans, but they continue to overstate the outstanding principal balance ( OPB ) by including capitalized interest amounts in the aggregate calculation for new loan eligibility. As a direct result, Plaintiffs eligibility for an additional {$24000.00} in federal loans has been wrongfully denied. 

III. Applicable Law and Regulations Higher Education Act ( HEA ), 20 U.S.C. 1070 et seq.

Under the HEA, federal student loans are subject to specific statutory and regulatory frameworks that govern annual and aggregate borrowing limits.

Aggregate Loan Limits Under 34 C.F.R. 685.203 This regulation sets the maximum annual and aggregate loan amounts that a student may receive in Direct Subsidized and Direct Unsubsidized Loans. Nowhere does it authorize the loan servicer to include unlawfully capitalized interest in the principal balance for the purpose of restricting further loan eligibility. 

Provisions on Capitalized Interest, 34 C.F.R. 685.202 ( b ) While the regulation permits the capitalization of interest under certain conditions ( e.g., during periods of deferment or forbearance if interest is not paid ), it does not allow such capitalized amounts to be deemed principal when determining a students eligibility under the aggregate limits. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX. XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXXXXXX ) stands for the principle that the Department of Education and its agents must adhere strictly to statutory and regulatory directives. A failure to comply with regulatory provisionssuch as improperly interpreting or expanding the scope of aggregate loan amountcan render the agencys action arbitrary, capricious, or otherwise not in accordance with law. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX XXXX ) ( cited for persuasive value ) similarly underscores that loan servicers must follow the precise regulatory guidelines established by the U.S. Department of Education when assessing interest, principal, and overall borrower eligibility. 

IV. Legal Argument Violation of 34 C.F.R. 685.202 ( b ) and 685.203 The Defendant ( s ) accounting practices contravene the Department of Educations regulations by counting capitalized interest as part of the outstanding principal for purposes of assessing new loan eligibility. See 34 C.F.R. 685.202 ( b ) ( authorizing capitalization but not including such interest in statutory or regulatory eligibility calculations ). 

Under 34 C.F.R. 685.203, the aggregate loan limit calculation is intended to cap the total amount a student may borrow in principalnot artificially inflated balances caused by servicing errors or improper capitalization. The unauthorized inclusion of capitalized interest in the aggregate effectively denies XXXX the loan funds to which they are statutorily entitled. 

Violation of the Higher Education Act ( 20 U.S.C. 1071 et seq. ) The Defendant ( s ) practice is directly at odds with Congresss intent to ensure access to federal loans within prescribed statutory limits. By artificially reducing Plaintiffs borrowing capacity, Defendant ( s ) violate 20 U.S.C. 1078 and related provisions that aim to protect student borrowers from arbitrary or capricious denials of loan eligibility. 

Failure to Properly Link Consolidation Loans to Underlying Loans Defendant ( s ) admit to a deficiency in linking consolidation loans to their underlying loans, thereby forcing the system to treat the entire consolidation loans OPB, including capitalized interest, as an undergraduate balance. This administrative error breaches their regulatory duty to accurately represent the borrowers correct loan history. XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX XXXX ). 

V. Conclusion and Prayer for Relief Wherefore, based on the foregoing, Plaintiff respectfully requests this Court to : Declare that Defendant ( XXXX ) current practice of including improperly capitalized interest in the aggregate loan limit calculation violates 34 C.F.R. 685.202 ( b ) and 685.203, and is therefore illegal. 

Enjoin Defendant ( s ) from continuing these unlawful accounting practices and order them to recalculate Plaintiffs aggregate loan balances excluding any improperly capitalized interest that is not allowed by law. 

Restore Plaintiffs eligibility for the additional {$24000.00} in federal student loans, as guaranteed under the HEA and its implementing regulations.

Grant any further relief that this Court deems just and proper. 

Respectfully submitted, XXXX XXXX

I have a Capital One XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX and pay {$390.00} per year for that card. One of the benefits that they offer with that card is an annual {$300.00} travel credit. I just checked my account with hopes of using that credit, but found that it had " expired '' in mid XXXX and been replaced with a new {$300.00} for this year. They tell me that these credit expire if not used within 12 months. They tell me that this is noted in the card specifications. It may well be, but that should not allow they to steal the credit that I paid for without adequete warning. I believe that they've effectively stolen {$300.00} from me. I paid them {$390.00} each year with an expectation of receiving the promised {$300.00} travel credit, but without warning, they've deleted it. 
In my mind, the only appropriate option is to reinstate the " expired '' credit.

Product: Vehicle loan or lease
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XXXX XXXX I submitted a complaint regarding Title XXXX subsection XXXX of my SCRA rights being vuolated as the original document stated that I am waiving my rights and per this act, I do not have to. This was after countless attempts of getting them to amend this document without success- it took until submitting a complain through CFPB that they did something about it, and amended the document. 

However, after reviewing their response and updated waiver, it is much better than the first one they sent me. However after meeting with my lawyer again about this, there is still some issue with the verbiage : it still states that I voluntarily and knowingly waive the protections against repossession afforded under the SCRA. Instead it should say " I am willingly utilizing my rights to surrender the vehicle under the SCRA '' as I do not wish to waive my rights. This should be corrected and the issue would be resolved. Otherwise it feels like their is a hidden motive by stating that I waive any part of my right.

I've disputed this information with the credit bureaus and they are refusing to delete this information. This also is a cease and desist. According to 15 USC 16 96 G I'm entitled to a history of payments paid by me as the keep stating I gave an account with their company as I have never never done any business with this company. I would also like to see my signature on this account guaranteeing I would pay this creditor. I'm asking has there been any insurance claim found on this debt. I want proof on a change of title that you can collect on this debt. They are stating I owe them a debt and I have yet to receive a validation of debt which is mentioned above. I have repeatedly asked for this company to delete this information from my credit report and they have refused. I have asked for validation of debt and they have yet to provide any according to the information provided above. I've never done business with this company and if they continue to report on my credit report they are in violation of the law and I'm entitled to {$XXXX} per violation. They needs to delete any and all information that is related to me and if they refuse I will use all laws applicable to me and sue. I'm a XXXX in which our information has at times appeared on our credit reports or it may be neither of ours. No matter what the situation may be I've never done business with this company or have a signed contract and this information must be deleted

Consumer complaint narrative:
Recently I did an investigation on my credit report and found several items on there to be inaccurate.

Under 15 U.S. Code 1681e ( b ) Accuracy of report Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report, it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure the maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates.

15 U.S. Code 1681i ( 5 ) Treatment of inaccurate or unverifiable information ( A ) In general if, after any reinvestigation under paragraph ( 1 ) of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency shalli ) promptly delete that item of information from the file of the consumer, or modify that item of information, as appropriate, based on the results of the reinvestigation; and ( ii ) promptly notify the furnisher of that information that the information has been modified or deleted from the file of the consumer.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XX/XX/XXXX Subject : Formal Complaint Regarding Inaccurate Late Payments on XXXX XXXXXXXX Account Dear CFPB, I am writing to dispute inaccurate late payments reported on my credit file for the XXXX XXXX account ( Account Number : XXXX ). These late payments, specifically a 30-day late payment for XX/XX/XXXX, a 60-day late payment for XX/XX/XXXX, and a 90-day late payment for XX/XX/XXXX, are incorrect and misrepresent my payment history. 
Nature of the Complaint : Inaccurate Reporting : These late payments are false and inconsistent with my payment records, as I have consistently made on-time payments through autopay. 
Violation of FCRA ( 15 USC 1681i and 1681s-2 ) : Reporting and failing to correct inaccurate information violates the Fair Credit Reporting Act.

Violation of FDCPA ( 15 USC 1692e ) : Reporting incorrect payment history may constitute a deceptive or misleading practice.

Violation of TILA ( 15 USC 1601 ) : The Truth in Lending Act requires the accurate reporting of credit and payment terms.

Civil Liability Under FCRA ( 15 USC 1681n and 1681o ) : Noncompliance with these requirements subjects the responsible parties to legal penalties. 
Summary of Discrepancies Equifax Reported 30-day late payment for XX/XX/XXXX, 60-day late payment for XX/XX/XXXX, and 90-day late payment for XX/XX/XXXX. 
Payments were consistently made on time, and no delinquencies occurred. 
Requested Resolution : I request the following : Conduct a thorough investigation and remove the erroneous late payment entries.

Update my credit file to reflect accurate and truthful information.

Provide written confirmation of the corrections within 30 days, as required by the FCRA.

Enclosed are supporting documents, including payment records, to validate my claim. I expect your prompt attention to resolve this matter. 
Thank you for your immediate cooperation. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
Apparently, XXXX XXXX XXXX opened a credit card account in my name without properly verifying the actual applicant. I don't recall how I actually became aware of the account a couple of years ago ( likely I saw a credit report ). I contacted XXXX when I became aware of the account and well after it was in default. XXXX confirmed over the phone that it did not have my correct contact information in its records until I reached out to them to let them know that I never opened any account with them. XXXX however refuses to correct its error that it should not have opened the account to begin with. I called XXXX several times and also wrote them a couple of letters explaining everything to them, but they refuse to change anything. XXXX has continued to damage my credit by reporting the account as mine, which became delinquent which they eventually wrote-off. 

XXXX was completely negligent in how it issued the credit card. If it had bothered to confirm an email address or confirm a phone number, it would have known it had incorrect information, or at least have some way to trace who really opened the account. How it is possible a card issuer would not bother to at least verify contact information for someone applying for credit? And why is such a high burden placed on an innocent party to correct a card issuer 's mistake? There don't seem to be any consequences to XXXX for its negligence or unwillingness to correct its mistake, but I suffer the consequences of destroyed credit. 

After trying to get XXXX to correct the error, I reached out the credit reporting services to see if they could correct the reporting. XXXX " investigated '' and somehow " verified as accurate '' the debt, but it would be impossible to confirm that it is my debt because it is not mine. ( My appeal was received the same letter in response. The " Adverse '' information of the delinquency will remain on XXXX 's reporting until XX/XX/XXXX unless some action is taken. ) As part of the XXXX correspondence, I noticed another credit card account with Citicards XXXX that I had been completely unaware of. When I called Citicards, they were unable to find any record of any account in my name or with my SS #. When I asked how is possible then that a delinquent account from Citi would show up as " Adverse Information '' on my credit report, the rep did not have an answer. The Citicard rep on the phone seemed like she would be taking action to correct the problem, but I don't know what is happening. ( I only discovered the Citicard account issue this week even though the account was opened in XXXX. My credit report shows the negative information will not be removed until XX/XX/XXXX unless something is done. ) In XX/XX/XXXX, I filed an Identity Theft statement with the FTC and sent it to XXXX and XXXX. I spoke with XXXX again by phone earlier this week, provided all the information again, but nothing has changed. The representative suggested I file a complaint with the CFPB, which is what I am doing now. 

I am guessing my name an SS # were part of a data leak ( likely through the Government Personnel Office who did a background check on me and whose data breach was massive is widely known ). Whatever the source, data leaks are extremely common and credit issuers should know this and take basic steps to confirm someone's identity before issuing credit ( the CFPB did more to confirm my contact information to use this website than the credit card issuers did for whoever opened these accounts in my name. ) In a more just world, the burden would not be placed on the victims to correct the problems that occur through credit card companies being negligent in their processes. In an even more just world there would be fines or class action suits for all the harm they cause by doing this. I am sure I am not the only one whose credit has been ruined by these bogus accounts. Despite my excellent record on my actual credit accounts, these relatively small fraud items are killers. I did not do anything wrong, but the burden is on me to keep calling giant and uncaring institutions, dealing with their automated replies, writing new letters in response, filing forms with the FTC and CFPB. How is this system fair? I was not in a position to prevent what the card companies did ( they could have prevented it ) but I am the one who gets screwed.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
